review_title: Culture is King at Concur
job_title: Customer Engagement Executive in Nashville, TN
pros: Working at SAP Concur has been the most rewarding and fulfilling career opportunity I could have hoped for during my career building years (28 - 34+). I've been part of Concur pre-acquisition and post-acquisition (SAP) and the culture has not changed even in the slightest. The work-life balance, focus on health and wealth,  individual career and personal growth, and the complete buy-in from leadership has not changed. SAP is an amazing  global organization that does the right things and takes care of their people.
cons: Concur is the 800lb gorilla in the room and continues to be the market leader in the Travel & Expense software.  Innovation and product improvements are the two areas that need more focus, but changing such a massive cloud based software product that is used by millions daily around the globe is a challenge, but they're making strides. SAP is one of the top 4 ERP and Business Suites giants in the world, but "Running Simple" is sometimes the hardest part of using SAP products.

review_title: Great environment, great people and great work!
pros: You have the freedom and flexibility to work without someone bossing over you.The facilities and perks are great which make you want to stay at work. The people who work here are unanimously nice, working together like a well oiled machine.
cons:
College freshmen are hired in droves but there is no mechanism or process to ensure they start contributing to their teams and the company goals. Very frustrating to deal with.
Salary hikes haven't been that great for a few years now.

review_title: User Experience Designer
pros:
- It has all the corporate benefit, but the team is super active
- They are hiring a lot of fresh grads! This is great opportunity so YOUNG PEOPLE, JOIN THE COMPANY NOW! Great career opportunity for you

I just joined a team and all my teammates are fresh grads. At the same time I got opportunity to work with VP together, and the VP guy is super nice and knowledgable. I feel very happy about this whole team culture (while I can work together with teammates on similar age, I still get mentored and discussing with Senior/VP level people easily.

AWESOOOOOME WORK LIFE BALANCE! wfh Fridays/meetings at Palo Alto office(where they got AWESOME cafe and other great stuff!

On my day 1 I met a guy who also choose to leave Amazon's Seattle office to come here. He said this company is much better on every level, benefits/work life balance/etc.
cons: - I feel like it's a bit political sometimes... just a bit, but it's ok. Even Google is political (don't be surprised!) It happened everywhere and you need to learn how to deal with it.

review_title: Very interesting job and high learning curve
pros:
My top 3 reasons for SAP: 
- pretty bright people including mathematicians, physicists, philosophers; this makes talks at lunch even more interesting (well, I'm interested in a some topics - these are a few of them)
- the canteen offers most of the time nice dishes for launch (also with different nationalities, e.g. italian, thai, indian, ...)
- I am working myself on my (interesting!) project and as long as I deliver results, I'm free to decide how I want to approach the problem (maybe this not the case for all employees, but I think for many)

Now I just remembered one additional pro - so I'll make it 4: the great health support, e.g. get a chair and table (one which can be extended, such that one is able to stand) which suit you, take sport courses for free, ...
cons: Honestly, I didn't notice yet anything that would annoy me. Maybe this will change at some time, but after one year employment I'm pretty happy.

review_title: Good opportunity for students
pros:
Friendly enviroment, good working conditions. People are friendly and mostly willing to help.  
SAP looks relatively good in the CV.
They hire lot of students and also foreigners.
The range of benefits is also fine (meal vouchers, cafeteria after the probe period, sick days, small gym in the builging etc.)
cons:
It is shared service center - the work is dull (copy and paste + check lists haha) and not very challenging. Limited carreer growth.
Massive fluctuation - my buddy and other senior colleague (1+ year experience) in the team were leaving when they were training me. Other colleagues in the team were new hires or hired few months before I was.
Salary was very poor and no matter how hard you work the annual increase is almost nothing (700 CZK in my case which is about 25 EUR and this was before tax! ).  The colleagues in finance said it was even less.

review_title: Researcher / Architect
pros: Relatively stable employer. There haven't been many layoffs through its history and even in the case of layoff, people are usually well compensated (e.g. 6 monthly salaries). If you have the chance to work with customers,  there could be some interesting projects due to the big size of the company and the diverse customer base. Work life balance if reasonable (e.g. 30 days paid vacation, home office, gym at the office). People in the office are generally nice as well.
cons:
Salary growth plans can be conservative and often favor newcomers and job hoppers. Some projects can be really boring and a bad move for one's career in the long run. Implementation of SCRUM was not and still isn't good. It feels too much like Ford's assembly line and not so much like a creative process.
Canteen in Sofia is average, but for people not generally concerned about healthy diet, it seems acceptable.

review_title: I  thought I found a gem of a company when I learned Software Giant SAP was in Old Town Scottsdale
job_title: Inside Sales Executive in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: 1. Well-known in IT industry 2. Free lunch program 3. Lots of tools for personal development 4. Smart people to network with.
cons: Simple...Management in the Scottsdale office. They ask us to run deals as if we were in the field and then reward us with scavenger hunts. Morale is so bad, yet management thinks nothing is wrong and continues to go to lunch with each other and hang out on the weekend and attend each other's weddings. Describing management as delusional would be a compliment. If you come to work at SAP...don't go to Scottsdale.

review_title: Management stifles any incentive to work hard
pros:
- Many perks including lunch card (taxable income) and gym on site
- Other coworkers are often nice people
cons:
- Culture of complacency
- Management is on aggressive delivery schedule and that trickles down to employees, however, compensation and employee treatment is not nearly at a level where employees feel like they will be rewarded for working hard
- Salary is comparatively low in relation to similar companies
- No room for growth, either career-wise or salary-wise. Starting salary is reasonable, but does not grow very much down the line (think logarithmic growth)

review_title: SAP truly deserves its spot on the "best places to work" list
job_title: MBA Management Associate in Newtown Square, PA
pros:
SAP's management understands that employees work harder when they feel valued and empowered.  Management truly believes in SAP's mission as a purpose-driven organization and encourages employees to bring their whole selves to work. 

SAP also promotes work-life balance. The company's global nature creates an environment where your work product speaks for itself, not the hours of face time you put in at the office. Accordingly, most employees can easily work without any negative consequences or judgement. This is great for working parents and other employees who value the flexibility to create their own schedules.
cons: The company's global nature leads to frequent virtual meetings, with few in-person meetings based on your location. If you want more in-person interaction, you need to go to the office. Yet sometimes the office isn't heavily trafficked, depending on the location. This is usually mitigated by travel to meet your team at events throughout the year.

review_title: Great company, great culture
pros:
Genuinely fosters a sense of caring about employees
Great company culture
Fairly competitive salaries
Good benefits
cons:
1. SAP varies the benefits it offers its employees based on geography. Employees in the US, for example, get significantly less paid parental leave than those in Europe. 
Ex. In Europe, the *minimum* a new mother can take is 15 weeks, and she can take up to 26. In the US, the *maximum* is 12 weeks. 

For a company that talks a lot about taking care of its employees, it seems somewhat hypocritical to treat them all differently, working within the minimum guidelines laid down by law. 

2. Internal raises and salary increases are fairly stagnant. Practically the only way to get a significant raise within SAP is to get a new job in a different department. This is awful, because then those with much higher expertise and product knowledge just... leave. Regular actual raises for increased expertise and product knowledge would save SAP a fortune in hiring and training newbies, as well as improve employee morale and help retain good workers.

review_title: Worked with great people on interesting projects but frustrated by management decisions and interteam conflicts.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in La Crosse, WI
pros:
Lots of friendly and competent people to work with
There are some interesting technical problems to solve (if you can get on one of those projects)
The benefits are good.
cons:
Poor/hostile relations between teams on separate sites
Too much reinventing the wheel - groups have no idea what tools, libraries, functionality have already been written in house
Long process for using OSS (GPL not allowed) in projects
Management does whatever it thinks best without asking employees
Management is trying to do more with less employees and work-life balance suffers
Management jerks teams around. They give you a project then transfer it away then assign another and then transfer it away.  That does wonders for morale.
Everything moves very slowly.  Adoption of new technology and methodology is years behind.

review_title: Slow innovator, complex and frustrating organization
pros: Large global company, exposure to world wide businesses, cultures. Visibility to broad industry trends. Loyal ERP customers.
cons: Organic innovation is very slow, unless it comes top-down from Hasso or the board. Executive board is largely organized functionally (vs. BU) tailored to board member's abilities, not suitable for a company this side. Great ideas from the bottoms-up almost impossible to realize, even those that get early traction in the market. Most new revenue is through M&A. Highly matrixed organization, especially GCO. General managers closer to the market have little influence on product direction and priorities. Development (except acquired businesses) mostly centralized or influenced from Germany and is often out of touch with the market. Many "me too" products that are late to market, many wasteful use of development resources not assigned to products.

review_title: It All Depends
job_title: Senior Account Executive in New York, NY
pros: Large product set that can be sold into many vertical markets.
cons: It All Depends....on who you are working for, what group and if you don't see your job change every year do the continuous reorganizations.  If you want the work/life balance most o us do that's fine....just be prepared to party with the key management folks weekly or you will be on the outside looking in due to the high level of office politics.  Products are very expensive and many often wonder it they are worth it.  Many companies have spent millions on SAP software; have they received the ROI/Benefits promised?  Perhaps some have but many have not.  Many other choices out there with similar functionality for a fraction if the cost.  SHOP AROUND!!!  And if your company somehow gets out of compliance with the terms of your agreement the SAP software compliance police will be out to get you every quarter/year.  And you don't want to have that discussion!

review_title: Opportunities within the bureaucracy
pros: There is a an aggressive sales focus. 2)There is a ton of resource put in to HR services and employee benefits 3)There are pockets within the organisation that operate like a start up
cons: SAP is still a vast bureaucracy.  It is incredibly difficult at times to get anything productive done after navigating an opaque matrix management structure and layers of compliance, legal, etc.  I wouldn't describe it as a place where loyal, entrepreneurial, hard working people thrive....best suited for the political manipulators.

review_title: Presales and SuccessFactors Consultant
pros: Great teamwork - colleagues are eager to share their vast knowledge, people are open for collaboration and are customer-focused. Exposure to the biggest IT projects in the industry and many opportunities to learn constantly. If you're not a fan of manager's career, you can grow as an expert in your field, and get competitive salary. Thanks to the big size of the company, you can and should network to get new career paths and opportunities without leaving SAP. Work-life balance in my role is really good.
cons: It might be a bit difficult to introduce and implement improvements or new projects - in some areas people tend to be too formal and bureaucratic. Some processes are a bit too sophisticated and can be further simplified. Crunches sometimes happen in sales or development teams. If your manager is not too good at leadership, you might struggle with career growth and learning opportunities.

review_title: God save SAP India Entity
pros:
* Insurance / PF/ Gratuity all good when it comes to employee well being
* Good brand to work, but outside India
cons:
* Highly Political Organisation in India. Run Simple is the word to be followed out side India, but not India.
* Motivation/Pep Talks from Senior Management is negative in India.
* Senior Management takes call on the basis of gut (Wimps and fancies) rather than ground reality facts in India.
* No work life balance. An employee is employed for 24/7 all 365 days a year. Which reduces the fact of learning and ownership of working for the organisation in India.
* Senior Management assigns the task as per their will without doing a home work as what is the capacity, and what is the propensity to achieve a target in India. 
* If an employee is good is rapport building with Senior Management, then she/he is safe, or else keep looking out.
* Highly unprofessional Senior Management specially in India, not too sure about other locations/regions.
* Because of Senior Management the culture and values which is being followed in other locations/ regions is negligible.

review_title: Be careful what role you take and how you will really be allowed to contribute.
job_title: Director, Solutions Management in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
1. Previously, because it was easy to develop yourself by moving to a new role within the company; that is currently severely restricted.  
2. They care about their employees... Let's see how they adhere to this in 2009.
3. The pay is generous given the low workload.
cons:
1. This place lives on Powerpoint to create vaporware and feel-good status reports.  They rarely spend time with customers, just management consultants and their own internal beliefs.  Status reports are always biased towards "green lights" as they move up the management chain.
2. Being in a staff role reporting into a group in Walldorf.  It is too easy to become detached and forgotten.  And all things "invented in Walldorf" are deemed better.

review_title: Good place to work
pros:
Diverse employee population
Some exceptionaly smart people
Autonomy, control over your own career path
4-day work week for consultants
Great benefits
Manager approves all vacation requests without question
cons:
Expectation of "giving back" to the company by helping to build a practice in your field, along with other administrative activities.  This is not a bad thing, however these activities are often on your own time outside of travelling to and working at your client sites.  Sometimes it can be difficult to maintain an appropriate work/life balance.

May or may not get a manager who cares about developing you as a consultant vs. just keeping you staffed.

Lately there are fewer long-term projects available.  If you don't stay billable, you are under scrutiny by management and risk losing your job if you cannot find work after a few months.  SAP has the highest consulting bill rates around, and it doesn't seem like we are adjusting to the changing economy.  Instead, consultants are increasingly expected to do more sales-related type of activities to push license revenue.

review_title: COE - great flexibility - awful salary
job_title: Senior Support Engineer in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
flexibility, (mostly) relaxed working environment, free lunch, zero discrimination 
Can grow quickly if you play your cards right.  Work from home. Great pension scheme
cons:
Terrible salary vs Irish market and even internally in global SAP environment. Places with lower cost of living paid more for exact same role(internal). 
New joiners on high salaries than people there 2 years. 
No consideration for cost of living in Ireland given to salary increases. 
Team managers try to help but are given terrible budgets for increases. 
Pension is great, but not when you're 25 and making around 60% of your peers you graduated with.

review_title: High rewards if you can handle high pressure
pros:
Benefits are great, everyone gets a laptop and mobile phone. Working from home is easy and generally acceptable across the business although it's not openly encouraged all the time.

Stock options and private Healthcare are top tier, pension and bonus is also very good.
cons:
Extremely high pressure. I always thought I could handle pressure until I worked here. If you're in a team that has anything to do with sales then you can expect to work 14+ hour days for the last month of the quarter.

If you're supporting sales then they treat you like dirt and speak down to you. It's a very sales focused company, if you don't get on board with the sales culture then you'll be left behind.

I saw 3-4 employees break down at their desks multiple times over the course of 12 months due to workload and pressure from senior staff.

review_title: It’s an enterprise software sales machine!
pros: This is one of the premier organizations when it comes to enterprise software sales execution. I joined SAP from a startup software product management and business development background specifically to learn and become GTM at scale, and become part of a team-based selling culture that executes deals at scale across all industries. There are many roles for one to learn and play. The culture work-life balance, and benefits are amazing.
cons: There is a lot of leadership changes going on constantly, which is both good and bad. Good if you’re in sales or product building since you can climb the ladder. Bad because it creates a lot of confusion on the teams doing actual work, and definitely makes it harder to be strategic.

review_title: Quality of work is declining...
pros: When I started early this decade, it still had the European impact and the employee benefits were very good. The SAP application platform still is still a very good product.
cons: As time went on, the American corporate greed really started showing its ugly face to the employees. While the financial growth of the company was in double digits every quarter and year to year, the employee benefits swiftly went down from good to neutral to poor. The C-Level bonuses went up and so is the incompetence and cronyism. Though the company preaches training, self improvement, family time etc for well rounded life, it is never practiced. Your training time will not be counted for productivity and so is your vacation. As an employee to get good bonus you almost have to kill yourself working. One of the biggest con is the bonus calculations. You are never told how your bonus was calculated.

review_title: Flexible work environment, but hard to get things done
pros: The nicest part about working at SAP is that you have flexibility to work anywhere, a lot of people work from their home office so most of our work is done over conference calls, emails and IM.    They also offer good benefits (free lunches at major offices, good HR benefits, etc).
cons: It's hard to get things done at SAP.  Dependancies on collaboration can get in the way.  I've worked on projects where you need over a dozen different approvals from different parts of the business to approve your project, and when one of the approvers ignores emails and misses meetings then wants to change things to benefit mainly his/her interest it is frustrating because everyone else suffers from the delay.  SAP is also very process oriented, even if it doesn't make sense or slows things down, case in point it can takes 2 weeks to open a PO and about 2 months for a vendor to get paid, and most teams  calculate their budgets in Excel.

review_title: RSE
job_title: Regional Sales Executive in Bellevue, WA
pros:
- Work-life balance... need a day away from the office? No problem.
- Earning potential (base could be a bit higher though)
- Tools available to succeed (software, territory partners, director, solutions consultant)
- End of month/quarter energy and excitement 
- Solution consultants are very helpful and knowledgeable 
- Plenty of coffee and drinks in the kitchen, lunch provided for most days during the last week of the quarter
- Directors want you to succeed and are willing to help out in any way
cons:
- At times the sales floor could be gossipy and felt like high school all over again
- The competition is cheaper and at this point probably as good of a product if not better
- Once SAP took over, key leaders left, some whom made a huge impact on the culture
- Territory can be good or very bad 
- Little or no diversity on the sales floor

review_title: Not a good place if you want to grow, but if your complacent its perfec
pros:
A good play to settle down
decent money and perks 
many people on easy street so if you want to slow down this place is for you
cons:
To complex, to much infighting and not enough people actually care about anything other than themselves
clearly 2nd class to certain regional employee base
No clear path to upward mobility unless you befriend someone who has headcount
Too many fiefdoms which just create layers and complexity and don't drive much of anything
HR can move you at any time under new management or new role.
Too many baby boomers who are insecure about losing job or territory. Will play political games and push younger team members down
Not a market leader as it thinks and customer lock- in is changing

review_title: Best company ever
pros:
+ Company really cares about its employees
+ Very focused on positive behaviors instead of purely KPIs
+ One of the best CEOs in the world
+ Very strong and solid strategy
+ Employees can clearly see a link between their jobs and the bigger picture
+ Company mission "make the world a better place" is not a Marketing Statement, people that work there really have that in mind
+ Company offers a huge amount of personal development opportunities: Social Sabbatical (SAP sends you for a month to do skills based volunteering in another country), Fellowship Program (you can apply to work 6 months in any organization in the world), Coaching and Leadership Programs, etc.
cons:
- Organizations are normally not as innovative as they could be
- Huge barriers because of branches in Germany (e.g.: German Work Council making dumb decisions that impact business in other countries, protectionism, old school, etc.)
- Company is still learning how to deal with change and embrace new acquisitions (e.g.: Business Objects, Sybase, Success Factors, etc.)

review_title: open, down-to-earth, great team work
pros: All in all, a very friendly athmosphere to work in, helpful co-workers, and close contact to direct managers. Good performance feedback and almost everybody is open for suggestions for improvement, is interested in personal well-being. People are eager to learn and often do voluntarily extra hours. But there is always time for a coffee and for a chat, social-networking is very welcome. Very good options to develop your carreer throughout different areas within SAP. Company car after 4 years, good company pension scheme and social security, health initiatives, free lunch, free coffee/tea/water, discounted shares... no time recording
cons: Unpaid extra hours, we really build bad UIs, extremely complex organizational structure and development structure - you need a year or two to get used to the bee hive of systems, transactions, roles, and responsibilities. Often too many management levels and unclear responsibilities.

review_title: Nice place to work compared to all others companies that i hear about
pros: Good work atmosphere, No entry-exit times, Good work-life balance, Everyone outside tells you that they also want to work at SAP some day.
cons:
Very Socialistic, after high performance for so many years I am paid almost equal to average performers, if you kill the incentive to perform well you automatically produce more non performers, why can't you HR and managers understand?
Every Salary cycle I am told, we will fix your salary in the next year.
They have some stupid compa ratio according to which I was paid low last year, Now i have moved to mid level pay according to my band and experience, even after a minimal hike. quite funny. Freshers from college and 3-5 years people salary have very less difference.
Some stupid bonus calculation resulted in everyone getting there bonus reduced to 83.4%, the co-CEO's had 40% hike last year they wouldn't have realized this cut.
low hikes given because the attrition is less

review_title: Good place to work but people take advantage
job_title: Software Engineer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Good executive management that cares about the employees. Management is transparent to its employees. There are a bunch of people in the company who want to take on challenges & want to make a difference in the industry. The CTO of the company is a good leader with qualities needed to make SAP competitive.
cons: Even though SAP has a great deal of positive energy, there are many people in the company who take advantage of it. Layers of mid-level management which do nothing but talk. I have seen many of them who have been here for years and do a lot of talking but deliver nothing useful to customers. CTO & leadership have a vision and SAP needs to cut all the layers of fat & create flat hierarchy of engineers to deliver the vision.

review_title: Account Executive @ SAP
pros: Great company in term of benefits, salary and bonus are quiete good. A lot of source of information so you can get what you need in order to success in your career path.
cons: Human Resourses department is inexistent. Once you passed the recruitment phase you are on your own. Management only focused in targets and not in people. Once a year after FKOM you don't know if you still have your position inside SAP so basically every year you need to move on in order to keep inside the company. This constant movement policy is not good as everything must restart every 12 months. This has its Price and is no cheap for the company. SAP also modify the region structure every 6 monts....3 regions, 4 regions, 5 regions, 3 regions again. Who is winning with this? Are they completely sure of what are they doing or they are just guessing?

review_title: Great Place to Work
pros:
As an employee I feel that we are very well taken care of.  The organization regularly updates the HR Programs and People Policies to build an employee friendly work environment. From free food, to free transport, to a creche within the campus, to extended maternity leaves, to a gym, yoga class, to a book club, to theater, music and dance interest groups, to a runners' club - we have it all. People are happy to come to work because they are allowed to indulge in their hobbies within the campus itself. 

The company also makes ample arrangements like the apphaus, the code marathons etc. to encourage people to think and come up with innovative ideas. 

The best thing about SAP, however, is it's commitment towards Diversity and Inclusion. In addition to very Inclusion friendly policies for women, early talents, mature talents, currently we have around 10 people worldwide who are on the Autism Spectrum.
cons: At times I feel that the management concentrates ONLY on the top performers and does very little for the average ones.

review_title: Review from new employee
pros: Offers great benefits that match most companies in Silicon Valley and lunch is free! Management supports newcomers very well and make them feel appreciated. Executive is very fun to listen to and some personalities are relatable, especially after reading Bill McDermott's book. Compensation is generally above average.  The company is very fast paced at least in the SV location so you get to learn a lot. Company parties are very well planned also.
cons: Not much stock options or opportunities for large bonuses for newcomers. The 401k plan could be better. Campus in SV is huge so hiking across buildings during hot days is rough, but they do offer a shuttle. Gym isn't that nice.

review_title: SAP UK Review
pros:
Great company over all. A lot of employee support and resources to encourage growth. Policies are all in place to help roles, flexibility to manage a good work/life balance. Freedom to manage own work loads and accommodate team activities during working hours is great. 

Equipment and resources are reliable to help you get your job done. 
Free lunch also :-)
cons:
On a company level is is great but on a more direct management level it will depend on the personality of the seniors. The environment is very corporate and not aligned with the a new and developing software companies. 

Direct management is very poor to support employees. The resources are all in place but no personal empathy from management to build relationships. 

The sales team are the privileged few who get all the credit, although they contribute very little to the bigger picture.

review_title: Flexibility, integrity, and honesty
pros:
SAP has enabled me to have the flexibility to get my job done with a flexible schedule in terms of both location and timing.  In other words, I get my job done working where I need to and when I need to.  

As well, SAP demonstrated a lot of integrity by allowing me to move to a new position when I encountered health issues that required a less stressful environment.

Finally, I appreciate that I can be honest about my work requirements and that SAP has been honest with me about what options are available.
cons: SAP is a premier employer and  making great strides to attract the best and the brightest.  This in turn fosters an extremely competitive environment which can be conducive to burn out.

review_title: Great Company, messed up what they did to Jen Morgan
pros:
Great benefits and work life balance. I love the focus on diversity and inclusion in the company. Truly felt like a global company, until the board ousted Jen Morgan.
The stock program, OwnSAP, is a great value for employees. You can contribute up to 10% of each paycheck to the program and SAP will match 40% of what you contribute (up to some ceiling). The stock immediately vests, so if even you don't want to invest in SAP you can immediately sell it and essentially increase your salary by 4% for free.
cons: Booted Jen Morgan in favor of a German CEO. Feels hypocritical to tout diversity and inclusion as a key value in SAP, then find an excuse to push out one of the most qualified businesswoman in the world. If the board didn't want co-CEOs, then why did they agree to it in the first place? Massive loss to SAP.

review_title: Lots of opportunities for growth and frustration
pros: Conservative, intelligent, responsible, and straight-talking senior management at HQ in Germany; many options for career movement in technical and non-technical roles; not a lot of dead wood - engineers are smart.
cons: Lots of red tape trying to do simple things like ordering a docking station for a laptop - can take MONTHS! Some real jerks in middle management from acquisitions. User interfaces of SAP software are unbelievably bad - can't take much pride in them and there's lots of frustration when using the stuff yourself. Underlying architecture stable but arcane - you will likely find yourself porting your 21st century code to something akin to Windows 3.1 after encountering the laughable attitude that "if you follow good engineering hygiene you should have no problem adhering to the requirements."

review_title: Saturated growth in India.  Chance of growth only if you are great with managers or friends with them.
pros:
Great in terms of work life balance
22 + number of years in company = total annual leave, sick leave, examination leave
work from home(though it is difficult to get approved)
Good benefits for women (Maternity leave, individual trasnport during pregnancy, extended maternity)
Relatively transperant communication except in some departments
cons:
Chances of growth are rare
Learnibility very limited unless you can have access to information people at higher level, One keeps on working on same thing for years.
Salaries scarce.
Benfits going down day ( tranportation is now paid, was free earlier).
No travel opportunities.
Performance review ratings are often predecided betweeb managers in a department even before review of employees start.
All in all a great compnay if you are on management level, excellent benefits. but if you are at a junior level chanvces of growth are minimum.

review_title: Good workplace overall - May have a turmoil ahead?
job_title: Project Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
- Has solid policies & processes in place.  
- Work/Live balance has improved in the last few months.  
- A performing product (HANA) run by a company with strong user-base.  
- Great benefits and salary.  
- Employees are mostly friendly and collaborative.
cons:
- Recent mass layoff let go of many high-performing employees based simply on geographic location, leaving many not-so good performing employees in HQs.  
- Career path is not often times not clearly defined; promotions are often tied to political positioning of the individual
- Every year first 4 to 6 months are in chaos while management take time to decide what employees supposed to achieve in the remaining 6 months of the year.
- Often processes are too "German" and too process-oriented

review_title: Inside Sales
pros: Pre acquisition the company was awesome. Lars was an inspirational leader and made some great kool aid! Compensation was great, culture was the best I've ever experienced and there was no negativity in the workplace.
cons:
Then SAP bought SF.... The fun and exciting culture was slowly replaced by management that didn't give .02 cents to what employees think and the sales teams were incentivized to fight each other for a sale. The compensation was lowered to the point where I couldn't afford to work there anymore and who would want to anyway because there was no training or incentives to excel. The managers who were promoted because they were good at sales had no management experience and had no idea how to lead or manage teams. I couldn't find the exit door fast enough! 
But this is what happens when a giant company buys the market leader and tries to cut operating costs and fit it under the umbrella of the parent. There might be as many as 5 people left from pre acquisition, but probably less...

review_title: Big Growth Opportunity
pros: I was referred to SAP by a former colleague. The company was on my radar but I never had a good understanding of their business. I learned more through the recruiting process and was blown away to hear about their impact on the world's business community. They power so many companies across the globe! What really hooked me in and got me interested in working at the company was their employee value proposition tagline of "Bring Everything You Are, Become Everything You Want." That assured me that SAP could be a place where I could innovate within my specialty and grow my career. I've been with the company for almost nine months and I can honestly say it's an awesome place to work and grow. Superior benefits, great programs and workshops, honest and inspiring coworkers... coolest place I've worked in my career!
cons: There's always more room for collaboration between teams so as to avoid duplicative work.

review_title: A company that really cares about you and invests in your future!
job_title: Global Program Manager in Denver, CO
pros: I have so many positive things to say about SAP.  Although the company is large, there are abundant resources and people to connect with to further your career.  I have spent time at a small startup and SAP often has that small-company energetic, change-the-world vibe and I know that is rare or nonexistent in large companies elsewhere. The Executive Leadership is trustworthy and transparent.  Motivation to do your best work abounds, I really enjoy working here.
cons: Sometimes certain elements of vision can get clouded through the vastness of a 100K employee company, but you truly can seek out lots of information about where SAP is headed internally and educate yourself.  There are also normal pains of navigating a large organization to find the right resources, but SAP is committed to "Run Simple" and we're making improvements.

review_title: Don't expect much, they are all the same.
pros: Free lunch in the cantine. Well with those salaries we really need it...
cons:
I have yet to see a company which doesn't take advantage of the "recession". Our manager at SAP would like us to work overtime without getting paid - well i guess all managers would like it, but this one is not ashamed to say it in the team meeting. Although the company is one of the Europe' richest. Now they don't even pretend having dignity anymore.

I estimate around 2/3 SAP workforce are contractors ("C-users"), with very limited rights, severely underpaid  and constantly under pressure, for fear the contract will not be extended. So come on, don't tell me its a "great company". 

If the capitalists are let go, they squeeze the workforce as they used to do in the 19th century. Since 1989 they don't have to pretend they care for social values, they lost any constraints since communism is not a threat anymore.

review_title: The classic risk reward scenario. Can be one of most lucrative sales jobs in the world.
pros: Great brand recognition. Big income possibilities if you exceed your quota. You will be surrounded by "A players" that are incented to help you sell. Broad array of software solutions in your bag. Market leading position. In the large company market, there is only one real competitor (Oracle). Integration and industry focused solutions with built-in best practices are great selling features.
cons: Management pressure every quarter. Account shuffling every year sometimes means you lose accounts you have invested months to cultivate. You get a new Sales VP just about every year. License pricing from SAP Germany is confusing. No real SaaS solutions available to sell. Tough economy to sell big ERP.

review_title: Consultant - Not a bad place
pros:
I loved working for SAP NA as a consultant for the following reasons:
-You truly own your own career, and can take advantages of all opportunities
-Flexibility to learn new skillsets as the market demands
-Exciting and fast paced environment, you will never get bored
-Some of the smartest people in the industry work here
cons:
Lots of uncertainly as far as the direction of consulting. With the new cloud/simplification process comes change, which is not communicated well.  
Here are the disadvantages to SAP:
-Lots of layers of management - hard to get new ideas up the chain
-Constant reorgs hurts morale and causes uncertainty
-Worried(especially as of late) of job security - losing great employees to more secure firms
-The vision changes every six months or so it seems
-Your experience depends highly on the manager that you are assigned. Luckily I had a great one, but others are not so fortunate

review_title: Great place to grow
pros: Excellent place to grow and innovate.  They were the Google, FB, and Amazon, in terms of innovation before those big 3 became what they are today, in my opinion.  Free thought and the ability to come up with ideas and see them executed was the name of the game at SAP.  As far as my experience went, I learned a lot, even after having been at other big SaaS companies. Hard but fair work, challenging but rewarding.
cons: I heard from some entry level people and others that it was easy to get lost in the shuffle.  That was a shame that it happened, and I tried to give my teams I managed a true voice and let everyone's opinion be heard.  Sometimes it wasn't always easy in such a large fast paced company, but the frustrations were there sometimes.

review_title: SAP is too complicated with the false promises given to the customers as well as employees
pros:
Pros aren't really pros after a while ,lots of promises given at the start 
SAP's marketing is good ,internal as well as external but that's about it
cons:
Management doesn't take employees advice on how to improve internal processes which are too complicated
Product support can't put up with the volume of incidents raised by the customers
There is not enough transparency about the products and support during the sales process which  causing disappointment and customers frustration after the implementation cycle
Salary lower from other premium players in software industry
Management too ignorant  to develop employees and to support their progression
Training of employees is week and very high level 
Customers frustrated with complexity and inability of SAP to keep its word given at the point of sale
Canteen food is just below the average standard

review_title: Make sure you have a thick skin
pros: Great brand, Free food, Good people
cons: A very political, brutal environment where people are here one day, gone the next.  The churn is simply incredible. Management team solely focused on this quarters number with no interest in you as an individual or helping you achieve success. There is a real 'us and them' environment and if you are one of them you can be assured of great accounts, good earnings and getting what you want, regardless of how it affects others. If you are one of the majority 'us' you can expect unreasonable pressure, poor accounts and receiving little, if any, support. Too many managers focused on their own careers rather than the people who work for them.

review_title: Dream place to work
cons: Not any , if I can think out, maybe the salary is not very competitive (I was hesitating on the offer, and I know some people gave up and chose other higher salaries).

review_title: Employee-friendly, integrity, good work-life balance, but hard to get things done
pros: SAP treats its employees well - in pay, benefits, respect for individuals, does not apply too much unwanted stress, flexible, work-life balance, friendly and helpful colleagues, integrity is highly valued. 'Terrorist' managers not tolerated for long. Strong emphasis on 'happy employees' unlike most American companies. Influenced by European attitudes to work-life balance.
cons: Somewhat bureaucratic and consensus-driven, all decisions need to be approved by the top, essentially paralyzing empowered decision making. Very hard to get something done. Complex matrix structures give no ownership for anything. Highly conservative and very slow to react to market changes and emerging trends. Lots of internal competition. Too many people doing overlapping/ same things create conflicts. Very little autonomy.

review_title: The NEW SAP is great, the OLD SAP is painful
job_title: Product Management in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Very loyal, very large global customer base.  Usually one of a few strategic vendors that the largest companies in the world rely on.

Flexible work environment.  Nice people (no screamers).  SAP genuinely cares about its employees and wants them to like the company.

Company is changing - very different from 5 years ago.  New businesses are moving fast and highly competitive.
cons:
Org structures can be very convoluted and very global.  There is some emphasis on co-location but easy to have people from Germany, India, US all on the same team.  Try getting them on a con call.

Very much a technology focused go-to-market structure in a business where solutions matter more to customers.

German HQ is very detached from realities of Silicon Valley.  Structural influence of the German Works Council is corrosive - limits mgmt from reacting to market trends.

review_title: Would be great if they used their own tools...
job_title: Anonymous Employee in South San Francisco, CA
pros:
Great people from all over the world
Opportunity to transition to the bigger Cloud players (reason for a positive rating on career opps).
cons:
Poor Management..."No Jerks" policy does not mean that it's upheld. 
Here's company that preaches a great sermon but doesn't follow their own message. Their full Talent Management pitch is around employee engagement and motivating their workforce...unfortunately, managers don't use the performance and goal tools. Sales model is dependent on has extremely poor lead generation and marketing. 

Think "Game of Thrones" and HR = Little Finger (watch out).

review_title: CoE Support Engineer
pros:
- Free lunches
- Fuel Card 
- Travel opportunities 
- Onsite bonus 
- Performance Incentives 
- Good progression if you perform well
cons:
- Germany control everything, Ireland does not have any control and are left with the scraps of work
- Less work life balance. Too much travel requirements and late shift requirements 
- No real management control in certain teams 
- Too much focus on costs rather than employees 
- Setting of non-realistic goals which has impacts of employees reviews 
- Not enough work and too many employees (Growth??)

review_title: SAP allows you to grow without having to change organizations
pros: I have plenty of flexibility in my work hours. Since I work on a truly global team there is no need to be at the office although the office is wonderful and most SAP locations have special access suites for lawyer office which means no fighting for meeting rooms. There are several programs that allow you to expand your experience- The fellowship program and the experience exchange program. One allows you jump into another job role entirely for 6 mos or more and sometimes in international locations. The latter program is a shorter job shadowing or project secondments in other departments which also comes with a travel budget. Employee engagement is valued and worked on. Every location in SAP worldwide has free lunches and some places free breakfast.
cons: Pay is never the highest. The pace of change can be slow for those that want to come and change things quickly but this deliberation also helps with stability.

review_title: acquired in, product ground to a halt, got out before atrophy set in
pros: Pretty good compensation, usually hit bonus target, subsidized lunches, nice campus. If you like job security and not a lot of stress, you can be a lifer here.
cons: Glacial development cycles driven by Walldorf (German HQ) mean that it's difficult to make any sort of impact. SAP does not understand how to really manage innovation and how to do things quickly. Also, there is lots of dead wood here - the people that actually make things happen either become executives (in a few cases) or leave to go somewhere where it's easier to actually do something (most cases).

review_title: Fast Paced & Challenging place to work
job_title: Vice President of Business Development in Austin, TX
pros: I've been with the company for the last 4 years and have found it to be both engaging and challenging.  My roles have provided me with the opportunity to stretch my abilities and continuously learn new things.  I've enjoyed my time at SAP.  The company offers plenty of opportunities for advancement as well.
cons: Lots of change.  If you aren't adept to change then SAP may not be the place for you.  We make changes to things regularly and sometimes they can be complex.  They are usually for the good and to keep ahead of our competition but you need to be flexible and not challenged with making changes.

review_title: Transformation
pros: employee centric, work-life balance, freedom, collaboration, free lunch, global bonus pool program, company brand name, smart people, global presence
cons: politics, cross board area alignment is off, communication is weak, no transparency, too much game playing and empire building, many lifers whose skills are not relevant, young talents are not trained properly, inexperienced management, lack Silicon Valley culture (agile, can-do, win/win mindset, entrepreneurship, passion, set people up for success), frequent re-orgs cause low morale

review_title: Good company as a whole but do not join the SMN Marketing Team
pros: SAP Concur as a whole is a good company with tons of opportunity. Unfortunately, areas of the business are very flawed, specifically the SMN Marketing Team.
cons: SMN Marketing has struggled with poor leadership and high turnover for years, and unfortunately the trend is still going strong. The leadership lacks basic marketing principles and will challenge your morals and lie to achieve the results they want. More than two dozen employees have come and gone from that team in a matter of a few years and you will be next if you decide to join the ranks.

review_title: Working with Awesome!!
job_title: Senior Sales Executive in Maidenhead, England
pros: A community of like-minded talented people who bring their best-selves to work everyday with a daily mission to be better than we were yesterday. Always being made to feel valued, heard and part of something exciting! I'm definitely a lifer!
cons:
It's hard to think of any - the fact that I've gained a few stone since starting probably is the main one; lot's of socialising, lunch and learns and cakes generally being floated about has had a detrimental impact on my waistline!
In all seriousness we work very hard, but play harder - working for SAP isn't a role you should enter into if you aren't an all or nothing person. It's not easy but it's worth it!!!

review_title: Nice benefits & pay- great career starter, but impeded by egos
job_title: Marketing Associate in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Supportive and casual work environment, at least in my location. Flexible hours and left to mostly self-manage (though I'm sure this depends on your team), which really gave me the freedom and peace of mind to work out my own rhythm and flow for better quality output.
cons: Our team, and therefore jobs, were constantly changing due to overhauls in higher-up management and their ideas of improvement, which were executed without too much thorough research into the existing work we were doing. It often felt like we had to start over with initiatives and ideas we already had in the works, only to never convince decision makers that they were truly worthwhile. Sort of led us to feel behind, compared to the rest of the specific industry we were working in.

review_title: Respect is a major concern
pros: -Work/Life Balance and special events
cons:
-(From Sybase to SAP) SAP dropped the ball on the Waterloo location.
-The entitlement and passive aggressive mentality amongst employees is concerning. 
-Facility procedures that are put in place for employees to follow are very rarely followed which shows very little respect for the facilities team which in turn makes their job difficult to perform.
-The facilities team is known as the "bottom of the totem pole" even though they keep the building the employees work in up and running.
-For a site of almost 300 employees there is no proper on site HR support which is very concerning. 
-With all the above being said, the environment can be very toxic and hostile.

review_title: SAP is being part of something big, a family to me.
pros:
Diversity, inclusion, and respect for others.
The culture of sharing ideas.
The drive to make the company's strategy a reality for our customers.
Make our customers run simple is not just a slogan, it is carved in our working spirit , it is part of our company DNA, because we care !
cons: There are times when great ideas are being patented but at the end of the day are not being reduced into practice (implemented), maybe due to lack of resources and/or difference in the R&D priority, and/or maybe due to over focusing.

review_title: Politically unstable, rudderless, and drowned in bureaucracy.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Philadelphia, PA
pros: A surprisingly large number of very intelligent engineers, some very interesting technologies, and a fair amount of freedom and flexibility. Palo Alto campus is very pleasant, with open spaces, decent cafeterias, a nice little garden... there is a fitness center, but it's a bit inadequate.
cons:
Restructuring is a biannual event, or worse. Political coups and hijacking of projects are common occurrences. Products are created by engineering, then sold as something else by a perpetually disconnected sales and marketing army, and suddenly a solidly engineered technology needs to be hacked into whatever it got positioned as for customers.

HR in the US has been completely outsourced to offshore call centers, and things like compensation for paid leave, reimbursement for expenses, and help with problems with the health insurance provider can take months to resolve.

review_title: Best Company to work for!
pros: If you are interessted and motivated everything is possible.  I started at SAP three years ago and just recently changed job internally. SAP definitely supports their employees to develop to the next level and the benefits the company offers are quite unique. Since I started working for SAP I sure had a bad day or two (especially monday mornings) however I did not once regret that I decided to work for SAP. Just a week ago I returned from my holidays and I was so happy and enthusiastic to see my collegues again. This was the moment I realised how fortunate I am.
cons: Well nothing is 100% perfect however i dont know much i could complain about. SAP is a very big company and therefore it is natural that things move a bit slower than in small and lean start-ups.

review_title: One of the best companies to work for.
pros: If you are hard working than the benefits and salary will come. For me everything was more than enough, but everybody needs to take into consideration that the amount of knowledge, work and added value you bring to the company will also increase your salary ad benefits. That being said don't stand around and complain if you are not putting in the work and having a little bit of patience. SAP is a great company from which each individual can evolve professionally, have a great work life balance and meet great people.
cons: Like in every company there are naysayers and people who complain about certain things, which brings an air of negativity in the work place. Maybe some internal reviews and and problem resolution seminars would help.

review_title: Get rid of "networkers" and "politicians"
pros: Quite good work-life balance, benefits are good.
cons:
Way too much politics.
Knowledge and expertise alone do not matter if you don't have good connections. Often low quality software is produced at cheap locations, and this is sold to the higher management as "efficiency". Skilled people leave the company once they realise there is no way to add anything of value. Everybody else seems to stay here forever.

review_title: SAP BSCE - great place to be!
pros:
The company SAP BSCE is a good employer. The company is more than only fair to the employees, providing several benefits, including also home office work, paid days off for several reasons. There is lot of training opportunities and several ways where to move your carreer.

It is a very fair place to women who have children, giving flexible working time to mothers, part time work as well in case it is possible in the particular team/department. 
For a woman who just returned from maternity leave it is possible to apply for next level position like e.g. manager position and be chosen among several other candidates! The family is not a handicap here.

Great team spirit. There is an environment where colleagues are supporting and motivating each other. It is just nice to work with intelligent and friendly people. 

Multicultural environment where people from different culutural background work together to reach the common goal.
cons: There are not many Cons I could mention.

review_title: Working Student
job_title: Work Study Student in Walldorf, Baden-Wurttemberg
pros:
1. A working student can familiarize her/himself with the range of SAP products (HANA, BI, BO etc) . One can download some of this softwares internally on company's laptop and play around with them. I have not explore the opportunity to get certified on these specific software but there should be some
2. Interaction with superiors is very flat, quite unusual for Germany work environment. You can approach colleagues at any time and unless they are very busy usually they will stop and listen to you
3. Company provides plenty campus facilities that you can use ex gym, table pool, relaxation room etc
4. As a working student you benefit free abundant lunches and water/coffee/tea
cons: The headquarters is quite huge employing currently 12K people and there are many departments located. When applying you may end up in a department doing something that you really do not project yourself doing in the future. When you apply choose carefully which positions you apply for. Do no choose based on requirements, choose based on what are departments/team objectives

review_title: Best place to work
pros:
Employees feel empowered and have the complete freedom & control over the work they do. 
Trust built by the management is immense, there is always the assurance that your manager will be there to rescue you. 
Very less politics.
Flat hierarchy and friendly colleagues.
Yearly team outbounds to the best resorts in the south.
Open learning resources.
Company car lease & AC shuttles.
No problem for leaves and work from home options .
SAP shares & RSUs
cons:
On the job learning is more vertical. You get to know a product deep and master it, so involving in different products is almost impossible.

There is this peculiar first year syndrome seen in lateral hires. They hear so much about the work-life balance and the culture in SAP, a few lateral hires tend to go easy and not push themselves in the first year. Looks like management is also not much concerned about it.

review_title: Beware the long term VP
pros: The hype sounds great. If it were only true for all employees. Read between the lines.
cons: There are a some in management who have been there forever and some who just shouldn’t be there anymore.  In particular the ones who get by while treating people terribly, and gleefully climbing over the top of them at any cost.  All under the guise of being so nice. In reality just very very weak people who should go.  No value added management. Very threatened by and takes credit for the success of those doing the work.  Some sent to foreign posts - But still there nonetheless. Just stay away. Some people can’t be trusted and are outright slimy.

review_title: Best Place To Work For
pros:
SAP Labs is certainly the best choice if you get an offer.

Here goes the list that SAP gives its employees.

Lucrative salary with huge joining bonus
Flavor of a product company
Great Place to Work across the globe
Lots of learning opportunities
Opportunity to work on different current technologies
Higher study opportunities
Opportunity to attend big events and conferences
Huge growth in professional career
Rewards and Recognition
Referral bonus and appraisals
Excellent Leave Policy
No time logging
Flexible work from home policies
Perfect work-life balance
All Round Development in Sports, Music, Painting, Photography and more
Great Infrastructure
Cool peers and managers
Exposure to B2B scenarios
Free laptops worth Rs.100000
Free 4G internet connection
Free Lunch and Dinner of all cuisines
Frequent team lunch and dinners at big places
Free Snacks
Free transport
Free Business Trips
Free movies with team
Free Fruits and Health Drinks
Free full body check-up for you and your family
Health Insurance and Accidental Insurance worth Rs.1200000
Birthday and Anniversary Gifts
Goodies on Men’s/Women’s Day, Diwali, Christmas and more
Amazing celebrations on Annual Day, Family Day and more
…
…
Your happy face
cons: I haven't found any cons till date after working for 3 years.

review_title: One of the best choices for Bulgaria
pros: Excellent working environment. Company cares about almost everything which can make employess feel comfortable e.g. ergonomic workplaces, different types of meeting rooms, different choice of food and beverages. Feedback is constantly requested and improvements are actually made. There are a lot of different teams and a variety of projects and technologies to choose from. The company invests in its people in different aspects - support for carreer development, education even help for solving personal issues. In comparison with other workplaces in Bulgaria SAP is really an excellent choice.
cons: There is no effective control for the lowest management level. Sometimes hired team leads do not understand neither software development nor people management but just have hunger for a management career. The company has very low internal control for identifying such toxic bosses supported by microteam of submerges. So as many other large companies you can get in the situation to love your company and job and things you do, but be forced to go away from your toxic boss.

review_title: Great company and strong product/solutions, good culture and good work life balance.
pros: Very good company, caring and with strong values and culture that made its reputation. Loved the solutions/products and the work life balance. Benefits were quite nice too.
cons: My experience was with a very immature and poor management, very old style in authority and micro management ! Not knowing how to manage senior people of 20+ years of experience.... I had a very bad experience that ruined my view of the beautiful company that SAP is....to a point where I was sick with stomach ache in the morning - turned out to be over quickly for the best !! I find it sad when something like this happens, when you just feel clicking and connected to a company culture & values and this gets ruined by the wrong casting in management.  After all, we all know the say "you don't chose your company, you choose your boss" !!

review_title: One of the best employers - if you are able to go for an unconventional career
pros:
Open culture; Leadership team is focussed on issues to be fixed not on politics - SAP is, compared to other employers, a company with relatively low levels of politics
Global Opportunities are open on all levels - leadership team is committed to run the company with a global team, not as a kind of centralized hub& spoke system
Executive Board consists of five nationalities, 
Different career paths possible - technical & management
cons:
Compensation for Garduates too low
Employer branding at campus very low
No good opportunities for MBA, its an engineering company
SOme departments are really still too 'German" in their thinking and approach, though it got better ove rthe last years
Innovation cycles are too long - from idea to productizaton; 
Diversity: Asia is often a bit neglected when it comes to participation in global or regional top management

review_title: Hard career progress and low salaries
job_title: Associate Consultant in Lisbon, Lisbon District

review_title: "Great place to work"
pros:
* I appreciate the process. Many rounds of testing and that makes sure that we deliver quality software to customers.
* 80% + employees are clear with SAP strategy 2020 and working towards it.
* Now moving onto cloud, bigdata, machine learning and others. Surely we can see the future.
* Kind of work depends on team. If you work for a team that delivers on cloud you will find great work.
* Work from home is available
* Great for women employees
* No problem for leaves
* Team outings/team lunches regularly
* recreational space in every coffee corner
* Fruits, hydrated water coffee day coffee, chai point tea etc etc
cons:
* slow learning curve
* Not so good for scholars/interns. I have worked with couple of scholars, they are great at what they do  but still they do not get converted because of CGPA and other stuff.
* Management of resources. They let go of great talent like scholars, interns and freshers who do not get proper work.

review_title: A great place that I am proud of saying I work at
job_title: Solutions Director in New York, NY
pros: SAP takes both it customers and its community commitments seriously. We are driving a technology culture that believes in innovation with purpose - extending the existing culture of defining our success in terms of our customers and creating a better life and way of doing things by simplifying process, We really believe in it, which is pretty motivating. I also see such a strong commitment to the community - broadly through our Next Gen center, adoption of UN principles, and locally through involvements here. There is also lots of encouragement and opportunity for training and expanding skills or learning new ones.
cons: License and services can be brought even closer, which makes getting holistic discussions going more easy.  You need to be proactive to really be successful because responsibility does come with empowerment

review_title: Great place to work, but not the only one
job_title: Customer Success Manager in Bogotá, Bogota
pros: Great people, open environment and a good climate to work
cons: Even when is a good climate to work, at the same time the environment could be very hostile, some people is not so collaborative as they should and depending if hr partners likes you or not , your career advance could be dramatically boosted or terrifically slow. Wages are below the industry average

review_title: Poor Meritocracy
job_title: Product Support Engineer in São Leopoldo, Rio Grande do Sul
pros: Work life balance, no management pressure, stability, openness for feedback
cons: Meritocracy, no management pressure on the ones that don't do anything in their work duties...too much stability for the ones that don't deserve it

review_title: In the past, the work and compensation were great, now the work is still good but compensation is average.
pros:
Infinite opportunities to learn and grow (self-driven)
Work with huge variety of fantastic companies
Great to work with latest SAP products (all documentation, training courses, and customer messages available to employees)
Talented co-workers
cons:
Compensation on declining trend for many years (necessary to work harder and harder to achieve status quo or slightly less)
Main management motivator is to work longer/harder (while giving lip-service to work/life balance).
Limited promotion opportunities for technical/architecture specialists (once at Platinum/Principal level - if not interested in pure management/overhead roles).

review_title: Working "9 to 5" is not an option.
pros: Above average pay and bonus, very nice facility in suburban Philly.  Free company subsidized lunch every day for permanent employees.
cons: Highly stressful and over worked environment.  50 hour weeks are the norm, sometimes more. Constant reorgs with shuffling of leadership and employee layoffs, and little or no job security. Company tends to heavily rely on contractors - 30% of workforce are contractors who get no benefits and are the first to go when expenses get tight.

review_title: Services Sales Manager
job_title: Senior Sales Manager in Kuala Lumpur
pros:
Great technology, extremely talented and smart people working together. Good renumeration and good leadership from Bill and the top leadership. The people working with me are smart and always work to their best.

The benefits especially car allowance is great. Parking is given and team initiatives are plenty. 

You need to stay near the decision makers meaning that you need to make yourself visible to the management in Singapore so spend some time in Singapore. Build your internal network and find your godfather/mother.
cons:
Not a good place for services. Services management does not know what to do with Go to market, In my country, we made money through audit which makes customer engagement difficult.

Most of the people work in silos, common metrics are non existent so you need to depend on veterans to make certain things happen. 

Very high pressure for sales team. Sales meeting is performed with little trust given. Micro management is rampant and customer emphathy is almost non existence.

review_title: SAP is just ok
job_title: Product Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- Work/Life balance is great, SAP is very understanding about family commitments and very supportive of each other 
- You often have the opportunity to work on significant projects
- There is a performance based pay type of culture so if you are good in your job you can get paid, depending on Department
cons:
- SAP does not pay competitively
- SAP does not do a good job of adjusting pay across countries or states. 
- Often your sphere of influence on a given "important project" is limited by managers inserting themselves who are not necessarily understanding all the complexities of the project but are making decisions anyway based on some political factor
- Not all teams do the performance appraisals correctly so you can get places in a team that does not do performance appraisals properly and then it doesn't matter how good your work is

review_title: Great place to work! Could be more tech friendly...
job_title: Support Engineer CoE in Newtown Square, PA
pros: The people are really nice, and I think the company overall does a very good job of making you get used to their workplace environment. It's a great place to work at.
cons: The structure of work at Newtown Square branch is very business like, and someone from a technical background it's really weird to get used to. They still use Windows even though most of their work can be done much easier and faster on a Mac. Some people do have Mac's, I'm yet to figure out how to get one for work.

review_title: The most high impact company you'll ever work for
pros:
-> Your work has a lot of meaning. You're not selling ads to people. You can interact with clients in real time and get feedback and requirements that GENUINELY makes an impact on their lives and businesses.

-> The challenges are unique. Unlike single product/B2C companies like Facebook or Google, you face a diverse set of challenges in a B2B setting. SAP houses teams that deal with healthcare scenarios, banking scenarios, manufacturing scenarios and so much more. The challenges at B2C companies are mostly purely technical/architectural (e.g. Spark or Hadoop for Big Data processing, ML for recommendation, etc.). At SAP, your challenges are more software *application* oriented. For instance, what data does a doctor need to know when a new patient requests and appointment? Should manufacturing time series data be shown as a line chart, or just a histogram of outliers?
cons: -> Salary is far below competitors in the same domain (e.g. Microsoft)

review_title: Pretty Office.  Ugly People.
pros:
Casual and for the most part informal culture 
There was an OK work/life balance
Snacks/games/distractions available
Weekly happy hours
Young and vibrant co-workers
Time off is generous both vacation as well as maternity/paternity (SAP benefit)
cons:
Criteria for worker evaluation is not clearly defined.  
Transparency from management level is almost non-existent
Not a great place for minorities (especially at the Management level).  This does not apply to SAP as a whole who has  a great track record for diversity.  
Favoritism and "it's who you know" system definitely rules the office. (you will have to actively seek out opportunities in order to "shine".  
By signing up you automatically start your "brand" which will follow you throughout your time here (will hamper opportunities if it's not considered excellent).   
People are asked to do a ton with the most minimal of resources (time, staff, etc.)

review_title: Market Development Representative
pros: Good culture, Possible advancement, Fun coworkers
cons: Tons of turnover, Inexperienced Management, They tell 40+ employees that they can all advance after 1 year while also hiring externally

review_title: Hierarchal nightmare
pros:
- good training programs
- excellent benefits
- opportunity to make a lot of money
- excellent retirement plan
- lots of resources to support your efforts
cons:
- a disfunctional, extremely hierarchal environment
- many levels of management who are getting paid to perform administrative tasks and adding no value to improving customer experience or improving SAP sales
- management has no desire to listen to the highly experienced employees they are willing to hire; dictates come down from above....often with no regard for the reality on the street and reality of SAP's own organization and limitations.
- I believe SAP is far down its lifecycle curve; it will collapse from its own weight and inabiity to be agile enough in an enviroment that demands flexibility and insight.   Best days are behind SAP

review_title: SAP  - a great workplace
pros:
The company has a good vision and very dynamic. The teams are really focussed and there is ample visibility of your work.
SAP is a place where employees help decide policies that directly impact them. Obviously there is a limit to what you can do, but having a sounding board itself is a great thing in such a big company. 
As an egineer, you would want :
1. good work -  working on the SAP database product is challenging and it really gives enough opprtunities for you to use your creativity and technical intellect. 
2.  good pay - SAP rewards its employees with various stock related benefits, along with bonusses and a reasonably competitive pay. 
3.  Culture and value system -  From time to time there aretranings, programs, extra curicular activities planned, which gives you opportunites to explore yourself beyond work. 

I find SAP a great work place.
cons: I do not see any real cons.

review_title: Constant change, not necessarily for the better
pros:
Ability to work virtual from anywhere in the world
A stable, long-term career if you want it
Lots of smart people to learn from
Looks nice on your resume (which I've heard numerous times since working here...like this should compensate for everything else...)
cons:
Not a lot of opportunity for career growth - you can stay where you are for 20 years if you want
Top-down mandate for strategy - often with no actual insight into the problems they are trying to solve
Lots of strategic changes being made without a real vision of what the changes are attempting to accomplish
Quite high turnover in product management 
Low pay for equivalent position in other companies in the Silicon Valley market
Flex hours can mean working 12-18+ hours per day during busy times

review_title: "Mean girls" sales management
pros: SAP field sales reps can make significant money.    I've known several reps who made $2m in one year.
cons:
SAP Sales Management promotes a "mean girl" culture.  If you're in the clique, you get assigned wonderful opportunities and can make significant money.  If you're not in the clique, you get to create new opportunities on your own, but it's best to hide them from the head of sales of your group/.  The head of the clique can not wait to reassign that opportunity and income to one of her followers.
If you're talent is to be 90% inwardly focused on internal politics and currying favor from internal power brokers, this is an ideal environment.
If you're 90% customer focused, watch your back.

review_title: Good Place for Software Developers
pros:
SAP is a save harbor, pays very well and offers interesting software development projects.
SAP has been growing from an old-school MS/Windows-focused company to an agile, open company not only offering jobs for all kinds of software-development experts, but also for computer science graduates.
cons:
Many departments are under constant reorganization, which may demotivate (younger) employees. Sometimes company politics will just not make sense to a regular developer.
The workload can be very high sometimes and the career opportunities for "regular" workers with a family at home (40h/week) and part-time workers (parental leave) may be very restricted.

review_title: Sybase buisness
pros: Gym and classes, subsidized food, Big company benefits. Possibility to grow if you are transferring from Germany.
cons: Low performance requirements. Even though there is training available, not a lot of people actually have the time to use it. Most people bogged down with bug fixing and test management listening to the HANA, HANA, HANA propaganda rather than exploring and implementing computer science papers. There is not a lot of visible growth opportunities for the young people that come into former Sybase. Indeed most of the people are here for decades doing the same or almost the same thing.

review_title: Business Processes Principal Consultant
job_title: Business Processes Principal Consultant in Moorestown, NJ
pros: Leading edge technology/software company with competitive pay and benefits. Top company for social awareness and consistently among the best companies to work for in various surveys. Strong & focused senior leadership communicates the mission well for the whole organization. Major change management from on-premise to cloud-based culture is progressing well.
cons: Sometime a bit to heavy handed financial controls from HQ in Germany interferes with effective staffing/business execution in the field. Legacy on-premise attitudes are still entrenched in some areas, causing delivery hurtles that need extra effort to overcome.  the necessary competitive moves toward greater utilization of off-shore and near shore delivery centers is a necessity, but dilutes the quality of delivery as these less experiences tech-implementers do not have the same business domain experience as the regular consultants.

review_title: Functional overlay to the sales team focused on HCM, CRM, SCM and other product lines.
job_title: Center of Excellence (Sales Support) in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Good bonus structure and great benefits package.  exposure to really smart people and products across the board.
