You will get tasked with something you have no qualifications for, and you will be expected to work beyond normal work hours.
Career opportunities often get blocked internally because internal job applications are required to go through your manager.

review_title: Solution Architect
pros: Customers love SAP and hence I find it extremely important to work with them.  The organization fosters professionalism and transparency across all teams and markets. Personal and professional growth is given utmost important and everyone is encouraged to spend time to think about themselves and take charge of their career.
cons: One need to be very flexible and adaptive to be able to work in SAP. Because our customers are everywhere, across different geographies and time zones and depending on which SAP organization you work for, it can be sometimes late in the night or early in the morning. At the end of the day it is our work and one need to own it completely

review_title: For Sales, depends on which region you're in
pros: SAP is pretty good about their stock program, 401K and medical benefits. Working at a place with a recognizable brand name helps.
cons: It seems like every year, it gets worse and worse to be in sales at SAP. They constantly raise quotas by 50-200% year over year. My quota from last year went up 250%. They cut down the number of accounts you can have, and they constantly take out products from your sales bag and either don't give you credit for them but still have you support those conversations or they give the products to everyone to sell. There is a ton of competition against your own people at accounts. It's honestly like how Oracle used to be.

review_title: Technical Escalation Manager
job_title: Technical Escalation Manager in Monterrey, Nuevo León
pros: It is a company that cares for people's development and offer a balance between office & home. As a dad, i don't have to stress out my self looking for time to spend with my family, SAP provides me with a good quality life style and balance, therefore i commit myself to support my company whenever is needed and feel encouraged to proactively give more of my self anytime i can.
cons: I'm in a small location and probably sometimes i feel like the overall SAP culture is not translated to us. But that's ok - as we've been growing we started to see more engagement in cultural events organized by SAP.

review_title: Truly the best place to work
job_title: Senior Business Process Consultant in Toronto, ON
pros: Leadership, tell it like is culture, politics are much better compared to other companies, compensation, benefits, equity plans, training, colleagues, office locations, ability to work remote, career opportunity and advancement - I love this company and am never leaving!  Supportive of getting more women in sales and leadership, it's really refreshing that they recognize it's a boys club and actively changing it.
cons: With a company this large and complex it is difficult to "run simple". I do not know the answer, but there has to be a way to simplify how to work within the organization.

review_title: Best I've ever had!
job_title: Lead Support Consultant in Newtown Square, PA
pros: SAP allows employees the freedom to do the job without micro-management. Employees are empowered to create their own solutions and execute. The work hours can be long sometimes, but flexibility is given when needed. You are never alone at SAP. You always have a very large team to help you. Team work is not just something that is encouraged, it is part of the life here. We say it and we mean it, "There are no stupid questions"! If you need help, someone will help you.
cons: If you are the type that needs specific directions and plans to perform your job, this is not the place for you. If you do not like to travel, again, not the place for you.

review_title: In one word: Sharks!
job_title: Afraid to Say In Fear That SAP Management IS Here! in Chicago, IL
pros: Great Salary, Great benefits and paid time off.
cons: SAP is a great company overall.  However, if you are lucky to be in a department with good management.  In my depratment, you are on your own! No support from management, heavy politics, unbelievably debilitating bureocracy, arrogance is resonating throughout the entire department, ni communication and it is hard to trust people.  You spend half your time CYA.  You are only as good as your last recent performance.  Although Bill an\d Jim have created a great vision and people strategy, it does not propogate to all departments.  In my department, management uses fear as performance leverage.  SAD.

review_title: Once great company now in crisis
pros: The smartest people you'll ever work with. Good benefits, ability to be collaborative and always learn. Used to be the best company to work for.
cons:
Some of the worst upper management I've ever seen in my career. Constant mgt fight between German and US, upper management makes decisions and refuse to take input from people actually doing the work, bringing productivity to a standstill. Constant cutting corners, no budgets, endless politics make getting things done impossible. Extremely top-heavy with upper management, not lean.

Company currently has no direction, just parrots buzzwords and cannot clearly communicate to employees. Extremely political. Mired in complex processes. Constant re-orgs.

Does not care about employees, does not walk the walk about "people are our most valuable assets, we grow talent" - high performers laid off, with critical skills the company needs now; no real opportunity for career growth.

review_title: Great potential, poorly executed
pros: Great company and brand. Excellent co-workers. Strong suite of products. Good facilities and terms for most employees. Open and direct communication.
cons: Lip service only to career reviews and progression. Very high staff turnover in key sales roles. The customer is a low priority and assembling the right team together for many activities for a customer extremely difficult and very last minute. UK HR department is detached and generally unhelpful. Numbers of the least-respected individuals from a performance and contribution perspective are promoted!

review_title: Good for a long time, but has gone downhill over the past five years.
pros: Great bonuses, good vacation policy, community-oriented, decent medical benefits, very smart people to work with in general.  The company does a good job of taking care of and up-skilling new employees with the long view of their success.
cons: Attrition of benefits over time, quarterly focus on profits degrades quality, work-life balance is way off.  Travel is the norm for most consultants and sales people, but SAP takes it to an extreme.  The expectation for working during off-hours has been heightened in the past 3-4 years.  The recent realignment to a cloud-based business model is causing a great bit of internal upheaval.  Recent layoffs have hurt morale.

review_title: Engineering
pros: Major culture shift the last 7 years.  Leadership is making great strides to keep  us relevant and innovating.  They have done this under heavy competitive pressure and some key leadership changes the last few years. Company wide people are great to work with, benefits and pay are great.  Opportunity to work with many people all over the world which can be a challenge but we make it work well because of the people and culture.
cons: As with any large corporation there tends to be a lot of churn in middle management and this can make it difficult to keep a clear strategy and momentum over the longer term.  There has been less of a focus on strong leadership for many years but this is improving.  Many people in management positions with strong technical but poor management/leadership skills.

review_title: Very good employer but less learning and career growth
pros: Good Brand Name, Nice Campus/Offices ,Facilities like WFH for more than 2-3 days, Free Food, Free Transport, Car Policy,30 Day Leaves, Insurance, Health Check-up, Broadband Reimbursement, Decent Salary, Less or Manageable work load
cons:
-No Learning, Struck in same mechanical work intrusive to SAP.
-No Career path or growth. Career Management is not a priority of the managers here since most of them are home grown after spending X years in SAP.
-High percentage of package is Bonus that’s paid once a year reducing the take home salary
-Govt. organization /Arrogance kind of attitude in people since most of them have been here for more than 10 years doing the same kind of work.
-People here don’t want to change or adopt any latest trends and will screw you if you propose any process or technology improvements.

review_title: CRM Functional Consultant
job_title: CRM Functional Consultant in Buenos Aires
pros: It is full of resources of all kinds, lots of opportunities regarding training and certifications.  The network is incredible, where ever you need you just need to ask, and you will get it.  I have worked for a lot of corporations before SAP and I found SAP different, from my perspective it is a company that really worth it!.
cons: If you are in PSO your travel capacity should be 100% of your time, if you are not in that place, then it is not going to be a good fit for you. Like any other corporation, a lot of things are already set and of course, there is bureaucracy which sometimes caused delays or confusion.  I guess the cons are more for you to be clear what to work for a well set corporation means.

review_title: SAP is a Great Place to Work
job_title: Regional Director in Newtown Square, PA
pros: The benefits, compensation, perks, time-off and overall corporate culture is second to none. You definitely feel that SAP cares for you not just as an employee, but as if you were part of a large interconnected SAP family. The company tries to invest in the right programs to develop and reward people, and puts employees at the center of it's key decisions. Helping other organizations run better using best in breed technology drives employees here. You feel inspired by great colleagues on a regular basis.
cons: With 93K+ employees, it's a hard place to get big things done. It doesn't offer the flexibility and upside wealth potential of a start-up, but you can have a solid career making a difference in the world and do reasonably well for you and your family.

review_title: 10+ years and still loving it
job_title: Senior DevOps Engineer in Vancouver, BC
pros:
I really feel like SAP does not only have great core values written down somewhere, but actually lives them, with many internal and external initiatives showing that. No question SAP is a stock traded company and therefore needs to keep stockholders happy, but is at the same time making efforts to use its reach to do good.

Despite being a huge corporation, one does not feel like being just a (i-) number.

Always technologically advancing which while challenging is fun.

Great corporate culture and diverse workforce.

In my job I was provided with all kind of opportunities to advance in my career, for which I had to work for of course, but they were/are there.
cons: Some of the usual suspects of large corporations, e.g. questionable processes, diversity in leadership (especially women in higher roles), but they are all continuously improved, just slowly bit by bit.

review_title: I love SAP - SAP loves me
job_title: Human Resources Services Associate in Prague
pros:
You know how you often read that slogan "Become everything you want to be"? 
SAP makes it come true! 5 months into my first role I successfully introduced my own global project and I am now working with people from all over the world on a regular basis.
In addition, during these challenging times especially, SAP has shown to be a top-level employer as I constantly felt like I was taken care of during the lockdown and transition to home office. I was able to continue my work normally with no setbacks.
cons: The only downside I see in SAP is that the communication between different lines of businesses doesn't seem to be smooth which often may cause delays and frustration.

review_title: "grow grow grow" motto should also applies to employees
pros: SAP delivers Technology state-of-art tools and aides to its employees; it has a consistent and permanent training program that allows to keep professionals updated, Human Resources Dept. encourages Work and Life balance;  the work environment is respectful
cons: Poor career advancement blocked by the direct managers despite the professional growth supported by the training program, salary raising politics not consistent over the years (e.g. sometimes you can not cope up with yearly inflation); too bureaucratic and heavy internal procedures; bonuses plan decreasing year by year; the certification requests are to stressful to manage and the certification tests do not measure the real knowledge and experience because they are only focused on the memorizing factor

review_title: SAP great benefits, frustrating if you have employee performance issues.
job_title: Operations Manager in Greenwood Village, Optional[CO]
pros: Great benefits package as well as pay.  Good people to work with.  Impressive programs designed to identify potential high performers.  They are obviously doing something right, as evidenced by their market share in the ERP software industry.  SAP Senior Management rallies the troops very well.  Offices are quite modern and comfortable.  Nice little perks, such as a lunch program for office based employees.
cons: Company is very conservative and business is over-influenced by legal considerations.  Employees seem to be hesitant to criticize the lack of potential imporovements to productivity, such as SAP applications that are difficult to interface with standard software.

review_title: Hopefully will improve under once CEO, Bill  --  and Vishal's resignation
job_title: Sen Director in Palo Alto, CA
pros: SAP has this massive install base of ERP systems, so the "opportunity is SAP's to lose".  Unfortunately we do seem to be losing one battle after another, with the likes of Salesforce.com and Workday simply eating our lunch.
cons: Promotions are basically "who you know" and I've been bounced around too many times and looked over.   The best people tend to leave once they see they are not going to be recognized ....    Most senior management place higher value on externals - so generally you can expect to remain stuck.

review_title: Lots of perks, for a lot of work
job_title: Support Engineer in Newtown Square, PA
pros:
Some of the best training available at a company. We're talking classroom, books, etc. provided. It's a real throwback to your college days.
Some of the best compensation possible as well, such as a large salary, a bonus, and equipment.
cons: Long, long hours. Your fat salary comes at the price of long hours. Don't expect a 40-hour work week here, at all. If you're unfortunate enough to be in a position that requires traveling, expect to see your family a lot less than you do now.

review_title: Great company
pros:
Company supports work-life balance and promotes healthy lifestyle
Home office 
Benefits + bonus
Company values, most of the colleagues You are going to meet will be very friendly
plenty of internal career opportunties
Brand - everyone in finance field knows SAP as a system, good experience
A lot of training and learning opportunities
Supportive management - in general, depends on the department

In general I am very satisfied - I would recomment the company for a long term perspective
cons:
Too much tolerance for complaining fresh graduates - junior or assistant positions should be created for them
Lenght of employment  is more appriciated than real skills (but it can be also a pro for shy colleagues, everyone will get an opportunity to grow eventually)
Low age average in described location - difficult to find "mentors" to learn from when You are joining the team as already experienced member

review_title: Personal learning and development on a global scale
job_title: Associate Creative Director: Employer Branding in Austin, TX
pros: The flexible working hours at SAP allows me to make the most of my day and avoid time sinks such as heavy traffic. Continuous learning is strongly encouraged and I am able to hone my craft working on a diverse range of projects.  I've personally never felt closer to this world we live on as I get to work with amazing colleagues globally towards our goal of improving peoples lives. There is a structure and trust that exists within SAP that i have yet to find elsewhere.
cons:
I hope you like emails :) 
If you try and go it alone you may feel overwhelmed, if you run with the best you will go far.

review_title: Hierarchical and non-diverse company
pros: Free lunch and some managers may be good
cons: The big con is lack of diversity, in reality, they keep sharing statistics or ratings claiming to be winning diversity awards but it is a sham, the Board of directors is all white male Germans, only one lady in it I am guessing for optics. I work in Africa and all management is white, from CEO, CFO(german ), COO etc claiming they hire the best people for the roles as if there aren't other people besides white male Germans qualified for the job. Additionally, they are very big on bureaucracy and have lots of approvals for basic things including even when taking internal training.

review_title: Still a fascinating company to work for -  a place for fun at work and business success.
pros: Great products - deversified portfolio with innovation build-in in every layer. Highly skilled colleagues - profound experts in many departments willing to share their knowledge and contribute to the sussess of other teams, highly value their responsiveness and fairness. This comes from  motivating management culture, enforced by the recent Board changes (Jim and Bill, as well as the recently hired Angelika to lead HR and give People the force at the top).
cons: Overly complex - this is true for many products and programms, as well as for the internal structures and processes.

review_title: Great place to get experience and leave
job_title: Global Product Support Engineer in São Leopoldo, Rio Grande do Sul
pros: Outstanding work-life balance. Many people almost do not even work at SAP, and spend all day doing personal tasks and watching videos. Good point is getting experience on a specific module, and leave SAP to work as external consultant.
cons: The same people that do not work sometimes earn almost the double than hard workers. SAP has no meritocracy and the salary is only based on initial negotiation. In Brazil if you do not negotiate a good salary when you enter, either you become a manager (which is an extremely unclear process) or you will get frustrated as you will produce a lot and will only hear "sorry" from your manager.

review_title: Fantastic company for which to work
job_title: Executive Assistant in Newtown Square, PA
pros:
*Good benefits, salary, maternity/paternity leave, bonuses. 
*Pleasant security and other staff. 
*Great culture that focuses on development, teamwork,  success of both the company and the customer. *Depending on your manager, there is a lot of opportunity to learn and expand your horizons. there are courses in-house for employees that make personal development a real option.
cons:
*Sometimes parking is hard to find at Newtown Square office
*Some positions require a lot of travel. 
*Work life balance is encouraged, but some positions make it difficult to maintain
*Yearly increases are not as high as they could be. 
*To start here, many employees must begin as an hourly contractor and work towards becoming salary.

review_title: SAP - right company for you?
job_title: Senior Director Business Development in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Salary and Benefits are excellent.
If you go in at the right level with the right executive support, SAP can be a great place for you.
cons: Career Path = Challenging as SAP categorizes all employees as managers or "experts" (read: individual contributor).  Once done, they don't like to reclassify.  In other words, your career possibilities are established early and if you don't like the path you're on, it's VERY difficult to change within the company.

review_title: World class company but over engineered processes
pros: SAP is a world class company where people work hard but also get competitive compensation and benefits.  Despite being a large company, it is up to yo to shine and take control of your career. There is no glass ceiling, and great performance is quickly noticed and recognized by management. Employees feel a sense of pride working for this company given the strong executive leadership (Bill is an amazing CEO and human being) and the strong brand.
cons: SAP is a complex organization with a dizzying number of teams, departments and virtual groups, with a lot of overlap.  They take matrix structures to the extreme.  Internal initiatives are over-engineered, creating additional but unnecessary work, such as more spreadsheets to track everything, more KPI's, and more meetings to plan more meetings.

review_title: Great people but pay and talent need improvements
job_title: Director in South San Francisco, CA
pros:
People are nice and they have a get things done mindset
Somewhat flexible work-life balance
Management cares about culture and people
Right emphasis and focus on priorities by management
cons:
Difficult to get a response from HR and they don't get back to you in a timely manner
Collaboration and other basic office tools are painful to use (not integrated, SSO issues, different systems that are cobbled together)
Feels like an older, corporate company
Not very diversified at the exec management layer
Somewhat chaotic work culture 
Talent needs improvement (bar could be set higher for new hires and existing employees)

review_title: CONSULTANT
pros: Salary is higher than market. Company culture is friendly! You can reach the documents and trainings easily. You can travel a lot.
cons: Imagine you start the job as a technical consultant. However, later they ask you to the sales pre-sales activities, which is generally does not fit your background and personality. And later you are blames becuase you did not perform a sales actvitiy. You may find yourself complaining as "But I do not also clean the office because I am not the cleaner. Same for being a sales guy. I am not a salesman but you ask me to do more than 2 jobs at the same time!!"

review_title: Great place to work
pros: great place to work..excellent pay, benefits, chance to learn new skills, management willing to work with employees, work/life balance, company does not mind spending money for hotels, food. flights when having get togethers, great bonus program, very easy to make great money if you work, always have meeting at the best places Las Vegas, Dallas, Atlanta, Martha's Vineyard, always top notch.
cons: A few PM's have an attidtude problem. These are easily remembered since they are not that many and you can pick and choose what projects you want so if a bad PM is on it, simply pass the project.

review_title: Great company w/ good products; however, horrible leadership and direction in Vancouver
pros: Great benefits.  Great location.  Friendly coworkers.  Good products.  Great pay when meeting quota.  SAP looks great on your resume, as I discovered.
cons: unrealistic quotas for most.  Tools needed for inside sales not given, such as a proper leads system, CRM and integrated phone system.  End of quarter turn some in used car salesmen w/ their tactics.  Appearance is just as important as results.  You must appear to getting results w/ bogus entries in CRM, exaggerated results to management, etc.  Told to make 40 calls a day; however, not given any contact info. or leads.

review_title: Disappointing experience, all top talent is leaving
job_title: Account Executive in San Francisco, CA
pros: Huge customer base, that is about it.
cons: Products are perceived in the market as old technology with bad user experience. Constant change in leadership (top and middle management); terrible culture; although they are trying to attract young talent they continue to fail to deliver on talent-development programs; rampant nepotism; lack of accountability, too many "legacy" employees with high salaries who are not bought into the idea of bringing new talent onboard and most importantly, keeping it!

review_title: Complex with great global reach
pros:
- Global company, one of world's leading technology/business solution providers, great drive to innovate and change the business paradigm.
- many travel opportunities 
- well known in some industries, less in others
- HANA is seemingly the best in-memory database in existence today, huge opportunity
cons:
- very complex, takes a long time to 'see the light' and understand the complexity of solutions and how they interact, integrate and with a constant stream of new acquisitions it will keep one busy
- several reorganizations and changes in middle management 
- not too well known (yet) outside of Europe
- huge 'tail' of old perceptions, slow, mammoth and inflexible contrasts with new drive to innovate and change business for the better

review_title: Stuck in a Silo
job_title: Senior Product Specialist in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Warm people work here who have the potential to be good friends.  Lots of activities on campus to both help you network and gain new skills. The facilities are awesome and include a gym and free lunch.
cons: Each group/department/project seems to be run in isolation.  There is very little collaboration across the organization.  The culture is nepotistic. A good number of managers should not be managers and treat their underlings as either an entourage or player trading cards that they collect for the sake of maintaining appearances.

review_title: I had got offer from SAP SDC for project manager role.
pros:
Since I have passion to work on delivering SAP projects I was keen in joining this organization. But unfortunately I'm not keen on to travel frequently. I understand life in SAP SDC/GD  is hectic on travelling for consultants but not sure for project managers. Do anybody has an idea on kind of travel expected for the project managers part of PMO practice in SAP SDC. Please share your reviews.
How often the project managers travel in SAP GD/SDC and the travel duration ranges for how many months.
cons: I would leave this space to be shared by the experienced folks from SAP SDC. can you please answer my question folks

review_title: not the SAP that you know
pros:
The salary is good compared to the market, plus you have many other perks. 
It is a huge ship which is difficult to move, but not impossible. If you have the ambition and energy, you can accomplish great things. But nothing is delivered on a silver plate, you need to fight your way through to get there.
cons: Many employees who have been working at SAP for a really long time (>20 years) so sometimes it is not very dynamic. Some of these people work the way we used to work 10 - 20 years ago. So sometimes it is challenging to innovate (talking about disruptive innovation) in such an environment.

review_title: Once you come to SAP there is no reason to leave!
job_title: Senior Human Resources Business Partner in Newtown Square, PA
pros: Smart people, interesting work, amazing culture supporting us to bring our true selves to work, tons of opportunities (openness and support to transfer across teams, if desired), authentic leaders, flexibility to balance the rest of your life, year-round volunteer opportunities and support to give back to the communities where we live and work.
cons:
It is hard to get into SAP - I have referred friends but the competition is fierce and interview cycles can be long.

We are working to improve diversity here but there are many programs in place and employee and leadership led initiatives to improve our diversity.  In my experience, the culture is a place where everyone is welcome to be who they are but we need to do better at recruiting more diverse talent.

review_title: Great company to work with unparralel benefits offerings!
pros:
- Very good benefits plan - very few companies can match it , Globally.
- A lot of flexibility and work life balance
-A lot of career opportunity internally, opportunity to try new roles for short or longer duration 
-Learning opportunity is great! Trainings and loads of trainings...so much so it's difficult to get time and attend all.
-Social enterprising and support to various social causes, supporting organisations those support social causes
-Inclusion and diversity- a great place to work, very inclusive culture
cons:
- More women participation is needed at managerial and executive level. 
- Internal alignment of the businesses is needed, streamline the Org structure.

review_title: Great Place to work, but you better make your quota
pros:
Great brand recognition
Looks good on a resume
A lot of opportunity to learn new technology and experience new roles
Base level salary is higher than most
cons:
There tends to be a "what have you done for me lately" attitude on the Sales side which results in a lot of talented people being let go due to a perceived lack of performance.
It's very easy to be "type-cast" into a role and not be able to get out of it
Out of sight means out of mind and employees are expected to sell themsleves internally to get on deals

review_title: Politics, Politics, Politics
pros: Global recognized brand, huge customer base, large scale projects working at a global company that makes technology most major companies use
cons: Politics and culture of an old legacy software company are rampant. Extremely slow moving. Lots of people with extremely long tenures (which is not common in the tech world) that have no other experience outside SAP and are so very set in their ways--very political and "clickish". Lots of unproductive employees they can't get rid of due to european employment laws. Will take a miracle for SAP to improve the outdated culture, red tape, and bureaucracy built over the last several decades at this company. They're a bleeding talent from some of the innovative companies they have acquired in the last few years.

review_title: Terrible Team Lead
job_title: IT Service Desk Analyst in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Free food and opportunity of working from home.
cons:
Terrible Team Lead, he has no idea how to deal with people and get the best from them. 

Only numbers are considered.

No possibility to get a salary increase.

Restrict work as you are very limited in what you can do. 

They only want people to take the calls and just it, they are not really looking for people with knowledge and that really could fix users issues, as far you take the call and hung it up, it is more the enough, why fix users issues properly?  Just escalate it.

It is what the most of the people there do, they do not know how to fix the issue, they just escalate it.

review_title: I LOVE working for SAP
job_title: Senior Director SAP Ariba Presales in Denver, CO
pros: I originally started working for Ariba quite a few years ago and came to work for SAP as a result of the acquisition of Ariba by SAP in 2012. Since the acquisition, I have seen Ariba, now SAP Ariba, grow and flourish like never before. With the help of our parent, SAP, we have innovated more in the last 5 years than in the prior 10 years combined. Further, SAP is such a great company to work for that I've never been more happy and satisfied with my job and my earnings. I am very proud to call SAP my employer and most importantly, the place where I feel at home and a solid career.
cons: Be prepared to work hard and be rewarded nicely for your hard work.

review_title: Image and Ego
pros:
- Fellow Employees are typically pretty good
- Compensation good for the first few years
cons:
- Company LOVES restructuring. In 2018 alone I saw around 15 changes in leadership or organizational structure
- Anything from higher than your director (if they're even local) comes across more as a press release than a team member talking to you
- Almost all offices are open concept, with meeting rooms always packed with people trying to find privacy
- Willing to fire scores of employees because leadership/sales made mistakes
- A very visible section of the leadership team is obsessed with identity

review_title: Big company but do not stay for long
job_title: Software Engineer in South San Francisco, CA
pros: Good 401k matching. Good place to learn about enterprise software.
cons: Significantly low pay compared to other jobs in the Bay Area. No clear company agenda. Too many managers which create a huge disconnect. Many managers are unqualified and upper management only care about numbers and not results. Trust in management is super low, especially after the huge layoffs in March. Tech stack is old and becoming obsolete. Progress is slow. Unless you’re planning on retiring soon, staying for more than a few years in SAP is career suicide. That’s a reason why many employees have a hard time leaving the company and those who do end up leaving for MS, Salesforce, Workday, etc.

review_title: Best Place to Work!
job_title: Customer Engagement Executive in Boston, MA
pros: Ethical, Innovative - and expands innovation in multiples through Partners, Visionary, Senior Management pushes Wellness to employees, Inclusive culture, Listens to Customers and uses their boots on the ground feedback to enhance products .
cons: I have worked in a few companies over my career, and SAP stands out as a best place to work.  Nothing is perfect, but the grass is not  greener on the other side.  Providing management actionable feedback is the way to go.  I am staying at SAP - they listen and act - yeah Qualtrics!

review_title: Great place for work-life balance. Not great for advancing your career
job_title: Business Support Associate in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
flexible work from home policy
- employees got to work from home at least two days a week(or more if approved)
boss allowed some employees to live outside the Bay Area if they desired- in return the employee needed to visit once a quarter
- boss was very ok with employees clocking off to pick up children or go exercise in the middle of the afternoon- as long as you did your work shortly after, all was fine

free lunch

you almost never worked more than 8 hours a day. often, many employees would work less than that as the amount of work would be empty on certain days
cons:
not a good place to start your career- opportunities to advance are very limited
work is quite boring
pay is kinda low for the bay area

review_title: UX Designer
pros: Benefits, theoretical possibility of changing jobs/departments, slightly higher salary than average as Creative, nice colleagues, insight into how a large enterprise works, Design Thinking methods
cons:
Due to size of enterprise sometimes very slow movement, little to no innovation possible although it seems like that from the outside.

Average age in headquarters 40+,  therefore not ideal for an early career

Change and possibilities too dependant on the will of the manager and available budget, which is frustrating.

Some departments frequently travel, others never get to. Thats why the quality of a product is also highly dependant on that (no proper research, no budget, not enough staff = poorer quality of end product)

review_title: 20th century technology and lots of propaganda
pros: It's a tech company. Pay is reasonable, given the lowball "salaries" (if one is lucky to have one) that have become standard in the economy. Benefits are good.
cons: Zero visibility to those on the ground. All major decisions are made in Germany, and are often shortsighted and/or senseless. Developers who aren't in Waldorf or Bangalore often get the short end of the stick, while expecting to conform to half-year deadlines. Teams are spread out across timezones, making it difficult to collaborate effectively. Core backend technology is severely outdated and causes a lot of problems with modern client-side application implementations (i.e. mobile).

review_title: Good opportunities at a solid company but be prepared to work hard
job_title: Solutions Engineer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Lots of opportunity, a solid company, new things to learn. SAP has good products and a pretty solid management team. Of course, there are good things and bad things about SAP and there are good and bad managers. But, as a whole, it's a good company to work for if you can deal with working for a big company. It definitely doesn't have a start-up feel and after 4 years I still don't understand the org structure. But, you can grow at SAP and the benefits typically seem to outway the issues. Pay and benefits are pretty competitive and there's even a pension.
cons: Hard work. Culture is to work very hard and long hours. SAP always wants more from employees.

review_title: Great company with some shortcomings in its engineering departments
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Walldorf, Baden-Wurttemberg
pros:
above average salary
everything is quite relaxed, no pressure, no extra hours
Many extras like sport and fitness opportunities, company car, ...
the company has a unique market position. Quite unlikely they get a real competitor any time soon
cons:
too many unskilled / unqualified employees
most software seems to be completly broken (see first point)
most problems are solved by pure manpower instead of using some brainpower
Everybody seems to be fine with delivering broken and far too complex products. There seems to be no motivation or competence to engineer really good products.

review_title: Director, Solution Management
job_title: Director Solution Management in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Excellent work-family balance, work from home options, very nice benefits (although salary not too high), encourage employee growth....

Colleagues are nice and respect each other and help each other out and there is a lot to learn from the different resources available, training given to employees, opportunities to grow and build your dreams and aspirations...all in all, it's a GREAT company to work for and I would recommend it highly to people from different stages of their career!
cons:
Typical "red tape" associated with a large company...it takes longer to respond to market demand and customer expectations sometimes because of the processes we need to go through (compared to start-ups for example)....so if you are competing with start-ups and smaller vendors, it can be a little challenging... 

Takes some time to get adjusted to SAp's work culture, teams, how to get around the teams etc...

review_title: Solution Management
pros: The salary at SAP is on the higher side for technology companies. Bonuses are fairly consistent however they tend to be a larger percentage of overall compensation, more so than most would want. Other pluses are things like employee stock purchase plans, good insurance, many employee discounts at companies SAP does business with and a flexible work environment.
cons: Promotions are difficult to obtain probably due to the recent acquisitions, making the organization top heavy. Other cons are work-life balance from the organization challenges of being in multiple countries. Most of the colleagues we interact with are in the corporate HQ location in Germany so there are many early morning calls needed.

review_title: SAP services
pros:
Good location of the office. The  whole facility is very comfortable and cool. Home office possibility.
Big range of educational opportunities within the company. Flexible working hours. SAP software works good :)
cons:
Salary is lower compares other shared service centers in Prague
Not very many possibilities to go to another level on your position, like specialist for example. If you are working in finances then almost only way of promotion which is causing raise of salary is promotion to management level.
Referral bonus is paid only after 6 month of person working in the company, meanwhile first contract is almost always for 6 month :)

review_title: A bad team amid an alright company
pros: Interesting work and great opportunity to work with people from around the globe.
cons:
My personal experience is my manager was given a team they never wanted, and would rather remain in development than management. They are ill prepared to deal with conflict, and treats their employees unequally.  It's been made clear that career opportunities and flex work arrangements (a 'benefit' of employment) are rewarded unjustly. 
The questionnaires passed out by HR are worded such that any real concerns aren't brought to light, and direct confrontation sheds light on the fact that any issues should be swept under the rug.

review_title: This review is for SAP ARIBA, Don't think both are same.
pros: Free food and cab. SAP ARIBA has nothing good except this.
cons:
Legacy technology.
Worst location and infrastructure both BTP and Sharda towers.
Management and team is regional biased.
All good and new tech work will be given to favourite employees and you will be working with old legacy technology. 
Legacy tech has no value and u will learn nothing.
In Sharda towers specially, local regional language preferred people are sitting and who doesn't want to move or change.
Team is not welcoming to Hindi/English speaking people.
It is not the case in one team only but I found this issue with most teams.
I have never seen this type of culture in all my career in Bangalore.
Ariba is ruining the work culture ethics.

review_title: It's not the same any longer
pros: I worked at SuccessFactors for several years. I joined around the time SAP bought Successfactors, it was the best job I had. We used to have a great team. Very great and approachable leadership. It had a great culture. The best job I ever had.
cons: After the SAP acquisition, SAP completely destroyed the culture of SuccessFactors. They brought in new incompetent product and engineering management. All the new management did was fire a bunch of people, and create a stupid policy about co-located teams, and ironically split the location Bay area location into two offices. So much so for co-location. I would not recommend the company to anyone since the leadership is weak and wanting with no vision for the future of the company.

review_title: Safe harbor in uncertain times - clear "people first" strategy
pros:
SAP is really taking care of its employees or how else can you explain zero job losses during covid19? Clear message, clear strategy how to move forward and weather the crisis together. 
Apart from the crisis, SAP offers tones of benefits and offers you a place you WANT to work. You don´t have to, you want to.
cons: Like in many other big multi-national companies, decision making takes much longer and an information overload due to its big product portfolio is certain. But that happens in many other firms too...

review_title: SAP is ok but not as good as it once was.
pros: IF you like an opportuntity for Global Travel then go here.
cons: Culture can be slanted to 'German' side of the house. Depending on which department you are in can be a decent place or bad. Large corporation with typical politics. Travel cab be excessive. Can have peaks or periods of time where you are working much more than your 40hr week. Is not as loyal to employees now in 2008 as it was in the 1990's. They will cut people without thinking if the numbers are not being met, just like every other large corporation.

review_title: Good Place Gone Ugly
pros: Good customer base and recurring revenues. Great customer list. Product is best of class with very ugly User Interface, which can not be fixed until the entire product is rewritten. Pays well and provides good benefits - although they're being diluted year after year - first employee stock purchase plan was taken off, then pension plan - now I'm sure the 401k match will be reduced.
cons: * Too political, too many middle managers. Too bureaucratic with too many middle managers (Directors and VPs) with no real power so so they have to resort to politics. No real innovation - it is a cash cow which is being milked by the executives specially McDermott and his cabal.

review_title: Focus on fit + capabilities
pros: Lots of opportunities for movement within the company if you look for them, strong sense of teamwork and collaboration if you find the right team, and opportunities to work on cutting-edge tech and business issues leveraging the scale of a global enterprise.
cons: The size and the complexity of the organization mean that there sometimes is a lack of clarity and lack of alignment, internally.  Decision making can be slow at times, and in the end this is not so much a truly global company as it is a German company with operations (and thousands of employees) dispersed around the globe - a subtle but important distinction.

review_title: An elite and respected employer, but not all rosy
pros: Outstanding products, solutions and efforts toward innovation.  Many bright, hard working and aggressive people.  Connections in the industry are great and SAP "card" is a door opener.
cons: Too much of the focus today is on sales and marketing goals (and results), with not enough recognition of general economy.   Product development and solutions expertise seems to have become a second priority wtih executive management looking at the numbers drive.   The "partner" game and high margin goals can cause bad behavior.

review_title: Stable, rock solid company
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros: SAP being a 40 year old Enterprise Software company offers a very stable work environment. SAP Labs is the R&D division of the company. Work is interesting, as we keep exploring new opportunities to build new features and products. The culture is consensus oriented. There is not too much of hierarchy.
cons:
Depending on which part of the organization you are in, the nature of work can vary dramatically. SAP has seen tremendous success with its ERP applications. But, success has been far and few in other areas. The company is trying to reinvent itself in areas of Cloud and Mobility.
Do not expect to work on the latest and greatest of technologies. Speed of innovation has been another challenge. Things tend to move slow, and the focus is usually on delivering a near perfect solution rather than something quick and good enough.

review_title: A great company to work for
Fantastic!! If you like working with smart people, SAP is the place to be.
pros: Software is one of the best industries to work for and SAP is one of the leaders in the software industry. As an employee, you have opportunities for personal growth. Since a lot of employees work remotely, there is not a strong office culture but the company has strong core values.
cons: As with many companies who are experiencing double-digit growth every year, change is the name of the game at SAP. Sometimes it seems we go through changes just to shake things up.

review_title: Feature Developer in Vancouver
pros:
I worked in the Vancouver office as a feature developer. It was a good experience. Wasn't anything special. The people were very nice, the challenges were ok. I think it's a good company to give you industry exposure after university.

They offered paid lunches, where you could use a gift card and go to a number of restaurants around the area.

Good if you're looking for a stable job.
cons: It was a little laid back, personally I didn't get anything technically interesting. But then again I wasn't really passionate about Business Intelligence.

review_title: Endless growth opportunities, dedicated staff, killer industry
pros: The culture at SAP is undeniably strong. Management does an incredible job of focusing on company goals and getting you to think bigger picture. They really tie you into why you do what you do, and how every role is important. The industry itself promotes the growth and positive atmosphere in the company. People seriously love this place and you see it within everyone you meet.
cons:
Building out succession planning and frequent, major changes in the organizational structure. While
Change is good and needed, SAP restructured departments and made major changes continuously. It was difficult to see if the impact of the changes were successful because the next change was already in the works.

review_title: Senior Quality Analyst, Bangalore- Bullying and Toxic environment
pros: Free Transport and Food
cons:
I decided to join SAP after looking into all the good reviews about the organization.  However work culture, Work-life balance all depends on the Team/LOB that you join. 
From the past 1 year that I have been working here I do not see any of the "good review" points coming true. The team that I am part of has  people with more than 10years experience. Bullying, Harassing is very common because of their own insecurities.  Lots of politics being played which would not allow a new comer to stabilize at  the workplace. 
Favoritism is also part of this show, which leads to undeserving employees being rewarded and eventually promoted. 
Work-life balance is zero now due to the stress that the workplace has induced.

review_title: SAP makes you want to go the extra mile
pros:
Can be busy at times, like any job, but if you're an American who wants European work-life balance, SAP is the way to go. Remote work is common and encouraged, 2-3 days a week. No set hours. Set your own schedule. Very good healthcare benefits. Decent 401k, cash target bonuses are often exceeded based on company performance, and a very generous ESPP that is basically free money. They also promote from within. 

McDermott is continuing to build upon a company culture that values its employees, and it shows.
cons: The company is a disorganized behemoth and can be difficult to navigate. Expect to spend days making simple decisions with people on the other side of the world. As a plus, you do get to work with people from all over the world.

review_title: "BEST PLACE TO WORK"
pros:
Excellent opportunities for project managers to drive the delivery of niche SAP products. 
E2E visibility for the project manager,  starting from discover phase to Run phase.
Very friendly atmosphere. Thanks to the leadership team for the drive of installing friendly ambience in the organization. 
Very supportive supervisors 
Very decent salary package.
Good work life balance.
cons: There is definitely no Cons . Should be the same with many of SAP employees, this is explicitly seen as a result of negligible count on exit rate in SAP.

review_title: Business Analyst
pros: I have worked for several other companies on my way here to Fieldglass and I can say, without hesitation, that SAP Fieldglass gets it.  They do not micromanage, they are flexible, caring, understanding and make it a joy to come to work each day.  I have been given the opportunity to work from home, leave early and many other work life balance requests.  My manager is supportive and encouraging to my career development.
cons: One of the downsides is that it is hard to know where to go for information as there are so many departments and teams and group emails.  Having a better directory of team/departments/emails would be helpful.

review_title: Regret about my career move to SAP
pros:
Nice food
Benefits
Cab facility
Nice Salary
Eco-friendly environment
cons:
No proper involvement of HR with the employees after you put down your papers to know your issues.
No exit interview to exchange your problems
Managers are non-supportive

review_title: Communications Consultant
pros:
I've been working in Galway in a global communications role for just over a year and I've had such a great experience so far!  Since my first interview I've just really loved the culture and people at SAP. There are a lot of benefits to working here including 
- Management puts trust in the employees 
- Autonomy and a lot of opportunities to take initiative and make an impact
- Great culture and company values that you can get behind
- Opportunity to volunteer and help out your local community 
- Flexible working hours
- Option to work remotely up to 2 days a week 
- Gym onsite and free lunches is a real bonus 
- They value employee development and there are lots of learning and development opportunities for every level.
cons: Really enjoying SAP so far so no cons.

review_title: LATAM Boys Club Central America
job_title: Senior Regional Sales Executive Latin America in Miami, FL
pros: Good benefits, great enterprise and leading business software solution products.
cons: SAP LATAM is the epitome of the Latin macho boys’ club.  The toxic and hostile environment is not only within the North team, but it is also fomented and perpetuated by its top leaders and complicit with human resources.  As a former employee, who was subjected to age, gender,  ethnic discrimination and inappropriate touching harassment, I was fired in retaliation three business days after an unresolved mediation with the EEOC.  After almost 5 years of loyal service and enduring this level of employee treatment, SAP discharged me in the most inhumane and humiliated manner without severance and without completion of expense reimbursement.  They don’t practice what they preach, high turnover in management and promotion of unqualified talent based on favoritism. At SAP you are only a number.

review_title: SAP Labs Israel, very good place to work and learn, very bad HR.
job_title: Business Scenarios Modeler, QM in Tel Aviv-Yafo
pros:
SAP Labs Israel:
learn how a big organization works, learn methodologies, learn good things (like processes) and bad things (like to long processes).
the main good thing is learning, if you don't have experience this is the best place to learn.
cons:
SAP Labs Israel:
 bureaucracy, can't develop new things, everything takes time. can't propose  new GUI and UI, all is according to corporate standards (which are very constrained due to regulations).
not a good place for innovations or creativity.
very bad HR, the HR is very nice as long as there are no problems, the minute you need something or  leaving the company, the HR will be your worst enemy.

review_title: Good but can be frustrating
pros: great benefits, looks great on a resume, mostly talented and competent people.  SAP quickly weeds out the inefficient and incompetent.  Good products, and the entire SAP marketing engine is designed to sell software with a great infrastructure of support.
cons: It is clearly the "German way or no way".  Too much process control, too many middle managers, too many product acroynms.  For the sales people, can be incredibly rewarding financially, but the quota pressure is ENORMOUS and if your territory sucks, then you will be looking for a new job within 18 months.

review_title: Overall good but you can be typecast in a particular role which can make it hard to move up without moving out.
pros: Amazing sales force with good products - especially HANA. Very customer focused. Managed very well with good senior management. Good work environment. Can also get a good work-life balance ... but you still have to contribute.
cons: Can be almost impossible to get your ideas properly considered unless you know the right people, but then many large companies are like this. Although getting better, many people still seem to think that SAP is the center of the software universe which means opportunities are missed - see Advice to Management.

review_title: One of the strongest and the oldest player still holding its strength.
pros: They have been the key player for enterprise software market for more than a quarter of a century. Looking from inside, the system and eco-cycle with the stake holders including partners and customers are their strong point.
cons: The market is rapidly changing their rules like the evolving of cloud solution. Yes, the company has started to acquire company to get the cloud DNA, but the selling strategy and license model is too complex and difficult for the new comers to join, and the new culture of DNA seems to be quite difficult for some of the sales managers.

review_title: Too big to provide decent employee benefits/advancement potential
pros: It's a popular solution for large enterprise businesses, but struggling with opposition from the following:  niche s/w and services solutions that address comprehensive in-depth business capabilities, e.g. Workday, Salesforce; and large enterprise s/w companies that can provide global, mobile products at a more effective price point, particularly based upon cloud capabilities.
cons: Too little focus on employees and customer satisfaction; too much emphasis on margins and product development; too much complexity across business units and matrixed management; too much confusion re: partners and integration; no accountability except for sales/margin numbers.

review_title: Not impressed working at SAP Canada. Worked there for almost 5 years.
pros:
- If lucky good working conditions
- Flexible(can work from home)
- Nice office locations
- Free food, drinks, TV, games, etc.
- Good to have it on your resume
cons:
- It is almost impossible to switch jobs if you have no support or know people very well
- Boring work, no real innovation, very repetitive.
- Lots of bad managers who promote their peeps.
- If you work hard or are lazy you will get the same outcome.
- No sense of direction, bad decision making by management.
- Expect to do training but barely allocated time and opportunities. Usually has to come out of your own time.....
- Low salaries

review_title: Great place to work if you're over 40 or if you have an extensive knowledge of analytics software.
pros: Free Lunch, Great benefits, Travel stipend, 3000 products to sell, salary + ote when you reach Large Enterprise sales
cons: Too big of a company to make immediate decisions or get customer service issues handled in a timely matter.  Sales process is completely micromanaged and you will have to update upper management 3x a week on the same information. Managers are not upfront about actual comp made within verticals and territories .  Takes years to get a pipeline and by then they will have already changed your territory or vertical or job description.

review_title: Great company.
pros:
- Company continues to strive and invest to be at forefront of business and IT, SAP is an exciting place to work.
- Great benefits, people, and pay
- Lots of smart people to work with and opportunities abound
- Mature processes, management and capabilities
cons:
- Sales environment is tuff but rewarding
- Can be bureaucratic and political but what large company isn't.

review_title: Good Company
job_title: Senior QA Engineer in Reston, VA
pros: There's a new project to work on every three months, so things move at a fast pace. Good in a way because you don't tend to get bored working on the same thing. And there's always lots to learn. People in general are nice to work with and the company has reasonably flexible hours. You are allowed to work from home occasionally and there's no dress code. Situated in Reston just minutes away from Wiehle station and very close to the future metro stop. The company has a lot going for it.
cons: Pay is relatively less compared to the market and they don't have great benefits in terms on bonus and company shares.

review_title: The opportunity is endless, as long as you start outside of Market Development
job_title: Market Development Representative in Bellevue, WA
pros:
-Concur has unlimited opportunities for career growth (once out of Market dev.)
-The people you work with are fun, friendly, and you will want to hang out out with them outside of work
-The product is amazing, and if you are able to get to a point in the company that you get to sell the product and not a meeting, it really is a value-added service
-Great Benefits
cons:
The  Market Development team has gone through a roller coaster of management in the past 2-3 years. The current regime has caused a severe downturn in morale, productivity, and trust in the process, and unfortunately Concur as a whole.

The rest of the managers have a lot of potential, but are forced to abide by upper management's leadership style. The major issue that I ran into was that I constantly was being talked to like a child rather than a working professional. An awesome pro of working for Concur was their benefits including 25 days PTO, however if you take a vacation, and do not hit your goal (which is astronomically high, while only increasing) you will be chastised. In fact, some were asked "do you really think you should take that PTO over Christmas with how your month is going?" 

The job itself is difficult enough, cold calling is difficult enough. The job of leadership is to be selfless, to be a part of the grind, and to MOTIVATE people, rather than showing up late, leaving early, taking constant PTO, but then belittling their employees when they want the same (or similar) freedoms.

You will also need to be in seat for a minimum of 1 year, while attaining the high quota consistently to be eligible for a promotion. Elsewhere in the organization it is based on merit and production for a promotion, however in Market Dev the leadership (primarily directors) were more worried about hitting their own numbers, and how much you can help pad their pockets than your career development. They will do whatever they can to keep the  top performers on their team to help themselves, rather than helping you progress in your career within Concur.

One final con: At Concur, and now SAP Concur you are a part of an incredible organization that strives to change businesses and lives of their employees as well as yours as an employee of SAP Concur. In Market Development, you are told NOT to attend the all hands meetings, the team celebration lunches, etc. because that time is better suited with you on the phone. This completely secludes the MDR teams from the bigger picture, and thus makes you feel like nothing but a number

review_title: Consulting is not same as SAP LABS
job_title: SAP EIM MDG Solution Consultant in Bangalore
pros: Flexibility to work from home. However this is a double edged sword wherein the client expects your availability at odd working hours with no appreciation or backing from managers to stand up for employee's work-life balance.
cons:
Rewards and recognition is based on certain predispositions by the manager. It could vary from background or how well the rapport built with the managers.
Managers could be very partial in the consulting side of SAP. Making the quality of work second priority.

review_title: SDE
pros: Great work life balance. Acquisition of Concur by SAP, actually helped the company to look into their tech debt. The company is investing on the technical debt.
cons:
If you have worked for the company for little longer, there is view that you are not ready for new challenges.. your ideas are stale.  You have to be on the good side of the Directors in R&D. You cant challenge them and cant disagree with them. I wish Upper management talk to team other than Directors to get the view of the department.

 I have seen people quit the company and join back, to get a Hike, promotion and to get to work on new technology.  They are forced to do it. I wish they give training and enough challenge to employees who love Concur and love work life balance.

review_title: Very diverse place to work
job_title: Sales Operations in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great benefits and pay, which is pretty standard in Tech.  What I love most is the diversity - young and old, differently abled, many religions, different colors, accents, LGBTQ...pretty much any kind of diversity you can think of, you will see it, experience it, live it, celebrate it at SAP.  Another big plus is the flexibility.  Many people work remotely and bosses typically seem to be respectful of family and other commitments.
cons: Very large company, so things often don't move quickly, and sometimes hard to figure out who the right person is to help solve your problem.  Can be political, but for me personally, it's more what I've heard, and not what I've experienced personally.

review_title: Great colleagues, Great opportunities, Great benefits.
pros:
I have been at SAP Ireland for many years and really enjoy coming to work. The work itself can be challenging but there is a great atmosphere around the office and it is reassuring to have colleagues  (local & virtual) that you can rely on for help.
If you are driven to succeed there are a lot of opportunities locally & globally with SAP.
cons: Globally, like any large multinational with 90,000+ employees, there can be some politics between different areas of the company. While this is not something you find locally in Ireland there can be trickle-down effects from global organization.

review_title: Executive Assistant
pros: flexibility around working hours, working from home; free 3 course lunch everyday with focus on health - amazing benefit; GPTW; healtcare, pension, bike to work scheme, lots of opportunities to meet new colleagues and friends; sports and social club; opportunity to give back to the community with one day allocated to charitable causes per year - loads more available on top of that. very green - environmentally focused, how we can make the world a better place. lovely management who listen to employee feedback and implement changes to show they have heard and want to continuously improve our workplace. by far the best IT company to work for in Galway.
cons: traffic on the days you work in the office!

review_title: mixed bag
job_title: Support Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
I was paid well.
Being acquired was life changing.
SAP knows how to throw a company party.  Good, clean fun.
Benefits were good.
The CEO was warm and personable.
I could work from home so I could go to routine medical appointments.
cons:
Customers use tools that slice and dice and act real nice while employees use junk that crashes and can't talk to other junk that goes clunk.
3 of the 4 worst managers in my career have worked for SAP and I worked under them.
HR doesn't have a backbone even after a department investigation with glaring evidence.
Processes are so choking that you literally fight to get your job done.
Customers are always right even though they can be dead wrong.
Managers can team up with customers and it can be the customer and your manager vs you.
Medical got a little expensive.

review_title: Nice people but strategy needs work
pros: The work environment was very good. Employees are respectful of one another. SAP does everything first class in terms of their conferences and events. Certainly the benefits are top of the line and their internal help desks are very responsive.
cons: Constantly changing strategy with no ryhme or reason. I had 3 Vice Presidents during a 10 month period because people were getting fired or relocated. Many of the internal resources are outdated and worthless such as their internal CRM system being used by sales people. It's siimply horrible. The sales lists provided internally for prospecting are all outdated and causes a ton of corrections and unecessary administration.

review_title: Great place to work, but...
pros: Salary and benefits are top notch.  Flexible work arrangement and abilitiy to work remotely are exemplary.  Constantly changing competitive environment offer new challenges every day and make the job interesting and exciting.
cons: Recent cost cutting measures make it challenging to keep up with the increased job demands and fewer resources to meet them.  Too much emphasis on promoting based on sex or race, with little regard for the managerial or even technical skills of some of the fast track "stars"

review_title: has some work to do
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newtown Square, PA
pros: Good/cheap cafeteria, decent gym, incredibly beautiful office, fantastic provided laptops and phones, relaxed environment, good healthcare, 401k matching, work from home can be flexible by position.
cons: Very little onboarding or training in general, a strong push for training via online resources but no provided time to do so, we are the first to use our own products so of course various systems are broken regularly and the average employee needs to juggle chrome/IE/firefox to access different things.

review_title: Customer Facing Sales VP
pros:
- Quality people committed to delivering success (despite many self-imposed constraints)
- Market leadership and brand recognition
- Strong partner ecosystem (waiting for a wave of ERP upgrades with S/4HANA)
cons:
- Customer aggravation with too many product focused go-to-market resources 
- Management focus on quarterly results vs. long term customer success / satisfaction
- Inability to innovate organically (also responsible for inflated valuation of acquisitions) 
- Contemporary HR processes that prevent the most qualified leaders from rising to the top

review_title: Product Owner
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Cambridge, MA
pros: Interesting work topics and challenges.   Colleagues are qualified and experienced in their roles.   Strong desire to do the right thing for customers, the environment, with good cross team cooperation.   Benefits and pay are good.  Yearly bonuses have been paid out with consistent regularity
cons: Opportunities for growth are limited especially in offices outside corporate or national headquarters.   Frequent travel restrictions don't permit travel to work with remote groups within your direct job influence.

review_title: S4 Functional Specialist - CoE
job_title: SAP Functional Consultant in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
Outlook. Right now is the best time to be working for SAP, the company is growing and there are opportunities for all of you have the drive to go for it.

Benefits. Benefits are really good, in Dublin you have free lunch, pension is good, options on stock. 

Growth. Training is good, you start by learning a huge amount about SAP services and how to deliver and then you have almost unlimited access to information to learn.
cons: I don’t really have anything that could be seen as a real “con” but maybe for those who do progress the workload can be high and the need to find a balance is definitely something you will need to discuss with your manager.

review_title: Nice place to be but irrelevant knowledge it you leave the company
pros: It's a nice place where things are mostly chill, cool colleagues, they pay you good enough and the benefits are also nice. Once you get in it's hard to be kicked out, if you find yourself having problems on your carrier path they sit down with you and try to find a solution for it.
cons:
The challenges vary from project to project. Some of them are fairly boring.

The tools you have to use are sometimes ridiculously unusable.

As SAP uses their own technology for everything (they have their own database technology, programming language, javascript framework ...) once you want to switch to some other company you will find that you have to learn everything from scratch and the years of experience you gained so far won't really matter anymore.

review_title: Great Workplace, Great Values but..
pros:
For me as student I have the chance to visit different teams that work on different  subjects.
Atmosphere is in generally good.
Alot of chances and things to learn.
Alot of people to learn from.
cons:
In Consulting field  it could be stressful, and there is alot of extra work but this is part of the job.
Lack of encouraging at least in my case.

review_title: Flexibility and Growth
pros:
Flexible working locations - I do 100% remote work, but there are offices that I can go to when I need some people energy. Access to any SAP offices worldwide. 

Flexible working hours - many people work 4 days a week or on alternative working time. This can be arranged depending on the nature of your work and your team.

Investment on people - SAP invests A LOT on people's wellbeing and growth. The company culture supports helping each other as well. I've been benefiting from shadowing and mentoring of amazing people around the world. 

Good benefits, free lunch and free gym.
cons:
The main London office is far from central London - hence the remote work flexibility!

Large company - bureaucracy and silo can happen.

review_title: Principal consultant
job_title: Principal Consultant in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Great access to all training and learning material
Great network of consultants and product developers
Good competitive benefits. Very good insurance and 401k match
Global company and great number of opportunities to work globally
Clients respect and listen as you are SAP
cons:
Delivery executives and project managers can be tough to deal with and are not the best people on earth

Thick skin people in the organization never respond and don’t care to reach back to you

Too many silos in the organization where one arm doesn’t know what the other arm does. 
Lack of diversity at top

review_title: Pretty nice place to work
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in São Leopoldo, Rio Grande do Sul
pros:
- Fair wage
- Nice benefits
- Nice building
- Picks me up at home with SAP Bus
- Allows home office
- I can have a long career with a solid plan to be growing
- Solid company where you can have an stable job without worry being fired out of nowhere
cons:
- Hard to change mindset when things clearly does not work
- Bureaucracy for some things that should be simple

review_title: A great company that has lost its way over the years
pros:
- Market leader
- Focus on people and processes
- Very smart people, committed
- Core products are of top quality, providing real value to customers
cons:
- No longer as good with career growth - management has programs for talented employees but its all talk and no action.
- No clarity of vision from management
- Focus has been on sales and margins rather than product quality, retaining top talent and good processes
- Local/regional top management is pathetic, more keen on empty talk rather than making any "real" changes and improving the work-life balance for employees.

review_title: Great Place to work.. Good brand
job_title: Applications Consultant IV in Newtown Square, PA
pros:
-Great place to work
-Learnt a lot
-Enjoyed the brand recognition
-Chance to work with one of the smartest brains. Atleast in IT
-Good bonus
-Emphasis on training
cons:
-Consulting sales is pretty bad.. Not impressive at all. Being a consultant, it bothers me a lot because consulting team at SAP is one of the best anyone could ever find. 
-Lot of travelling
-Every other person is from Ivy League school. So, my Ivy degree didnt help me much.. Had to work real hard for recognitiion.
-Expectations are high from consultants. So, where consultants from other companies sit back and relax, we have to struggle a lot. Maybe due to our $300/hr billing rate.. 
-Its not what it used to be..

review_title: Awesome company for a lazy non-passionate person
pros: free food,company car,salary,flexi-timing,gym,lot of leaves,no problems in coming late and going early,u can chit chat for 4 hours in coffee corner without feeling bad as there would many along with you.
cons: no promotions,change of responsibilities too often,too many re-orgs and structural changes,team shifts,the reason provided for most of the re-orgs is that we have been asked to implement this change we ourselves dont know the reason.

review_title: Stable large company that is a good place to work with multiple personalities
pros: Good pay and benefits. Has lots of long term employees. Provides lots of learning opportunities (depending on your organizational unit). Encourages employee harmony. Hard work is usually noticed.
cons: Encourages people to network which is nice but this also can mean that you won't be heard unless you are part of the old boy clique in that group. Work life balance can either be great or awful depending on which group you are in. Not innovative enough.

review_title: Labs India does not seem to be on the right track
pros:
Free food, free transport, free soft drink etc. free stuff that employees like although they cost really nothing
New technologies are coming up so lots of opportunities to learn new things
cons:
Fresher and 5 years experienced top performer do not have very much difference in salary
Sometimes you can get a bad manager and no one does anything about it, you suffer or you quit
In general work life balance is good, past 2013 year it has been bad for me
Lots of politics in Performance reviews

review_title: Moving to the Cloud in India
pros: Learn a lot supporting multiple SAP products in the cloud.  Good networking and training opportunities. If you love to travel this is where you want to be in consulting.
cons: As of right now SAP is laying off most of their North American (US based) CTC employees in favor of cheaper less experienced Cloud Consultants in India.  They can hire 10 employees in India to 1 in North America.

review_title: Best job I've ever had
job_title: Software Engineer (UI Developer) in Reston, VA
pros:
- We do get free lunches - two per week.
- We do have unlimited PTO, and the culture is great about letting you use it. 
- Very flexible work schedule. 
- Good benefits. Above average 401k match, excellent healthcare options.
- Nice perks- free drinks and snacks, free gym in the building.
- Casual dress code.
- Company is committed to improving the UI, and it's beginning to show solid results.
- Scrums are quick and to the point.
- Sympathetic attitude attitude toward teleworking and work life balance.
- Attractive, naturally lit office with floor to ceiling windows. Makes a difference for those seasonal affective disorder.
cons:
- Crunch time can be stressful. Welcome to software development.
- Open office. I don't mind it much though, as it's fairly quiet.
- No other major cons.

review_title: Avoid SMN Marketing
pros: Working for Concur was great until leadership change this year in SMN Marketing. I would recommend working for Concur and other marketing teams just not that group.
cons: A recent Leadership change has caused a mass exit of marketers on this team. MQL targets that were unreasonable and lacking ability to track due to broken systems were all that mattered even if burned the team out and poor customer experience. We worked crazy hours and constantly blamed and bullied in team settings. Unless you are on the Dream Team brought in externally expectation was to keep your mouth shut and do what are told. This was not the Concur I knew, we always supported each other, valued advice and input.

review_title: SAP Fieldglass, APJ
pros: SAP Culture is great, lots of support, resources, opportunity to learn and grow.  Flexible workplace with global reach and diversity.
cons: SAP Fieldglass Specifically. Toxic culture within Fieldglass APJ.  Poor deicions making skills, insecure leaderhsip team, unskilled leadership team, biased cliques within decisions, promotions and opportunities.   ZERO opportunity for promotion or career advancement if you have integrity.

review_title: Awesome Place to Work
job_title: Support Engineer in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul
