pros: Flexible working hours; Shuttle to the company and back home; goods like fruits and snacks(cookies) available on every micro kitchen at the office; Gaming area; Good Parking lot; work-life balance; Achievable career path; Outstanding compensation package compared to other companies in Brazil; Work environment is great; Facilities are even better than most companies around the world; Trust on my direct management; Work from home as per agreement with your team/management;
cons: Given the size of the company and teams, it is not that easy to get a substantial raise other than changing your position/role; Your starting salary counts a lot in the future, since the budget is by team, and everyone working on the company are very good on what they do, so it is not that easy to stand out from the crowd;

review_title: Great Leader and vision at the top  /  some issues at the bottom (Chilean subsidiary)
pros: A great company with an amazing purpose, mission and vision, good perks, benefits and salary, many good people (some pretty bad persons)
cons:
Without being the best company for perks, benefits and salary it is a standard multinational level company in that terms which is good (not the best as some at the company would say or believe). 
The problems at this South Latin American subsidiary relies on a highly politicized environment which is almost like Game of Thrones in which you have to navigate and waste time to please bad intended people just because they have "friends" at higher positions.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work...not anymore
job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Dublin, Dublin
pros: free lunch, fuel card, working from home
cons:
- the pay structure makes it impossible to go for a mortgage. Base pay is not that great and shift pay is not guaranteed so is not included in the calculation. The day that SAP decides to take away shift payments will be a day of great exodus form the company.
- small pay increases which nearly meet the inflation rate...but as we are told by management SAP is in the middle of the pack when it comes to pay.
- entertainment budget introduced this year for a company of this size is a joke. The yearly budget per team lasted only for one team night out (meal + 1 drink)...seriously SAP you cannot do better?!?!?!!

review_title: Great job to get to know life at SAP
pros: Strong commitment to engage with local and worldwide communities to help with the UN sustainability goals. Real culture of respect and celebration of our differences. Great prospects for learning in various settings and platforms. You'll meet a lot of inspirational leaders with a drive to mentor you and listen to your feedback. Very good maternity and parental leave policy. Flexible work and work from home options.
cons: A lot of acronyms to learn! A lot of platforms and systems to learn! Can be difficult to move up, and some areas could use better tiering to recognise senior team members with a title and the matching pay bracket.

review_title: Good company, but have a short term outlook.
pros: Even though a victim of the economic downturn, I have no general ill will towards SAP.  This was a good company to work for.  There was allot of energy and they take care of their employees.  Benefits are very good, including a very reasonable severance.  Decisions may be short sighted, as with most publicly held companies these days, but they do tend to take care of their people.
cons: I question the long term viability of targeting many of  their most senior sales engineers for staff reduction.   They have mandated that allot of intellectual property walk out the door.  It will likely prove costly in the long run.

review_title: Not a good place to start your career.
job_title: Senior Support Engineer in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Fuel card and free food, but these are highlighted when trying to get a pay rise. The flexi time is hand, but most companies seem to have flexi time now.
cons: The salaries are very poor and the pay increases are only ever about 1-2%. The pension is shocking, they contributed 2%. It's a very lazy environment, perfect for someone with no ambition. Some people seem to have no work what so ever because they spend most of their time in the canteen. Most roles will lead to you been pigeonholed as they're isn't a demand for the roles in other companies. The location isn't great and parking is limited. They have travel freezes all the time to save money and training is done over the phone from india/Germany.

review_title: Director of sales
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great benefits, training. Free lunch with healthy food. The quotas are completely out of touch with reality of the pipeline. People take credit for deals they they didn't have anything to do anything with.
cons: Internal systems are really slow and cumbersome. There are a lot of people who seem to do nothing and still work there forever. Very sexist culture. If you are a woman, be prepared to be treated like a second class citizen

review_title: Solid, profitable company

review_title: One of the best places to work and grow professionally

review_title: ...You WILL be ground down eventually...
pros:
- Free Dinner
- Decent benefits (although most companies offer the same or better)
- Good people, with some great talent
- Opportunity/Requirement of Travel
- Flexi-time available (depending on assigned work)

To be honest, this is a good place to start your working life (graduate), perfect for an intern. SAP is a big name after all. It's easy at the beginning, and you'll gain good experience desirable in any job - soft skills as well as technical. You can see this reading the 5 star reviews of anyone that has worked here in Dublin for 'less than a year'.

It's important that there is an exit plan though, because you WILL be ground down eventually, becoming a transparent shell of the person that you used to be, sitting in an office at 11pm on a Friday night, reminiscing with a sad smile on good times with people you used to know.
cons:
I can only speak of the COE in Dublin, I do not want to paint every department in every country with the same brush.
This in mind, here it goes.

- Base salary is woeful. We are cheap labour, but 'flexible'. So hire where it's cheap, and send you off to do the same job elsewhere, for a fraction of the cost... In fairness, well spotted.
- Yearly increases may allow you to treat yourself to a slightly more expensive take-away (at 11.45pm, on a Friday night, on your own in the house (if you can afford a house)).
- Enough has been said about work-life balance, and steps are being actively taken to make it worse. The phrase 'Things can only get better' has been proven wrong on so many occasions, I simply expect the worst.
- Last minute travel requests, to places that do not appear on any 'Top 10,000 places to visit before you die' lists, on any website.
- Blatant lies, impossible promises.
- Unqualified and out of touch Middle Management... It's a mess. You are a number, on an Excel sheet, that someone will look at and say, 'Which number will we put in this place next week?... Actually, who cares?' This is no longer about ability (I assume it may have been once, many Springs ago...)
- 'More Graduates... We need more graduates!!' You'd need a plane to get over that knowledge gap...
- No training... 'Learn on the job'... Nonsense, it's embarrassing and unprofessional...
- The travel. You will see many lovely offices. Big offices, small offices, offices on the 13th floor, offices in the basement.

review_title: IBU Exec
job_title: Vice President IBU Vertical in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Solid corp that pays well and does cares about their people.  SAP has grown very fast and no longer produces the old SAP only software and services.  Also strong teams of smart people
cons: It is one big shop and very focused on many industries.  This leads to issues that relate to the corporate direction and comms conflicting with the specific vertical market's issues.  Takes lots to balance this out by region

review_title: Excellent fit for entrepreneurial, independent spirits
pros:
I've worked in multiple roles over a decade in different locations - it's amazing to be able to have a widely varied career while staying in the same company... best of both worlds. Incredibly collaborative, open culture where knowledge-sharing is the default. 

E.g., I have often used keywords to pick someone's name out of the corporate address book (when I need an expert, but don't know anyone to ask), and emailed or called them and say "I am looking for someone to help with x", and not once has anyone said "not my job" - every single time, and I'm talking dozens of times - the person helped me directly or gave me an introduction. 

You can move around and do different jobs within the company based on your interest and career growth plan - you can even change careers completely, if you want. One friend went from product management, where he was a functional expert on a topic working with the Sales team, to being a consultant and traveling to work with customers on-site. I personally changed from pre-sales to product management to marketing over the course of my career - and was totally supported by every manager in my chain to make those changes. That's incredibly rare.

The corporate culture is the best thing about the company. Sure, there are challenges - but every company has challenges, there's no perfect work, and no job is always fun, or simple. But compared to other companies I've interviewed with, and have friends working for, SAP is not only highly ethical and personally collaborative, it's a breath of humanistic fresh air compared to most American companies in the same industry, from supporting remote work as a default for most roles, to providing competitive benefits with better-than-average vacation. 

Additional pro, depending on your role (with manager approval) you can work remotely from other SAP offices or locations. For example, if you want to visit someone in another state, as long as you have your laptop you can work from their house during the day, and have the evenings free to spend with them. Or if I take vacation to the South of France for a week, I could extend the trip by 3 days and enjoy a second weekend traveling around, and  work several days from our office in Nice, and then fly home mid-week when the rates are cheaper. And when you have more vacation days to use, it's an amazing way to extend your vacation options, which for Americans in particular is in too short supply most of the time.
cons:
1. This isn't a traditional 'con' - it's about being aware that the culture isn't a fit for everyone. If you like a high level of engagement with your manager and being given exact directions on what is expected of you, this is not likely the place for you *unless* you're seeking a Quality Management/Quality Assurance/Testing/Tech Support type role. SAP is what I call an "entrepreneurial" company, that gives employees a lot of latitude in how to shape their job and how to define their career path. I love it, and I've had the chance to try a lot of different roles in my time here - but I have also seen wonderful, talented, intelligent people become exceedingly frustrated. E.g., I may have a short biweekly call with my manager (who is remote), and find that sufficient for discussing my projects, but some people may feel the need to speak with their manager multiple times per week with their manager to get direction on certain problems, or talk through ideas they have. Many managers aren't used to that type of 'constant feedback loop' of engagemnet - so I think it's important to understand if you come to SAP, you're going to be trusted to make a lot of decisions on your own, and you're going to be expected by most managers to be able to do that. I've heard people complain that when they asked a manager "What should i do?" the manager's response was "What do you *think* you should do?" If that bothers you, then you may not find SAP the best fit for your preference in management style, OR you should ensure when you interview, that you discuss your preference and expectations for the level of engagment from your manager. SAP wants people to be happy, but employees also have to be self-aware to understand the corporate culture, in general, and decide if it's a fit.

2. Constant, continual organizational change. Sometimes every 6 months, at least once per year. Change is common at all large businesses, but it does seem SAP moves the puzzle pieces around more often than peers.

3. One of the clearest areas that we see the origins of SAP as a German company founded by engineers is the number of templates - powerpoing and spreadsheets - that are created, maintained, and mandated for people to use. You may find processes are 'over-engineered' compared to other companies, and that can be frustrating... but it's improving, and if filling out a spreadsheet is the worst thing you can say about your job, it's really not bad at all!

review_title: Don't be fooled by the positive reviews

Pretty decent benefits package.
Office environment.
Mostly friendly employees.
cons:

They would micro-manage people, watch how your sit in meetings, take note of every little thing that they never used to do.  In other words, they have essentially become some annoying smart@ss managers.

review_title: Why I love SAP
job_title: Global Marketing Director in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The people I have had the pleasure of working with for the last six years. SAP colleagues are welcoming, collaborative and always come together for the common good of SAP and SAP's customers.
cons: SAP is transforming to meet the needs of its customers and this causes a lot of change that can upset people that have been in the company for a while as change is always challenging.

review_title: Not the great SAP where I was hired years ago, but still good company to work.
job_title: Senior Technical Support Engineer in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul
pros:
- The entry level salary is still good compared to the market

- The work-life balance is nice.
cons:
- Every week something new happen to force us toward efficiency and more work load is added,  some of those new things are not what we were hired to do in the first place. 

- There is no well established career plan, everything is subjetive.

review_title: Good place to work - but company loyalty is not highly rewarded
pros: Great reputation in the software world - de facto standard for ERP.  Comp is competitive but not great- unless you leave and come back.
cons: HR puts up road blocks and does not reward loyalty with higher pay or opportunities.  There is some degree of empire-building with ex-Siebel and ex-Oracle etc. people coming into higher level positions and immediately promoting their brethren hired in 2 weeks later.  Also some short-sightedness in my opinion on quarterly results for license sales.

review_title: A relatively steady ship in a sea of economic uncertainty...
pros: Highly professional organization with a solid well-respected industry reputation. Very flexible results oriented work environment with right mix of work/life balance. Compensation is on the high-end of normal compared with previous employers. Politics plays a much lower role in perceived performance than results, especially when compared to other companies in the same field.
cons: Culture is a mixed blessing -- everyone has a say and an opinion which often leads to indecision or "group think" mentality.  Risk takers are rewarded and/or chastised depending on the situation and group.

review_title: Location, location, location.
pros:
The company definitely makes an impact and is full of opportunities to learn and grow with but ... for that you have to move to California where its headquarter is. Field offices (at least Cambridge one) offer limited space to grow - you hit glass ceiling very quickly.
Cambridge, MA office offers free public transport pass, lunches (fairly good), reasonably large work space. Employees are respected by the management. The company offers tuition support for some courses.
cons: As mentioned above Cambridge, MA field office is not a place to put your professional career on a fast track.

review_title: It really depends what division you are in.
pros: Respectful of employees, very flexible with personal schedules and issues, good compensation and benefits, nice perks like subsidized lunches, good systems for finding and retrieving information
cons: Some of the internal IT systems are a bit antiquated.  It is also miserable dealing with expense reports, something to keep in mind if you are going to travel.  Also, the team you are on is really the key indicator of how satisfying your job will be.  Everyone clamors to be on the latest, cool project.  If you aren't "in" with the folks in Palo Alto, you will have a hard time getting noticed and promoted.

review_title: Good place to work, some things should evolve
pros:
From a Consulting perspective:
Lots of information on new products.
Access to developers, and development document, meaning possibility to get depth knowledge of new products.
Work-life balance is easier to find than in other consulting companies in Spain.
Benefits are better than average spanish companies.
International work environment.
Possibility to change dept and/or country are common.
cons:
From a Consulting perspective:
The main focus of SAP is sales. Therefore SAP consulting is sometimes left aside in terms of attention, development, etc.
Some contracts won by SAP are automatically transfered to partners due to the previous mentioned point and also to the high tariffs that SAP charges (out of market).

review_title: Join to enjoy life, not work
pros: very good work life balance; work doesn't keep you very busy so good place if you want to pursue any external interests, hobbies, goals.; good brand value for CV.
cons: Tendency to get locked in comfort zone too easily; un-challenging work many times; bureaucratic decision making; difficult for career growth due to size of organisation; usually get to work on a very tiny piece of project due to atomic division of work among too many team members; salary disproportionate to the brand value; no on-site projects/visits; too many re-orgs; less importance to empoyee's career growth.

review_title: More than 2 years as a developer
pros:
The human aspect: something easily forgotten in tech companies, is one of the major drivers inside SAP. Not just inside the organization, but also giving back to the community, many incentives for volunteer work and donation campaigns to the benefit of children in need.
A solid career opportunity, which values the employee and allows him to grow in his area of choice.
cons:
Too easy to stagnate and keep on doing the same work over and over if you don't have the discipline required to grow and are afraid of trying to move to a different line of business.
The internal marketing sometimes conflicts with the corporate climate perceived by the employees.

review_title: Great company if you look for stability
job_title: Solution Developer in São Leopoldo, Rio Grande do Sul
pros: Very good work environment, flexibility on vacations, work-life balance, good compensation and bonus plan, felxible working time, solid company

Several times, the managers do not seem to have a solid and consistent evaluation of your job, and instead they rely on the feedback of colleagues(feels like they repeat feedback provided by others). In some situations, i felt like the manager tries to explore more of my weak points than the points i am good at.

review_title: Good products, great clients and talented employees.
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Boston, MA
pros: Demand for the company's cloud product mix is very high, with strong pipe. Good place to gain front line exposure within the (B2B) cloud software space on a global scale.  Flexible work from home policy. Very seasoned and skilled sales professionals throughout the org. Great place to gain large scale, enterprise deal making experience.
cons: Time consuming internal processes that can slow down deal cycles. Too much emphasis on cumbersome and redundant sales forecast reporting. With the exception of a few managers, leadership is non-existent.

review_title: Former Employee in IT Dept
pros: Work from home on occasion on a flexible schedule and basis, some flexibility in terms of which hours to work during the day/night.  There is not really much else to say here besides that.
cons: Work life balance does not exist at all.  You are able to work from home because that is what will be necessary for you to get the help you need or to continue finishing up work given.  Minimal training and learn as you go sort of deal.

review_title: Awesome Company
pros: There are so many events and clubs around, SAP really creates a community for interns and full time employees. Flexible hours, work from home options, lunch on us program.
cons: It's a great company. I can only speak for myself, but there isn't much I would change! I would like to see the roles and access requests be a bit smoother/easier.

review_title: Mixed messages?

EDUCATION AND QUALIFICATIONS / SKILLS AND COMPETENCIES
•	Recent graduate of an accredited university with a Bachelors or Master’s degree in a relevant STEM field including: Information Systems, Engineering, Computer Science or other relevant degree.
WORK EXPERIENCE
6 months to 3 years of relevant work experience in a corporate environment through internships or recent work experience.

Message: only 20-somethings need apply.

review_title: Comfortable + growth opportunities + good compensation
pros:
- Flex hours (I work 7-3 most days)
- Best tools for the stuff we work on
- Challenging work
- Good management
- Reasonable expectations
- Friendly people
- Competitive compensation
cons:
- Politics slow down movement
- Lots of tiered management
- They send people managers to technical conferences and training courses with the intent that they return and teach the technical staff which rarely works well.
- Just a job to most developers (this isn't necessarily a bad thing for most, I'm a passionate person who thinks about the stuff we are building all the time find it a bit demotivating when none of my colleagues want to talk about it)

review_title: NOT a nice place to work
pros: Food Free.  Some very bright people if empowered to make decisions and expand their role.
cons: Inexperienced Management Team, more focused on time keeping, petty unimportant tools and creating an environment engrossed in  suspicion than allowing the individual to grow and develop. People not empowered nor encouraged to use initiative and grow the business.  More focused on internal management hierarchy than the all important Customer. Mostly interns in customer facing roles with no experience of proper customer services, buckle at the sight of an escalated customer issue.  Level of scrutiny similar to a high school environment.  I have seen people put in loads of personal time, travelling on business on their own time(Sat and Sun) yet reprimanded for leaving 5 minutes early form work!

review_title: Silicon Valley Next Talent Program
job_title: Software Developer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great program that lets new grads find out their true passion in technology. With a CS degree, you can explore in dev, QA, design and PM roles. One year, four rotations. Best benefit is meeting so many people in different teams, work/life balance, and trip to Germany. Highly recommended even if salary is not as good as FB or Google in Silicon Valley. Moreover, there are lots of training resources available for you in between rotations.
cons: There is always a chance that a team you like doesn't have headcounts due to organizational changes, even if they say they have headcounts, because they need your free work in their teams.

review_title: A people centered company with excellent career support
pros:
SAP is an amazing company with a fantastic culture that's highly supportive and where everybody has a common goal of doing innovative work. There's a lot of flexibility for different working arrangements around family or other personal commitments - it's a very people-centered company, and in a very genuine way, with the right support, investment and structures to enable these different arrangements. There's also plenty of well supported opportunities to work in different roles and geographies.

Everyone is focused on delivering high quality work and you should be prepared to be held highly accountable for that level of quality and impact but this work is highly rewarding.
cons: Like any big company you can expect to deal with some complexity and should be prepared  to navigate this!

review_title: Pay, growth, and performance rating are serious issues.
pros:
WLB.
Sick days.
Talent pool.
great people/colleagues. non toxic work env. good infra and facilities. free food/shuttles.
cons:
Pay, growth, and performance rating are serious issues. No growth ops due to global culture. You are very often moved from one proj to another - doesnt help at all.  No focus. End up working with architects with more exp on the product and suddenly become jr. most despite immense work exp!
Mgr is solely resp for appraisals. no ratings anymore.
pay is not at par with market std. very low and mgmt refuses to offer hike despite performance quoting budget issues. 6-8% annual. horrible. no points for loyalty.

review_title: Best Company to work for in the IT-branch
job_title: Associate Software Engineer in St. Ingbert

* Interesting projects to work on

review_title: SAP Labs Pune used to be a good place

review_title: A good employer who could be the best employer

review_title: Still bureaucratic but highly educated engineering culture now becoming more customer focused and commercial

review_title: This company's culture and people are great.

review_title: A pleasant rollercoaster if you can handle that. In summary, I like challenges.
job_title: Product Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Board vision and strategy, passion of its employees for the Company and its products, SAP technology and products, good salary and benefits, encouragement for education and training, important knowledge base, home office,

Company is very flexible, especially when it comes to improving things which do not properly work (software, processes, etc.). review_title: Run don’t Walk
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newport Coast, CA
pros: It has been a good place to work and SAP Global Leaders aspire to instilling goals supporting and rewarding employees.

In their quest to make the annual goal managers have become shells of their former selves. A lot more best  left unsaid.

review_title: Account Executive
pros: Good company with a lot of resources to draw on, unfortunately it is so disorganised it will take forever to understand what is available to you. Salary and benefits are generally quite good.
cons: Massively complex company that over complicates things. The company is too centralised with strategy direction decided in isolation either in Germany or the US that do not always work in the local market. Pricing is a big issue, competitors are eating us up.

review_title: Challenging tasks ask for a diverse workforce
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Malibu, CA
pros: Global company, with lots of opportunities in very different areas, be it in Finance, R&D, Sales, Marketing or Service. And basically all job profiles you can imagine are needed: teachers for our learning solutions, medical doctors in the Healthcare Industry unit,  farmers for our agriculture engagement etc.
cons: If you are not able to establish a good network or don't have a mentor it's sometimes hard to advance your career in the often times fast spinnig software industry.

review_title: Best leadership
pros: SAP is a true investor in people. Career development and support is highly regarded and opportunities are regularly offered to those employees that have the right skill sets and great work ethic.  Attractive perks and employee offerings are probably one of the best in the industry and these continue to be updated to increase available options for employees.  The canteen and Nespresso coffee machines are my favourite office perks.
cons: Honestly cannot find any at the moment.  It used to be remote working for me but that was due to the nature of my previous role.  Now I am in a delivery very role with ample time to work remotely.

review_title: I do not take working for Hasso, Jim and Bill as a job but as a privilege ...
pros: Open atmosphere and team spirit in combination with the respect to customers and even competitors. I always have a feeling that we do not need to beat our competitors we would rather learn from our mistakes and improve. Accusation is not in SAP culture. I am glad it is not ...
cons: Faster innovation of products is reached but it must be followed by innovation of services. The work started but it is still long way to go ... World is faster we should not hunt the progress we should be hunted.

review_title: An amazing learning curve in a new profession
job_title: Technical Writer in El Segundo, CA
pros:
A stable company which - more or less - respects its employees. We produce good software, I truly believe it, I saw it at customers in my previous job.
Work-life balance can be realized here.
I highly appreciate the corporate culture.
cons:
A real giant, which transforms slowly. Not easy to get an approval (thanks God not everything needs approval).
Too many turnbacks in strategy; constant reorganizations.

review_title: La Crosse Office Needs Lots of Work
job_title: Software Engineer in San Antonio, TX
pros:
The company itself does a lot for it's employees, but each office is different with some being better than others. In La Crosse, the engineering managers are non-technical and have little management training, so they're difficult to work with. Other offices I have worked with seem to have better leaders, so if you're looking to work in another office, ignore this review.
Being a global company, there are opportunities to travel and/or work with people in other countries. Also, there are opportunities to relocate and for personal advancement.
cons:
- Management.
- Being a global company can mean trying to work with people in different time zones. If you don't mind working non-typical hours, this isn't bad.
- Career opportunities limited in La Crosse
- No work/life balance

review_title: Gives me nightmares everynight. I have not worked there for 3 years.
job_title: EUS Technician III in Palo Alto, CA
pros: All of the workers are very nice people. Work life balance is good. Free soda's and fruit.
cons: Management not qualified. Must be with managers bff to stay in the circle of trust even though you are married. Say no and lose your job. "WOW".  Want to break up your family. No raise in 3 years. Ask for raise! Get raise! then get terminated. Tell uper management and they do nothing about it. If you want to work here be prepaired to be PIMPED.

review_title: Great company until SAP Bought us.
job_title: Professional Services Consultant in Farmington, CT
pros:
Work From Home flexibilty. Ability to buy Stock Options at a great discount.
SAP Growth is going to be great.
cons:
SAPs purchase of Successfactors has negatively impacted Work/Life balance
-From Unlimited Vacation Days to 16 days a years. High billability requirement  
-From Quarter Bonuses now moved to annual
-Ability to Max Bonuses from 300% now only to 150%
-Health Care Option PPO.. high dedectible or high premium - pick your poisen
-No raises after SAP purchase or no bonus rate hike.
-No team connection - since more than 50% works from home.
-Not sure where the opportunity growth is.

review_title: Frustrating for employees outside of Germany
job_title: Senior Applications Consultant in Reston, VA
pros: Good salary and benefits; well defined employee development programs.  Good products and senior leadership has good vision.
cons:
Hard to move quickly and nimbly in a company that is process oriented and bogged down in controls and approvals.  Most of the approvals are based in Germany, with a perceived reluctance to distribute the controls globally.  Can often result in significant delays in getting the job done, especially when time zones are factored in.  

Work-life balance is talked about as being important, but not many walk the talk.  Recent layoffs, despite healthy financials, have resulted in an increased workload.

review_title: Growth through acquisition not innovation
pros:
Competitive compensation and benefits
Flexible work location and hours
cons:
Poor work / life balance
Significant execution challenges trying to compete against Cloud vendors
High Executive turn over - instability and constant shifts in messaging and direction

review_title: Great ride
pros: Was at SuccessFactors in the early days through 2015 and truly enjoyed it.  Management team responsible for growth was outstanding.  A life changing experience for sure.
cons: There was a huge culture clash between SAP and SuccessFactors.  SAP bought us, so they had the right to operate as they saw fit.  Unfortunately all A+ players left the company.  Comp plans ultimately changed by SAP which was a big driver in the exodus.

review_title: Typical German process shoved down throat; resistance is futile
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: Great benefits - probably some of the most comprehensive in the local Vancouver tech market
cons:
Hard to ever get noticed. Middle and senior management fails at how to grow people and give opportunities to everyone to be great. Top talent is all based on how much you butter up to managers and one up one another. New local VP of development is cutthroat and only ever cares about you if you can crunch out lines of code. 

Local site's mission is working on a product that may barely make a splash. All a bunch of hand waving and it's years late.

review_title: SAP Placement On-Boarding process
job_title: Core Sales Associate in Vancouver, BC
pros: The atmosphere at SAP is welcoming and exciting. The application process consisted of a cover letter and CV screening, a telephone interview with the current intern and manager and then an assessment centre. The communication throughout the process is all from a current intern which is great as you can chat to them about their experiences. The assessment centre consisted of several networking activities such as coffee breaks, breakfast and lunch as well an individual task, a group task, a presentation and an indiviudal  interview. In comparison to other assessment centres I found SAP's to be more welcoming and relaxed due to meeting and chatting to everyone from current interns to sales directors.
cons: Possibly weight gain from a free three course meal everyday (which is delicious) .

review_title: SAP America Inc.
pros: Very relaxed work environment. Most people don't have desks so it's incredibly easy to network without even trying because you have the ability to sit next to new people everyday. I've met executives, interns, professionals and managers just from being able to sit wherever I wanted to sit. You can work from home a lot because all you need is a laptop to get your work done. Everything is done virtually for the most part.
cons: You can sometimes feel lost as a lot of employees' managers don't even live in the same state, and sometimes country, as them. So the first few weeks are about finding your groove and meeting as many people who can help you as possible.

review_title: So many Pro's
pros: Valued as an employee, great benefits, and if you don't end up loving your current job  the opportunities for internal movement and growth are endless. I came to SAP from a horrible previous employee and I was shocked at how great a company and the employees could be.
cons: Different teams and departments struggle with different things. In professional services or consulting (my team) you work long days and travel often. Sometimes the internal processes are time consuming and they do not allow for enough time for you to manage this on top of your customers. Additionally, in professional services, you do not always feel like you are apart of SAP which is unfortunate.

review_title: Great company, people and employer
pros: Great and very friendly people.  Market leading products, with real vision for the future.  Great company prospects.  Genuine interest and focus on employees.  Good benefits, and nice touches including free lunches and good coffee!  Lots of development opportunities and interesting options for future career paths.  Quality offices and working environment and good technology for employees.  Visionary CEO.
cons: There are limited offices that are very focused on Clockhouse and Maidenhead in the UK, it would be good to have some more regional options.  SAP is a process-driven company, so there can be a culture of working within a narrow remit field.

review_title: Market Development Representative
pros:
Concur is an incredible place to start a career if you're interested in sales. The culture is absolutely amazing and the energy on the Market Development floor is incredible. 

I came into the role without much experience in Tech or Sales and leadership is so encouraging to help you learn and grow and coach you along all the way. The atmosphere is very collaborative but competitive as well which keeps it fun. The role gives you a lot of autonomy and lets you manage your territory how you want, as long as your proving results. 

Opportunity for growth is astonishing within Concur and Market Development is considered a large pool of internal promotion candidates. I received two promotions in my first 7 months.
cons: Somewhat high or increasing performance metrics.

review_title: Great infrastructure but horrible management
pros:
- Great infrastructure
- Opportunity to learn
- Pleasant office & location
- Great communities within SAP
cons:
The hierarchy of management is vast and it is virtually impossible to understand who you should contact if you have any concerns. You get lost immediately. 

Quite a few managers have absolutely no clue on what they are actually managing. This results in an horrible environment and often bad decisions. Even though you have to freedom to add new skills to your bucket - it is extremely difficult to deliver something amazing - as other teams are always against innovation and they want to keep doing what they do on daily basis.

review_title: Excellent company to work for
pros: Many innovative projects are in progress. If you have ideas and desire to change, you are encouraged to grow with the company. SAP offers an excellent package of benefits, including stock options, company car, retirement plan, individual educational budget (might be used to participate in conferences of your choice) and many others. The company encourages to maintain good work-family balance, providing vast possibilities for home office and stress-mitigation programs. The employees are provided with state-of-art equipment, can buy books and have access to plenty of educational initiatives.
cons: Teams are often distributed across multiple time zones but travel is restricted, often frozen. This leads to many communication challenges.

review_title: I don't plan to ever leave!
job_title: Vice President Marketing in Denver, CO
pros: Competitive Salary, and benefits. Great flexibility to work from home. Excellent stock purchase plan. In 13 years I've never gotten less than 100% of my bonus. Pretty amazing considering some of the economic downturns weathered since 2006!
cons: We seem to be a very engineering-driven organization, which is he only thing that frustrates me at SAP -- we are not well funded to do our jobs in marketing and are continually asked to do more with less budget.  Some potential growth areas are so underfunded we are actually missing growth opportunities.  This is not limited to budget, but also to headcount to get things done. My teams have continued to shrink while adding more responsibility.

review_title: Like any company...you need to accept the bad along with the good
job_title: Vice President, Global Technology in Toronto, ON
pros: Great pay, benefits, work life integration & employee programs. I do feel like this is a company that drives with purpose.
cons: Way to many internal silos and "fiefdoms".  I fear success is hindered by selfish, and competing agendas. Sometimes we compete internally more than against our actual competition and that is very discouraging.

review_title: Mixed bag
pros:
Lots of room to be creative (within limits) with customer deals
Pay can be very good for top sellers. 
Many very smart and competent coworkers although it seems to be declining a bit
To a large degree, the account(s) to which you are assigned determine your success (maybe a "con").
cons:
Brown nosers and squeaky wheels are often rewarded
Be cautious "taking one for the team" as they can limit your ability to sell (which is the only KPI that really matters).   Taking on a troubled customer can have negative consequences
License team members (AE's) can be quick to throw you (or the services line of business) under the bus for self-serving reasons
There is a deliberate effort underway to replace many of the older people.  Wish I could write more on this topic.

review_title: Good place to work however too many processes get in the way of letting you do your work efficiently.
pros: Great experience working with many different teams within one enormous company.  Social media is promoted within the company to encourage knowledge sharing and better team community.  Good experience working within one of the largest software companies in the world.  Lots of opportunity to move into different roles within the same company.
cons: Large companies are often inundated with processes that get in the way of your work.  SAP is no different.  It sometimes takes months to get paperwork approved and alot of times you don't know where the delay is occurring.  Benefits are not as good as you would have within a smaller software company in my experience.

review_title: Awesome place to work!
job_title: Applications Consultant III in Chicago, IL
pros:
Vast opportunity to learn because of the diversity and complexity of our products for just about any industry /sector or business problem. 
Multicultural environment, excellent rapport across teams. 
Lateral career opportunities , relocation to a number of different countries and cities - can be awesome for someone who likes to travel.
cons:
Promotions (in Consulting) can take very long even if you have been doing very well , its just a near flat organization

Too much travel, constantly on the road. 

The company sometimes seems too big and there is just too much information out there in the internal portal, It can exhaust you to look for simple things..

review_title: Working within SAP Retail IBU
pros: Provides good solid benefits, talented people, solid and very large global customer base, very flexible with ability to work from home. Strong financially stable. Extensive global partner eco-system.
cons: Not very innovative, and becoming increasing unable to execute. Living off large maintenance revenue stream. No cloud strategy. Retail Industry business unit has no leadership and no real power to develop solution direction and investment. development teams unable to execute in reasonable time compared to competition. Sales organization in North America does not know how to sell retail solutions and unable to position what they have. Net new License revenue growth in North America has been limited over past three years at best.

review_title: Great team, great brand, but not built for Cloud, yet.
pros:
Cutting edge technology
Smart People
Loyal Customers 
Family Friendly
Strong Work-Life Balance
Great perks like free lunches and on-site gym
cons:
-Can be hard to navigate through as they are huge, with many differnt business units
-As part of the Cloud group, it was difficult to perform without the proper infrastructure
-Still a very on-prem culture; not very agile  when it comes to your typical "cloud" go to market   strategy

review_title: High performance environment
pros: SAP is a results driven company with great benefits and very competitive salaries. Definitely room for growth, internal networking is a must. Extremely high level of professionalism from all employees; some of the most talented people I have worked with ever in my career.
cons: Extremely high expectations, sometimes quite unrealistic or unreasonable. Need to always remember, SAP is a SOFTWARE company and if you are in a role that is not DIRECTLY related to software ( ie licence sales, or software development) you do get treated differently by the company... It's almost like 2 classes of employees.

review_title: Great company, great industry
pros:
- Awesome place to start a career, lots of processes and quality people that give you a real structure of mind that later enables you to innovate without being messy 
- Most people are very intelligent and interesting 
-Powerful brand, makes things easier with suppliers/clients 
-great benefits
cons:
- too many processes mean less agility 
- your starting salary is highly unlikely to evolve
- fast paced environment, can be difficult for some people
- unclear matrix structure

review_title: Recommended for those who prioritize their Family
job_title: Finance Operations Associate in Manila, Manila
pros: Working here at SAP for 2yrs now is an amazing experience. Each team is willing to support you and help you bring the best out of you. What makes me love to work here is the reality that they give their employees flexible working schedule. I am a full time employee but I have quality time with my family especially with my kids. I love SAP and I am proud to be here because the company loves my family too. :)
cons: So far so good. I can't think of any. I am overwhelmed how this company made me a career woman and a responsible mother at the same time. ;)

review_title: Not a company for people who wants to learn new things
pros:
1. Good work culture (only on paper and social media)
2. Flexible timings(depends on project)
3. Transport 
4. Food (pathetic food quality)
cons:
1. Management is worst. Managers are here to squeeze subordinates to 
and have no leadership skills. They are here to reap undue benefits out of their position.
2. Managers are basically puppets with no power to over say their German counterparts.
3. Don't allow people to change projects to make employees more versatile. 
Instead SAP will leave employees worthless that they will find it hard to get jobs in the outside market.
4. Mediocre salaries.

review_title: Good company, but technologically stubborn
job_title: Senior Software Developer in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
- The company's greatest asset is truly considered to be its employees.
- Really good benefits and compensation.
- A large international company and the pros that come with that (i.e. corporate stability, etc).
- Tons of jobs/roles for techs and non-techs alike.
- Work from home (project-dependent)
cons:
- Can be rather slow to adopt newer technologies such as cloud, etc. (however, the company is moving rapidly to cloud-based technologies)
- Not really a full advocate of open-source software (this is slowly getting better....slowly though)
- A large international company and the cons that come with that (i.e. layoffs, etc).
- Policies can feel kind of scattered at times since they frequently purchase smaller companies.

review_title: SAP makes it happen
pros:
In today’s competitive world, customers are not just looking for a company to solve their problems, but for a partner to continue a long journey of innovation and transformation with them, side by side. SAP strives on commitment and believes in growing together. A companies growth is like a rising tide, elevating its people along with it. My long journey with this company is a living proof of that as SAP’s transformation from a traditional ERP to a cloud based company directly helped me in transforming my career from a developer to a business partner. 
SAP delivers success to customers through a long and sustainable relationship, with people that believe in long term relationships and not short term objectives.
cons: No place for under performers.

review_title: Happy to go to work at SAP Concur
pros: The culture is overall very geared towards providing good experiences for employees and clients. There's a lot of attention given to ensuring employees find a healthy work/life balance with multiple classes and activities to reinforce it. My team within Learning Services is very open, varied, and intelligent. I'm proud of the work we do every day.
cons: It's a huge company and sometimes it can be hard to navigate your way around a specific need. I.e. there are multiple internal tools that don't clearly connect together. You really have to dig your way around to find what's the best way to submit a request.

review_title: SAP C/4HANA + S/4  = outstanding Customer Experience (X&Os)
job_title: Senior Customer Engagement Executive in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Flexibility to work and contribute effectively virtually.  SAP C/4HANA and its specific cloud offerings empowers employees across all LoBs to better connect with and serve customers
cons: Do to our size and acquisitions ... there is quite a bit of organizational overlap ... but this certainly gets minimized overtime as product integrations are further facilitated and driven across the global org.

review_title: Great company for people with drive and ambition
pros: Lots of opportunities for advancement for people who are willing to take on the challenge, great benefits, smart people, interesting work (really!), great travel opportunities, cash compensation is competitive (with big rewards for top talent employees), a lot of top-notch leadership in the upper echelon of the company
cons: Company slow to get rid of under performers, incompetent employees are tolerated for too long, company moves too slowly because decisions take too long, many poor managers in the company (especially in development, where often the most senior developer is promoted to a management position whether they are able to manage or not)

review_title: Even though overall spirit is changing, still a great company to work for
pros: A great company with great benefits and still lots of opportunities to grown internally. Free meals, mobiles for private usage, fitness club membership support, company car policy, overall freedom and very open culture from top management down to the single employee. People are used to getting lots of responsibility and achieving.
cons: It is not a start up company anymore with nearly 60 K people working for them, still a little bit of that feeling is being left, but it's becoming a usual company like other big ones. In a big company not always the best people become ones manager but the best politicians.

review_title: It has been rewarding to work at SAP Canada (Vancouver) in which I had the chance to work for 2-3 different dev groups.
pros: SAP Canada (Vancouver) has great atmosphere and drive for innovation. Definitely great benefits for full-time employees, especially the SAP lunch program card at Yaletown restaurants!
cons: Compared to other major software companies, SAP Canada (Vancouver) cannot compete in terms of employee basic salary. Recent years many people left because they get paid better elsewhere, and not helping is the high living cost & housing in Vancouver.

review_title: Would have like to found a role before being 'let go'
pros: Great people to work for.  Good processes and good recognition.  Would have liked to continue working if I could find a new role after the strategic shift.  If you are 'connected' you can really rocket up the corporate ladder.
cons: Working out of a small country limits career opportunities unless it is a sales and marketing role.  Very distinct     favoritism directed the German employees.  I was warned that the day would come when I might be let go, but SAP was fair when I was let go.

review_title: Is the most important company in software technology that helps companies to operate better.
pros:
The best thing about working in SAP is learning, shared knowledge,
Work team, can impact the life of the entire community working with SAP,
The best without a doubt is the people, their corporate values, the spirit of the brand.
cons: There are no disadvantages working in SAP, the challenge is to go to the speed of change in the technological world, the disruptions of the market, the customers, the challenges of the changing industry and the risks and challenges of the digital future.

review_title: Great global company with lots of opportunity
pros: I really like the mix between the German heart and. in the last few years, much more US influence.  Strong culture with clear and effective strategy.  Full of able and interesting people.  Realistic about the market and what the company needs to do (usually!).  Thinks globally and acts locally.  Good benefits.
cons: Some of the usual things I expect in any large multinational (complex management structures, not all parts of the organisation pulling in the same direction, resistance to change) but overall very few negatives.

review_title: Sr. HR Director
pros: I have worked at SAP for over ten years in both Marketing and HR.  I consider SAP a top notch employer.  There are endless opportunists to grow and learn.  The people are some of the best and smartest I have ever met and SAP is on the cutting edge of innovation in technology.  I would highly recommend SAP as a place to work.
cons: There aren’t many downsides to working at SAP.  It is a very large company with many areas which can have upsides and downsides depending on what the person is looking for.  The size provides endless opportunities , but also means that people probably likely will not know every person at the company or even in their board area.

review_title: Good Company
pros: I'm a second time around employee and was at another firm for 7 years in between. SAP is a far better place to work for now.  Previously it was much more controlled out of Germany.  Today it's a much better environment to work and thrive in.
cons: The employee atmosphere here is really good.  My only real "ding" is with many of their cloud products.  They really don't have their act together and it makes it difficult and sometimes demoralizing to compete against other much more nimble and user friendly firms.

review_title: Great pay, benefits, flexible work arrangements
job_title: Procurement Associate in Newtown Square, PA
pros:
-They allowed me to work from home full time when we relocated for my spouse's job
-Work life balance
-Great vacation days (you start out with 15 + 5 personal days, so essentially 20 right off the bat)
-Great pay, and in my position I essentially have unlimited overtime opportunities to make more money when needed
-Great overall benefits (tuition reimbursement, 12 weeks paid maternity leave + 4 weeks of part time transition back to work at full time pay, medical benefits are good)
cons: Very difficult to break in at the entry level. They pretty much only hire existing interns into entry level positions, so if you're looking to get into the company right after college or in your early career, the internship is the real entry-level position.

review_title: Where it pays to be a good ole boy
pros: SAP has the best consultants in the world.  They are the most knowledgeable and innovative I've ever worked with.
cons: Upper management has become a good ole boys club.  This was not always the case and I hope it will some day go back to a place where collaboration with employess at all levels is valued.

review_title: A lot of potential to expand your career if you know the right people
pros: SAP has great benefits and is one of the highest paying companies I've worked for. The prestige of SAP makes it a great place to really launch your career to the next level.
cons: If you are not connected to the right people, moving up the company is a challenge. Managers hire people they know, not necessarily the right person for the job.

review_title: Good company with poor middle management
pros: Nice place to work, good working environment though it may change depending upon client interaction. Pretty decent perks but most have been whittled away lately.
cons: Lots of nepotism, need to know people for your career to go anywhere. Extremely limited career progression choices. Useless unproductive middle management. Very poor work life balance. No focus on services, the services side plays second fiddle to the licence company. They will give away services free to sell/increase licence adoption.

review_title: Not so great for engineers
pros:
It is a SAP company so there are many benefits to employees.
Office building, Free Food, Gym, Shuttle Service.
cons: They use outdated technology and have lot of bugs which is frustrating for customers. The company is trying to adopt new technologies but they are too slow. If you are an aspiring engineer, this place might not be for you because career growth and development for engineers is not a priority. The rewards and growth promises are reserved for everyone except engineers so many talented engineers leave the company. This makes the product quality poor and below standards.

review_title: Great company to work for with good benefits but the pay was slow to come.
job_title: Information Technology in Newtown Square, PA
pros: Very progressive work culture which promoted collaboration and innovation.  When I first got there in 2001 the benefits were 100% paid for by the company.  When the bubble burst they took more and more money out of our paychecks each year.  By the time I left in 2007 they were growing and starting to reward for performance.
cons: No work from home arrangements although I understand they have relaxed that to some degree over the past few years.  Many reorgs over the years which can create instability and confusion.  There always seemed to be an annual reorg which put everyone on edge.

review_title: Good competition and food; Not yet there in adopting latest tech
pros:
- Good employee satisfaction by taking care of food (free food in afternoons and evenings). Also, free shuttles for commuting from home to office
- Good tech skills of the team. Team members are self motivated.
cons:
- Work is not in new technologies. Tech is proprietary. So, if you are planning to work on latest and greatest technologies that are used widely in open-market, this might not be a good place to work.
- In current work location, the IT/general facilities processes can be improved a lot in terms of communication and response-times.
- Some projects are not managed well and thus lead to bad work-life balance.

review_title: One of the best places to work for
pros:
Some of the pros are 

- Quality of peers and high quality of work which you get to do
- Flexible work hours 
- Employee friendly policies , like working from home for an extended period of time
- Freedom to innovate and explore technology
- Good compensation 
- Beautiful campus in Bangalore which became my second home. 
- The other compensatory benefits which come along for being an employee of Labs

There are many more pros.
cons: Only thing which I could tell as a con is the difficulty to spot opportunities across the various sections of the huge organization and go through the application process for those opportunities. It could be made a bit more simpler.

review_title: can be better...
pros: SAP is a global company and one of the best cloud companies out there. you learn a lot from cross team collaborations. The company tries a lot to give its employees work-life balance and opportunities to grow. Many employees have been working for the company for several years. It certainly provides job security.
cons: It is a highly political environment. You don't necessarily need skills or experience for the job to get hired at SAP. One just need to know right people to get any job at SAP. People get hired on teams with no expertise or skill set. It can be challenging to work on a team where your colleague and your manager are friends.

review_title: Not the same company anymore - transformed by SAP into corporate hell
pros: Great solutions, leading position in a high-demand market, lots of R&D spend via SAP
cons: SAP has completely integrated SuccessFactors into their corporate culture and it's been a challenging transition to say the least. The management team has almost been completely turned over and filled with SAP suits. No one hesitates to throw someone else under the bus in order to look good or deflect negativity from executives. Corporate culture barely exists any longer. SAP can't get out of their own way.

review_title: Flexibility, freedom, and fun
job_title: Senior Solutions Consultant in Vancouver, BC
pros:
In a global organization, considerable flexibility is provided to allow you to perform your duties in a way that fits in with your lifestyle.  This can be home working, or different hours to suit both your international colleagues and your own preferences.  

Freedom is given to you to add to your own role and follow initiatives that develop both yourself and the company.

Colleagues and managers respect your abilities and seek to provide stimulating challenges in a positive environment.
cons: To ensure a degree of uniformity, there are often procedures that have to be followed that can sometimes be a little tedious, but not unnecessarily so.

review_title: Cloud Support Engineer
pros:
Wonderful work colleagues
Flexi hours
Work from home scheme (unable to avail of it due to manager) 
Free food
cons:
Work life balance is horrible despite flexi hours
Managers are pushy and micromanage especially in Support level
More responsibilities assigned without a clear picture of expectations 
Unreasonable performance goals
Salary does not match the job requirements 
Bonus and Salary increase is a joke
Company slogan "Tell it like it is" is a farce
Double Standards

review_title: A good workplace for me in the past 10+ years
job_title: Senior Product Specialist in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
- flexible hours, can work from home during the work week (with manager's approval)
- free lunch, nice work environment in Palo Alto, CA
- stable working environment
cons:
- Depending on the role, sometimes I need to get up really early (like 6:30am) to catch a conference call with German HQ.
- some projects / products are similar and competing against each other.
- no stock options (but have stock discount offer)
- sometimes don't have the subject matter expert locally and need to take a long time to email and ask for the right person to help in a project / to resolve an issue.

review_title: Great People and Benefits -  Too Much Politics
pros:
SAP is the best place to start your career. Lot of opportunities to learn. You can prove yourself and climb the corporate ladder. Good salary and benefits.
Fun to work there, Lot of young colleagues.
cons: In many cases, the management doesn't care what you do and how you add value to the product, only how you can sell yourself. Without networking skills you cannot jump to the next level.

review_title: SAP - so much wasted potential and opportunities...
pros:
SAP has a great business foundations. It has great customers base from which you can learn a lot. The company successful adopted lean processes and culture. Great colleagues to work for.
The acquisition strategy seems to be effective.
cons:
The company is challenged at persisting a strategy long enough to see fruits.
The company fails to maintain assets and talents from acquisitions
Technology is over weighted and addresses religiously

review_title: Contradictions between company values and branch behaviour
job_title: Regional Sales Manager in Ciudad de Mexico
pros: Great company with a portfolio of some of the best products to serve the customers. Exciting self-development and guided courses available all time. Always talking and selling things about the hottest topics for the business world.
cons:
Local management always focused on the short-term, promoting behaviors and tactics not always on track with the overall company strategy. 

The local brand is losing the "customer interest first" philosophy since they are asking the customers to buy things that they don't need.

The best and the worst area to serve is Sales; best because of it the better-remunerated position; but worst because you can lose your job in a quarter.

review_title: Please stay away from SAP Reston,VA branch.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Reston, VA
pros:
- People
- Flexible work hours

Company is in good location. Many other tech companies nearby. No other pros. Glassdoor is asking me add 20 words.
cons:
I don't even know where to begin. I put "people" under  but that didn't mean mean they are technically sound. QA Dept is the worst of all. That should tell u how cheap, unstable and buggy the product is. Before I left, I heard a lot how the product is perceived in the market. And let me tell you it's NOT good. 
This company pays way below market rate so if you are in dire need for a job then work here. Otherwise work here and keep looking for job outside.

review_title: Great place to work
pros: In general its a great place to work. You get strange people everywhere but this would be a factor to judge. Great life/work balance, pay depends on position, good benefits, lunch and etc.
cons:
If you dont negotiate high salary at the beginning, then its very hard to bring it up. Increases are insignificant. 
Benefits are good, but you have to make your own mind what management sells to you. Ireland is seen as budget location, so don't expect anything extraordinary unless you are top manager. In general poor management.

review_title: I LOVE SAP!
pros: SAP allows and encourages you to bring "everything you are."  That applies to your talents, your skills, your knowledge and abilities as well as your whole personality.  The opportunities are limitless for those with the desire, drive, and talent to achieve.  People are friendly and collaborative, willing to help without reservation.  SAP has it's collective eye on the future and is working to maintain relevance in today's hyper-competitive enterprise software market.
cons: Many levels of management in some parts of the organization, you may feel as if you're lost if you're used to a smaller company.

review_title: Great place to work
pros: Strong diversity, very smart coworkers, lots of career opportunity if you have a good manager, strong compensation, good benefits, ability to shape your position, a lot of people following their passions, truly a Global working environment.
cons: Heavy workload, sometimes feels disconnected because so many people work from home and are so work focused, can be hard to get pay increases, products disjointed.

review_title: Good company to work
job_title: Software Developer in São Leopoldo, Rio Grande do Sul
pros:
Very good environment
Very strong development process maturity  
The employee matters
Very good benefits (life-balance) 
Very good events SAP that you can join
People are happy
SAP really wants to grow up, and take you with them.
The SAP Labs structure is amazing.
The best company to work that has an amazing culture and values.
SAP has a very strong and motivational "all-hands meetings".
cons:
SAP is still growing in  this cloud technologies, so diversity here is  delicate to discuss.
Deployment strategy is totally  a mess, but clever if you see from how mature it is, based on how the version matrix is almost infinite.

review_title: Great people, great products, management in denial
pros: Many knowledgeable and skilled employees willing to assist each other and committed to customer success. Best in class solutions and deep resources available for marketing and sales assistance. Competitive salary, plan, benefits. Teamwork environment that shares success.
cons: Senior management unwilling to recognize economic business conditions and recalibrate sales  revenue expectations accordingly. Mid level micro-management and consistent second guessing of agreed upon sales strategy. Internal sales meetings and calls are CYA events and not open discussions focused on closing deals.

review_title: Internally focused, externally only the margin is important.
pros: Good industry, exposure to new trends and technologies. Conservative company, engaged in sustainability activities. Facilities are appropriate with resources needed to work. Offices usually located in suburbs (rarely in downtown or centric places).
cons: Too much focus in rewarding Senior Management. Not an equal opportunity employer comparing benefits offered to employees in different geographies: much more benefits offered to workforce in Germany and selected countries. Pressure is extreme. HR, Recruiting and Purchasing processes often fail, due to dependency on very few resources (i.e. vacation time disrupt processes). Yearly decrease of benefits to match industry peers.

review_title: My best career decision yet!
pros:
*Great Pay
*Lots of flexibility (work from home, time off, etc)
*Amazing, energetic co-workers
*Magic Quadrant Leader
*Amazing cutting-edge technology
*Company values/Culture are very unique and refreshing (love the "no a**holes" policy haha)
*Real, transparent and inspiring executive leadership
cons: *SAP acquisition is good as far as capital to increase innovation but could over time (2+ years) slow this down as there is a lot of corp. bureaucracy at SAP as in any large company. Also, SAP has a completely different culture than SF so it will be interesting to see how they blend. Currently, SFSF is a operated as a separate company and only time will tell what the SAP acquisition will mean for the company but so far it's been wildly positive.

review_title: Great company to work for - global in nature,
pros: People are really nice. Everybody is very professional and all want to do a good job.
cons: Decisions makers live in Germany. Culture is conservative. While they have a big connection to the Silicon Valley with their recent acquisitions (Sybase, Ariba, SucessFactors, ConCur) and SAP corporate site in Palo Alto, the home office in Germany still dictates how things get done. They may leave you alone and look for your input, but the final decision rests with someone in a different country. Limited advancement and always in cost-cutting mode (who isn't!). No travel, but then people are traveling all the time. Not much in terms of employee investment.

review_title: Opportunities Are Plenty
pros: SuccessFactors has always been a wonderful company in which to work. The spirit of the cloud is pervasive. Being an international company, there are opportunities to work with people across the globe and even opportunities to stay within the company and move to another country. Since being acquired by SAP, those opportunities have even grown more.
cons: Since the acquisition by SAP, we have lost some of the entrepreneurial spirit. We are trying to regain the cloud mentality, but it takes a while to move 70,000 SAP people into the mentality of the 2,000 SuccessFactors people. Though, I am glad to notice that management from the very top recognize this and are still trying to get there.

review_title: Software Engineer
pros:
Good work life balance. Decent pay. Good benefits. Company name looks good on resume and LinkedIn. The company has a lot of resources and opportunities to explore.

Considering the sheer size of the company, I must give credits to the management on how efficient the company is run.

The colleagues are helpful and professional.
cons:
Processes. The company is run like a German made machine. There are processes to follow to get things done. The processes are not always simple.

Slow promotion. This is especially true for Canada.

review_title: VP EMEA Consumer Industries
job_title: Vice President Senior Business Leader in Walldorf, Baden-Wurttemberg
pros: Customer interaction, freedom for creativity and innovation. Great team spirit. Inspirational top executive leadership. Our strategy to become the number one cloud company has been on track. We are reinventing ourselves on a constant basis which makes our DAX listed company sometimes look like a startup which is on a fast growth trajectory.
cons: Due to our matrix organization there has been unnecessary duplicated efforts. Due to the many acquisitions we made in the last 5 years it is rather complex to summarize the company's value proposition and strategy into one single statement.  This has been improved lately with our digital strategy and digital framework which puts the digital core in the center of a five pillar digital strategy.

review_title: As every corporate environment
pros:
Large number of internal jobs to jump between if you wish to learn new things. 
Good product palette for Large Enterprises with solid installed base and ability to grow by changing technology platform. 
Good wages and employee benefits.
cons:
"One size fits all" approach to business can be frustrating
Silos in management and unclear responsibilities and decision authorities
Lack of management decisions and "It is not me..." attitude ... very political environment
Relatively rigid organisation unable to change way of execution especially in back-office and legal set-ups.

review_title: SAP is a struggling giant trying to find a direction in the era of Post ERP world
pros: Work life balance, peer to peer learning and a lot of loyal employees
cons: SAP is trying to find a clear direction in the current era of Cloud, IOT ,Big data and Analytics post ERP.  A fierce competition from Cloud providers Salesforce, Workday, Mulesoft(Now part of SalesForce) and even AWS is bringing the SAP to its knees where I see clear pressure on both front sales and support. HANA Product quality is still not matured even after 8 years since 1st launch. That all creating pressure, frustration in customers as well as employees.

review_title: Excellent benefits & salary – poor work/life balance.
pros:
Superb benefits such as free hot lunches every day in the Feltham office, a new on-site gym (also free), private health & life insurance etc.

Great company on your CV and learn skills from very talented people around you.
cons:
The work/life balance, overall, has been very poor. 

This is of course unique to each team and will depend on which function you work in, but frequent late nights, working some bank holidays and the never-ending deadlines/pressure can become very draining & demoralising.

review_title: A Great Place to Work!
pros:
-Great work/life balance
-Fair treatment
-Excellent pay
-Positive environment
-Learning opportunities
cons: Though our tagline is "Run simple", within the company things are definitely not run simply. If a rule can be made, it will be made, often quickly and without a lot of time for employees to learn the new way of doing things and without a lot of explanation. Different teams are very rarely on the same page when it comes to accomplishing a task because of this confusion.

review_title: Great Company, Good Comp, Friends for life
pros:
Over the last 13 years, I’ve had the opportunity to work with dozens of companies and some of the biggest name on the Fortune 500 and I haven’t seen encountered a company close to SAP with the full package.
SAP is the market leader in the cloud. Bar none. 
The company has a great total compensation package with some of the most competitive benefits.
You’ll work with some of the smartest, hard working folks in the industry, and above make friends for life.
cons:
Fast pace
pains that come with fast growth

review_title: Chill and very, very slow.
job_title: Graphic Designer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Chill work environment, some people stay at the company for decades. Stable day-to-day and friendly people. If you push really hard and own projects, you can create small ripples of change. Your team depends drastically on what part of the product you work on, some can be amazing. Lots of volunteering and learning opportunities (conferences/learning tool stipends, etc). Great work-life balance. Great support for internal growth.
cons: Incredibly slow paced. Skewed understanding of 'innovation' and 'change'. Be prepared to use lots of outdated, inefficient processes and tools. Little to no direct support with HR or IT (all remote and buried in hard-to-find dashboards). Unclear goals around growth. Design and user experience is a rock-bottom priority. Upper management takes on meaningless roles and overlooks IC needs.

review_title: Not a place for early talents
job_title: Software Engineer in South San Francisco, CA
pros:
- you get plenty of time to complete the work

- lot of opportunities for fellowships
- people are friendly and helpful
- good work life balance
- lot of fun activities oraganized for employee and their family
cons:
- compensation is very poor for the standards of Bay area
