review_title: A community divided..
job_title: Customer Support Advocate in South San Francisco, CA
pros: Successfactors under the watch of Lars was an amazing, high energy atmosphere that had a vision.  Let's say things haven't been the same since the SAP acquisition.  There are a few people from the SF days who are still with the company but all seem to be leaving one by one.  The South SF office is really nice with lots of space for one to function and there's free food and snacks most of the time. Comp and benefits are above average vs. the industry and most people are nice.
cons: SAP management has taken over and they either 1) have no clue about what made Successfactors so successful or 2)  have a clue but have their hands tied due to other quantitative initiatives or 3) fail to see any issues or problems within the organization.  There are so many layers of management that nothing gets done or approved in a timely manner (ie: taking 6 mo - 1 yr to backfill a role.  Which leads me to the next issue: teams are almost never properly staffed AND trained in a way where they understand the product.  This holds true in areas such a customer support to product management.  Just because you're adding headcount (coincidentally all from INDIA) doesn't mean that they are suitable to do the job as they lack the soft skills needed to deal with American customers.  In addition, management expects that a mere 2 weeks of rag tag (non-existent) training programs will get these trainees up to speed and working on levels as a tier 3 support associate

review_title: OK if you don't mind moving laterally for the rest of your life
job_title: Marketing Product Management in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Willing to invest in exploration of new business trends
- Can work there for life if you don't mind never advancing
- Pay is relatively high compared to market, mostly because they don't do anything significant with stock/equity
cons:
- Run by Executive Board that generally disagrees on everything or seems to actively avoid making decisions
- A select few -- very few -- employees are given the lion's share of new and exciting opportunities
- Horrible at promoting women and initiatives to improve the representation of women have token executive support
- Everything is done by committee, so anything delivered is watered down and not compelling
- Most people spend their day in endless meetings to "align" with several other groups doing essentially the same thing
- Many people will join your committee to work on a cool project, but only 5% of them will actually do any work
- Works Council in Germany -- essentially a union -- advocates for German employees and has approval authority over promotions, re-orgs, etc.  Employees in other countries have no such leverage
- American employees will work long hours, European employees generally will not take a meeting after 4p in their timezone and think nothing of asking the Americans to attend meetings at 5a or 6a in the US
- Management will bicker over spending $50K on something while wasting Millions on projects that are going no where
- Love/hate relationship with Silicon Valley
- Will hire you to do a job that you soon discover is actually already done by 3-4 other people in the org
- Employees -- even relatively senior managers -- have very little decision-making authority and are actively discouraged from making decisions

review_title: SAP
pros:
SAP is a great Company, enabling opportunities and with great employee engagement initiatives.
The Company allows you to develop yourself into new roles, even up to the point that you might need to model the new role yourself.
cons: Big Company = Process Loaded. SAP is consistent trying to change towards more simplification which is good, on the other hand Processes are still the core business of SAP.

review_title: Relaxed but really Laid-back
pros:

- Pays higher than local companies in the area with 26$/hr

- Not too Technical : It is not a company if you expect to learn a lot and try out many hot/sexy technologies. You have to follow SAP's technology stack which is very non-flexible and slow. SAP is also not mature for Cloud application development, they even have some stupid bugs that a high school student will be able to debug. I learnt nothing.
- Laziness : Huge amount of leave requests on monthly average basis. Note, This is without working from home days and vacations. When you come to the office, some people are always chatting,  drinking tea and talking about their dogs and cats. Some interns even call here "SPA" not "SAP"
- No training, no culture shock at all : when you step into the office, no one will come and show you to get you introduced to the project, and let you know where they are at (I wonder if they know what they are doing neither). Everyone just stares at the screen, and do not want to be helpful unless you keep bugging them. This is not the case in my previous internships, there will usually be a mentor and senior engineer assigned to you and give you instructions.
- Very traditional software company : no innovation is needed, do not give incentive to hard working fellows but to actors who come to the office 9-5 and sit there for meditation.

review_title: Limitless Opportunities

review_title: Quality specialist

review_title: Horrible place to work - SAP SSC Ireland.

Have worked in multiple locations, SAP Ireland is THE WORST place to work. 

0 facilities. All other location have at least few benefits and good salary. Ireland lacks/lags behind multiple things. Ireland SAP SSC is a shame on SAP.

review_title: HR Can Care More, but really did love working here

review_title: Sap is a really good place to work for but the VT team is really bad

review_title: SAP well positioned for ERP 2.0

review_title: Great benefits, some tough managers/strategies difficult to follow/understand
job_title: Principal Business Process Consultant in Walldorf, Baden-Wurttemberg

company car, shares
work flexibility: no need to work 8am to 5pm, but according to your objectives. Is up to you when/where do you work

Some managers are the most unprofessional people, which generates low interest and commitment to the job/company. Had to change 2 times a job due to unprofessional managers (micromanagement, or lack of trust). But had other 3 good  managers
Gender equality is not lived as part of the culture, even though every manager always talk about it

review_title: A workplace without trust, a vendor without customer experience in HK
pros:
- Company image looks good
- Fair benefits
cons:
-Unrealistic quotas from top to bottom
-Disastrous account selection and territory allocation
- In HK office, MD, Sales Leaders, Sales, constantly and coincidently "left" due to "family matters"

review_title: Worked for the Successfactors team. Good Experience but zero progression
pros: Nice work environment, nice benefits nice people, Good experience, exposure
cons: Progression is generic. You will get a 2-5% increase for doing the minimal work required or for going above and beyond. Eitherway it doesnt matter, If your hungry and want to progress there is no tangible progression path. You will never properly progress or get a good pay raise. I have seen the best and smartest of talent leave for peanuts. Mgmts and HRs response is a development path which sounds good out loud but in turn is a blanket response to doing nothing. Its a tick the box excuse.

review_title: Dream Come True!
job_title: SAP Associate Consultant in Newtown Square, PA
pros: Excellent salary + Amazing Benefits; Intellectual coworkers; Very positive and motivated; Unlimited learning resources and opportunities; Great management; I have come across senior employees who have been with the company for more than 15 years and all them still are excited to be with the company.
cons: I have yet to come by any. I have been with the company for less than a month and so far the experience has been a dream come true!

review_title: Consultant @ SAP India
pros: Good company to work with.Gives ample opportunities to travel.Very good policies like car lease and Home loan interest subsidy .SAP brand name is just great.People look up to you.SAP overall is doing well so SAP india is just getting the fruits of it.Employees getting stock benefits.
cons: Bad travel policies.Only good if you are a bachelor else its difficult.3rd grade mobility team.Mobility policy is horrible though.Not meant for married people.Growth wise not that great but ok.some managers are useless good for nothing than a resource coordinators.

review_title: Very good benefits and possibility to make your job
pros:
Portfolio of products, ability to know a lot about a big variety of solutions and get trainings
Ability to make your own agenda
Good salaries and good benefits
Access to good hardware, tablets, phones and overall good work comfort 
Strategy is consistent
cons:
Sometimes hard to identify how to progress in your career 
Solutions can be complex, with a lot of platforms to deal with
Management can be just a wheel transmitter that adds complexity and brings no added value
Reporting can be cumbersome
Processes can be sometimes heavy

review_title: Flexible work options, good experience, not so much in culture
pros: Flexible work options are available (working from home is an option in many cases), lots of room to learn, many resources available to employees
cons: Lot of acquisition means restructuring, which means your position can turn out to be not what you signed up for, older methodology means some of their new endeavors, e.g., mobile, cloud, can seem pretty antiquated compared to startup products, compensation isn't great, culture isn't very relaxed outside of SAP Labs

review_title: I get to be creative
pros: Challenging - no 'assembly line'-like feeling.  New challenges offering you the opportunity to be creative, innovative and prove your worth to colleagues and leaders.  If this is what drives you, you'll do well at SAP.
cons:
So many re-orgs -- it means you have to prove yourself to new execs constantly and often the work you put in for the last exec is meaningless to the new one.

Inconsistency in resources across regions means people are stretched thin and burning out -- causes animosity

review_title: Customer Support specialist
job_title: Customer Support Specialist in Pitts, PA
pros: Getting this Job at SAP has been life changing. Culture in the office is so dynamic, and management cares about the development of their employees. Not only is the culture great the onboarding experience was excellent. I met the CEO Bill McDermott my fourth day working at the company, and he made me feel empower as an employee. MY job is awesome, my co-workers are awesome, and were getting a new office in a year. I want to say thank you to everyone in the HR department for hiring me.
cons: This company haves zero cons.

review_title: Look No Further!
pros: The experiences I have had to date at SAP are far beyond most organizations. The people genuinely care about you, support your transitioning in, and help establish a strong foundation once you have acclimated. The support and resources available to you are next to none!
cons: Be ready to absorb a lot of information when you arrive. Some will be company specific and some will be role specific. At the end of the day this will not be a con - it just feels a like until you understand the vast resources at your fingertips.

review_title: Only the office design rocks
pros: love the gym,Modern office, events and hubs
cons: I had no home office, i worked 9 to 6 without any flexibility, my job description and the actual work did not match, i was not interviewing for a 1st level support but they made me pick up the phone anyway, my team was very anti-social and negative, the manager was careless and unresponsive to my questions, i received no proper training, my Multi sport card was not sent to me when it arrived in HR so i lost money (2 weeks), HR lady was arrogant, no nice places to eat around

review_title: No Better Employer In the World
pros: Been here approaching 7 years, no mean feat after a couple of decades at Oracle. Great leadership, attentive management that cares for their employs and amazing C-Suite leadership. Oracle could learn a lot about management from SAP.
cons: Very few Cons. If anything I would criticize their reimbursement policies but only because they give the same per-diem in New York or San Francisco as the do in po-dunk USA. That shifts the burden to the employee in more expensive cities. But all in all a very minor inconvenience from a stellar company.

review_title: Not for freshers
pros:
- Work life balance - Best in India
- Activities like hackathons, 3 months training in US called as SAP Academy of engineering 
- Free food, cab 
- Lots of outings
- Coool employee friendly perks
- Friendly colleagues
cons:
- Low salary and monthly take home
- Mostly inhouse SAP technologies like ABAP, UI5 which is of no use outside
- No brilliant engineers around, most of the people are from service companies.
- Poor engineering practices
- Mostly maintenance and support work, very few good development projects
- Very difficult to change teams - you have to wait 2yrs

review_title: SAP... great benefits, lots of change
pros: The benefits are excellent.  Potential for career advancement is good.  The campus is very nice, clean, and picturesque.
cons: There are many layers of management.  Efforts are not very coordinated among various groups, constant change makes it difficult to focus 100% on your job and not be distracted by rumors and confusing change.  Reporting consumes a large amount of your time. While career advancement potential is high,  you are competing with many, many people internally and externally due to the size of the company and the company allowing anyone to interview for any job.

review_title: SAP is a great company for mid-career
job_title: MBA Intern in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
experience in a successfull 50,000 employees company
resume check
industry experience

i came to SAP because it provides me a great opportunity to use my MBA skills while leveraging my technology background - and indeed in SAP you get to do that.

However, SAP in its nature as a huge company is very complex and therefore you cannot really make big changes as people are used to and like to work in a very certain way.

I would recommend this place as an internship.
cons: slow company - very complex in terms of organization

review_title: Solid company to work for
pros: The salary and benefits are competitive.  Organization is relatively flat where everyone has a chance to be heard.  New ideas and ingenuity are encouraged.  Many jobs are flexible in location and hours.
cons: There are too many processes that take too long, and some of the systems involved have been around for 10+ years.  This often makes tasks that should be simple to accomplish become frustratng.  There is definitely a focus on sales and short term results.

review_title: A company which cares for its employees and a great work culture
pros: I love the beautiful and green SAP campus . There are big cafeterias in every floor (which you would find filled with people and gossip, at any time, sipping away the free coffee).  Since the organization is flat, you can approach everyone and talk to them comfortably. Add to that the free food, cab and shuttle services, and very transparent company policies (trust me on this), it’s a great environment to work in.
cons: Employee engagement is not that high, especially in earlier days with the company. Work may not be extremely challenging.

review_title: Great company, if you are into what they are doing
job_title: Chief Development Architect in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Very solid and very stable company that will not go away any time soon. Good work/life balance (even though employees often disagree because they are spoilt rotten). Good pay.
cons: Limited number senior leadership positions in development in the U.S. If you are in consulting, sales, product management, marketing or any other non-technical field, you'll do just fine. But if you are looking for a hands-on development leadership role that will give you exposure to great technologies that will enhance your market value, you'll be disappointed. The development organization is basically run out of Germany.

review_title: Great global company
pros: I have a privilege of being a part of one of the greatest ERP companies in the world.  Besides, the team I work with is great, as well as people form other divisions and countries I met while on this job.  Wonderful environment, team spirit, working with the advanced technology - love it!
cons: Unfortunately the company decided to move operations division for which I work to Argentina.  Our team will be let go after the first of the year.

review_title: Good company, great place to work
job_title: Sales Support in Newtown Square, PA
pros: A strong organization, good culture, market-leading solutions and a strong commitment to innovation. The calibre of talent in the organization is impressive...you are working with some of the best and brightest, yet there is a strong culture of teamwork.
cons: The only challenge is the focus and emphasis on the quarterly earnings. There is a huge expectation to keep delivering results quarter after quarter, and sometimes that diverts enegy and thinking for the longer-term strategic perspective.

review_title: Changes are coming
job_title: Senior Developer in Newtown Square, PA
pros: It's still big so the influence will remain strong for a while.
cons: A lot of high level changes such as Vishal's suddenly leaving for InfoSys. SAP is yet to put out an official announcement but Vishal's already assume his office in the new company. As for the small potatos, it is NOT easy to switch to another team - people tried and left.

review_title: PS group SFSF
pros:
Flexibility work from home. 
Into cloud software. That is nice
Engg team collaborates with PS team for enhancements which is good
cons:
No pay raise for 2 years
Mgmt says no growth util Sr Mgmt  or your current manager leaves company
Benefits cost to employees increased more than more than 150%, in 2015

Under estimate work and then ask team to be efficient
Being in HR space but HR partner never responds to employee emails in time.

review_title: One of The best companies to Work for
pros:
Work at the edge New Technology in software, New use cases.
Contact with top Management of top companies, not only for its revenue but for its innovation.
Great social benefits, such as pension plan paid 80% by company, company car with fuel included, child care checks..., many vacation days. All of them over industry average.
Environment of talented colleagues.
cons: A lot of stress, high demand, difficult to balance private life with work.

review_title: Moving Goalposts
pros: Excellent pay and benefits package. Great products. Core sales teams members great people with whom I would work with again in a heartbeat. Company name a real 'door opener' at times
cons: Spreadsheet-based sales performance oversight and micro-management by European exec. Laborious and complex internal sales, CRM, commercial and operational systems and processes. Very complex, multi-layered product and sales matrix structure leading to argument and confusion about who owns which piece of business

review_title: SAP CoE Support Engineer
job_title: Support Engineer CoE in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Free food, multicultural environment, flexibility, easy going environment. My manager even though is pressured for presenting numbers to his managers, he is understanding, fair and leads by example.
cons:
No career development, no motivation for going the extra mile or for the amount of traveling you are asked.
Some managers lack peoples management skills.
SAP Dublin office is just a low cost for US office. Benefits compared with Germany are a laugh.

review_title: Consultant's view on his job at SAP CH
pros: SAP offers generally freedom  in my activities as well as training time self and in class if necessary to perform my tasks within the projects I'm involved. SAP communicates clearly and distributes information on a confortable way.
cons: Consulting at SAP means performance from customer's view as well as from internal view points. It also means long overtimes and travel hours that are generally not compensated.

review_title: Launch Pad for your Future! And...that's all about it!
pros: If you love IT and to be aware of the lastest and greatest techologies that will definie the way we do business, you will enjoy be part of the SAP family. It's a great school where who can learn new things if you get lucky to be in the right project or team. Some projects you have to go abroad but others are essencially remote. Work-life balance is usually good but it mainly depends on the project where you are in. You have the chance to take by free some SAP certifications that are highly appreciated by the market.
cons:
Almost everything else... The first thing to fix is increase the poor wages that exists in the SDC. The only way to earn more money is to have a project where you can work on-site. And these kind of projects are decreasing day after day. Concerning the career progress, it is very slow and if you enter into a uninteresting project sometimes its very difficult to get out of it at it at less it starts to go in the wrong way... 
Regarding the management team, it also depends who is your manager. They are very goal-oriented and they make everything to achieve those goals. They usually listen the team complains but usually they reply saying that they don't have power to change - or they don't want to - and this harmly affects the trust and transparent between the consultant's teams and the management. If you are one of the entrants, usually you have to pay a very high fee in order to get out to move to another company. So if you get upset and you don't like your job, you have to remain in the company unless you pay a lot - really, a lot! 
Ah, and to finish...and that one is embarassing: there is one breakout area without forks available to everyone that eats there. Forks should be expensive these days...

review_title: Great place to work
pros:
I've been working here for over 18 years now and it is a fast paced dynamic environment that challenges me and allows me to push myself and grow. 
The organization is filled with intelligent and driven individuals who are an absolute joy to work with.
The compensation and benefits package is very competitive
There is some flexibility in the working environment with things like working hours and working remotely, etc.
Tons of career development opportunities!
cons: On the flip side of it being fast paced and dynamic, the work load can be overwhelming sometimes so keeping work life balance can be a challenge.  Overall the pluses far outweight the negatives

review_title: Great place to work
job_title: Customer Office Specialist in Bogotá, Bogota
pros: Excellent team work with people from different areas. The company gave us a lot of opportunities to share with people from other cultures. Also, the company has a lot of possibilities of education for us in different topics
cons: The company is huge so some times it is hard to find the correct person you need help from or some times it is hard to find the information needed because of the same reason.

review_title: Best Large Company I've Worked For (over a 20+ year career)
job_title: SAP GCO Team Member in Downers Grove, IL
pros:
Company truly values its employees - its most valuable asset.
Good compensation, very good benefits.
Opportunity to progress and move within SAP, to new groups, new roles.
cons:
As with any large global company, bureaucracy exists and can make things move slow.
In some cases, business groups are silo'd, resulting in lack of transparency and communications across groups.
Some mid-level managers are not good leaders and fail to develop their team members.

review_title: Want opportunity, support and growth in one company? Yes please!
pros:
If you've worked with companies large and small, you'll notice it's easy to get lost in the mix.  SAP does a fantastic job of uniting all employees from various departments, regions, and seniority, to work collaboratively and efficiently (globally).

A great work-life balance.  Creative environment.  
Support from your management through to executives.
Endless learning and development opportunities.
cons: If you don't want to be a part of something innovative, forward thinking, and successful - perhaps SAP isn't for you.   But if you only have one life to live - why not make it great!

review_title: Excellent employer with some flaws
pros:
Benefits are generous - holiday, pension etc.  SAP really know how to look after themselves - the physical and mental well being of their staff is taken seriously.
Head office (*Feltham) is a great environment to work in having been recently refurbished.  Free lunches!  There's a real international feel to the organisation.
cons: The company is huge and there can be a disconnect between what the board promise and what is real in day-to-day life.   Saying that, the UK arm of SAP feels small and you may need some flexibility with travel/working location if you want to think about career advancement or role changes.

review_title: Great Company, Great people, Great Career potential!
pros: SAP offers great opportunities to develop and grow and achieve success.  There a large focus on the creative, design and agile solutions as well as all the latest technologies and innovations.  The people you work with are great and feels like a much smaller company on the day to day. The benefits and recognition are very good and includes a great free restaurant.
cons: Head office location is Feltham, great for airport but little out of central london.  There are offices in the city also, but are smaller.

review_title: It is OK...
pros:
- Good perks (free lunch, company car after 3 years, company bike leasing)
- Friendly colleagues
- Lots of development opportunities
- Good salary. Wouldn't say spectacular
cons:
- Walldorf ... Most young people prefer to avoid it altogether, also because if the cost!
- If you work in Walldorf, the cafeteria is really noisy (WDF03 at least)
- Lack of transparency, bureaucracy
- Working equipment is below industry standard
- Growing very rapidly (hiring like crazy!!), instead of focusing on keeping current employees (lots of good colleagues left during 2017)

review_title: A great company
pros:
Flexible. A lot of focus on innovation. If you are curious, there are many resources available to grow knowledge. 

I love their approach to diversity. Less corporate compliance videos, and more focused on embracing it because it's the right thing to do, and it's good for personal, professional, and business growth.
cons: It's too hard to fire non-performers. Some inherited managers (from acquisitions) are not suited to management in SAP style. Giving them a chance, hurts morale for those who work with and for them.

review_title: Reviews here are misleading
pros: Seriously, I wish I could say something objectively great about the company compared to any average tech company out there in the US.
cons:
Management doesn't care about employees. We don't get full bonuses even if the bonus pool is more than 100% and our productivity is also more than a 100% (yes, thats right). Raises are 1%, 1.5% and maybe 2%. Incredibly low compared to industry average. And any ideas you have are pointless as they're most likely going to die at the manager level. 

If you want to pursue another team or position within the company it's incredibly hard, politically and because they only want to hire from outside.

review_title: SAP is a Great Place to Work!
job_title: Process Manager in Newtown Square, PA
pros:
SAP is really focused on improving the world and people's lives.  This mission is visible in both the work we do as well as how we are treated as employees.  Major pros include:
Friendly environment
Great pay and benefits
Flexible work environment
Innovative and encouraging workplace
Growth opportunities and support
cons: Being such a large company, we struggle with simplification.

review_title: The company is great but can't get "startup" spirit again
job_title: Senior Software Development Engineer in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Work stability and legislation compliance, pretty good benefits, awesome flexibility and work-life balance, great office, open dialogue between employee levels.
cons: A part of workers have lost their motivation and don't want to learn new topics. This is a road to hell in software development where it's not enough to be brilliant in 20-30 year old technology. "Corporate overhead" seems a bit too high.

review_title: Run simple = mass-layoffs?
pros: Good benefits package (US); unique enterprise software solutions; great customer footprint; many internal opportunities (although limited to lower career levels)
cons: Company has grown too big; countless acquisitions (to increase cloud revenue) have taken a toll on customers and employees (loss of core values and culture); senior executives from “outside” (Mala Anand) with very limited SAP product/industry experience; unclear/missed cloud strategy leading to mass layoffs

review_title: Most Employee friendly company
pros: Train people well enough so they can leave, treat them well enough so they don't want to... this is exactly what SAP does.. lucky to work with some of the best minds...the benefits over and above the salaries is something you can't replicate elsewhere... personal learning and work life balance is something to strive for
cons: Things can sometimes move slow due to the fact there are so many teams internally in Successfactors and need a push from top brass to get things done,so much communication back and forth... problem that generally comes as and when a company scales

review_title: The best company I've worked at yet
pros:
SAP are on a roll with innovative, game-changing new products being launched and in the pipeline. If you're passionate about software it's very hard to beat.
Highly competitive pay and excellent (flexible) benefits, including up to 36 days holiday a year!
Open, friendly culture.
Generally good respect for the idea of work/life balance, with a European, rather than American, culture.
Good opportunities for taking training and personal development.
Free lunches and a great canteen!
cons:
Although personal development and career progression is very much encouraged, there's little formal structure around it. If you're happy to get on with the job you're in there's no pressure to move upwards which is great. But if you're talented and ready to move on in the company, then it's very much down to you to make that happen, and often relies on who-knows-who. I'd like to see more opportunities for high potentials to get exposure and experience in different areas of the business.
Benefits and expense limits with fixed values, such as car allowance, perhaps used to be generous but haven't been revised since they were introduced. 
Can be a fair bit of bureaucracy from numerous layers of management. There seems to be a great desire to impose the same processes and structures on all countries across EMEA, regardless of what might work best in a local context.
Office environment (Clockhouse Place) is pleasant but somewhat dated - you'll often find better elsewhere. Office location is nowhere near any shops or amenities, and is difficult to reach on public transport.

review_title: Overall, satisfactory, but the touted "opportunties abound at SAP", is not exactly true.
pros: The opportuntity for the company to do interesting things is great.  Being part of such a well-known and respected brand has been great.  Lots of great employee programs are run - fitness, wellness, financial planning assistance etc.
cons: You are a number.  Unless you stand up and shout and jump up and down, you are not recognized.  The company is so large, and there are so many layers of people, it is very hard to navigate to find the stakeholders that have any influence.

review_title: Growth Opportunities
pros: Opportunities to learn, grow, move into other jobs. Allows a lot of telecommuting. Good salaries.
cons: Has become much more bureaucratic since becoming more heavily aligned with SAP America. Lots of travel. Very little work-life balance. Telecommuting equates to 18-hour work days, and even if you are sick, you can still connect and participate in meetings. Very dependent upon the specific manager you have.

review_title: Great career skills development
pros: Able to work in various parts of the organization to learn about different aspects of the business.  Great benefits.  Great group of people to work with.
cons: Work-Life balance is very hard to attain.  Have to sometimes work during your vacations.  When you finally de-stress while on vacation, you jump back into stress on your first minutes back from vacation.  Career development education and training is hard to accomplish due to constantly being on the go.

review_title: A truly global company with many opportunities
pros:
Very broad portfolio of products. Interaction with companies of any size/industry. Truly global reach. 
A lot of possibilities to learn and explore different areas of expertise. 
Frequent reorganizations allow for frequent job shifts, especially for those willing to travel and reallocate.
cons:
Too much politics at middle-management level + too long reporting lines.
Constant shifting of priorities. Strategy not broken down consistently across different organizations.
Solid organizational silos. Technology decisions taken without technical argumentation by non-technical managers.

review_title: Calm place but not too inspiring
pros: Quite good benefit package. Company car. You can participate in lot of trainings. Nice working environment. The work life ratio is ok. The company always implement the new methodologies like lean, scrum, ASE so you can learn them.
cons: I would not say that you can be really innovative or creative by the company. There are lots of old stuffs, frameworks what you have to use. No one will use your product for years. Its a big slow company. As I said by the pros that you can learn a lot state-of-the art technical and management technics but these things are not really used in practice.

review_title: A roll of the dice
pros:
Free lunches at multiple cafeterias
Good bonuses
Nice location (near VMware, Pivotal, and Tesla)
Some projects use latest technologies
cons:
Easy to get stuck in a rut (with a product that doesn't generate revenue).
Periodic layoffs with no clear explanation on how positions eliminated were picked -- supposedly, the position and not the person, so many exceptional employees can be surprised to find they have a month to look internally, or find better opportunities elsewhere

review_title: SAP Rocks as a place to Work!
pros: 1) Everyone helps you (at Oracle it was like pulling teeth to get someone to answer a question) 2) SAP invests in your trianing, 3) Plenty of room to grow. move, 4) Great benefits, 4) Great food allowance
cons: 1) On-boarding initially is great but once you are in your position there wasn't much "organized" training (which is why the #1 "Pro" is GREAT because you can at least ask people for help

review_title: Great Pay, Frustrating Organization
job_title: Director, Solution Management in Denver, CO
pros: The financial benefits are great. The work/life balance is fantastic unless you end up in a role where you travel a lot which is quite common. The company has performed very well especially recently. They have continued to improve their core products. The company really takes care of their employees.
cons: There are many people that have similar roles and so your work is constantly overlapping with other people. There is no accountability for success with a single group. It is always spread across several groups. This can be very frustrating when trying to get something done because all decisions go through a committee.

review_title: SAP Saudi :?Great Company with room for improvement.
pros: Team work, Environment, many ways to solve customer issues, dynamic, Customer centric and SAP attention to details. SAP solutions are valued by customers.
cons: Middle management in Middle East lack strategy and long term vision and planning. They Micro Manage every step which makes you feel un-empowered. Career Growth is not clear, no work-life balance. No respect of your vacation. Always makes you worry and think when is your last day.

review_title: Account Executive
pros: Overall Strategy is right, where innovation is to enhance the current portfolio rather than act as standalone solutions. Impressive Enterprise approach where only big deals matter.
cons: Outside of Core solutions, the company is clueless. Cloud is handled by people who are used to an old on prem legacy approach. Mid management is poorest i have seen so far in a career of 10 years and 3 different companies  . Internal Processes are lenghty and tiresome. Work/life balance does not exist due to Managers mailing and even calling late in the evening and even on weekends.

review_title: Stable, good work-life balance
pros: SAP is a very stable and well known brand in Germany. The work-life balance is very good and salary/compensation is competitive as compared to top Software companies in Berlin. Flexible work time and place (home office), free lunch, and a company to build a career. Very diverse, multicultural, and equal even for women and minorities.
cons: As in most big companies, bureaucracies and strong hierarchy stifles innovation and growth. As a very stable company, it is quite normal to find colleagues spending their entire careers in SAP: an "ageing" workforce breathes experience but is also less agile than a youthful workforce.

review_title: SAP should stand for Some Amazing People
pros: 10 years after joining SAP I can honestly say it is still a privilege to work with some of the brightest and best in the business. BUT... it is not just the traditional employee base that inspires me, it is the amazing and talented INTERN community that continually remind me to think different, thing bold and challenge the status quo. SAP's intern programme not only brings even greater value to our customers but it keeps me 'career young'!
cons: Some might say the office locations but, quite frankly, the location is defined by the people, the sense of team and community not the postcode.

review_title: There is no comparison!
job_title: Senior DevOps Engineer in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
* Employee focused management
* Commitment to employee development
* Competitive pay
* Fairness in hiring and promotions
* High value on employee feedback in processes and decisions
* Flexibility
* Great benefits package
* Clear direction and communication from all levels of management
* Culture of continuous improvement and acceptance
cons:
* Hard to find other comparable companies
  * Other companies have a hard time matching SAP's benefit offering and salary
* Contracted services (1st level IT, HR helpdesks) can be difficult to deal with

review_title: Sales - Account Executive
pros: I have been with SAP for 10 years after 7 years at Siebel, the final year under the command of Oracle.  SAP has been one of the most dynamic and support places that I could ask to work for....demands are High but the amount of Support from Leadership down to really every person / group in the organization is incredible.  Beyond this, the Vision of the Company is unmatched and Compensation is in line with or above most of the industry as well.
cons: Nothing that isn't too minor that it warrants highlighting.

review_title: Walled Garden Can Leave Technical Employees on the Hook
pros: Remote work opportunities.  Cafeteria.
cons:
Technology:

Like most software companies, you're limited to using propritery software.  This is career limiting if and when you leave the company.  If you accept a job at this company I recommend you continuously pursue your own training outside of work to remain current with the latest software.

Management:

Your direct manager can make it or break it for you.  I worked for both good and poor managers during my tenure and the experience is so drastically different it's like working for two different companies.

review_title: Excellent Company to work for
job_title: Senior Business Ana in London, England
pros: Lots of benefits, including financial, but many that you wouldn't expect, like a focus of mindfulness and wellbeing, incredible international training and experience opportunities, a culture of openness and honesty, and many more besides. I feel respected and valued at a local level, and on a global level I know the power of SAP and the opportunities available to me. I am well paid for my job, and get generous additions like insurance, bonuses, pension, stock options and so on.
cons: There can be rigid rules around things like internal transfers, pay by grade and so on. But that can also be considered a Pro sometimes!

review_title: Intelligent Enterprise Solutions & Industries
job_title: Senior Director, Strategy and Execution in Dallas, TX

review_title: SAP is good company, but not quite what it was several years back
pros:
SAP was a great company with a great product. Its still a very good company, but there hasn't been nearly enough innovation recently to keep it going at the rate that it was. Especially in the Americas, there is huge pressure to deliver results every quarter. This has started to spread to other regions of the world. In general, delivering sales is a very good thing, but not if you continually steal from future quarters. It eventually catches up with you. 

SAP really cares about helping its customers be successful. There is a genuine desire to keep promises and live up to customer expectations. 

Benefits and comp are good, but not quite what they were several years ago.
cons:
There is now a really thick layer of upper middle management. Too many VPs and SVPs running around trying to stay relevant. There has been a general lack of innovation recently, so sales reps are running out of new products to sell. As a result, they only thing they can do is play "let's make a deal" which really means they will offer customers such a great deal that you can't really pass it up. Not sustainable. 

Development seems to have lost their touch. It can take years for products to hit the market, and then they are often too buggy to ship. (BBD!)

Too many annual re-organizations. A new set of management comes in and the first thing they do is shake things up so a few people can get promoted and it makes is seem like they are accomplishing something.

review_title: Steady

review_title: White, misogynist, Male driven
pros: Great, bright, smart, fun colleagues. Fairly good salary, comparable to industry.
cons:
I worked at this company from 1994 through to 2009, the core software has not changed since R3 days, they have bought the newer technology and kind of tried to bundle it together. I would not look at this company as being leading edge in the software field. Most companies have spent so much money implementing that they can't get rid of this behemoth until fully depreciated. Highlight of my career at SAP is when they put together an agenda for a user conference and the agenda said the men attended the talks and the women were to go for aromatherapy messages, I kept that agenda and still have it posted in my office to remind me of where I have come from and that you need to kiss a few frogs along the way. That kind of summarizes the female careers at SAP. Looking at the board today I see nothing has changed: 9 men, 0 women; 8 Caucasians 1 Indian; 5 Germans, 3 American and 1 South African (this has really changed since my day when it was 8 Germans and I American).

So if you are a female serious about your career this is not the company for you. If you are happy to sit in middle management and stay away from the sales men then plod your way through the various acceptable positions for females, the glass ceiling here is low and thick.

There is a strange corporate culture and a lack of diversity. 

For my sins I now have to engage with the sales men of SAP and I burst out laughing when they end a meeting with the wonderful line of ‘So can you sign today?” – such a cliché.

review_title: Solid but could be better
pros:
- People are usually nice, you can virtually reach out to anyone in the company in various locations by email/phone, someone can help you out
- Benefits, stock options, but recently transportation benefit was capped at 120$ which means people who park in the office need to pay the difference from their pocket
- Pretty stable company, the only major layoff happened in 2008
- Occasional international travel (Germany;-)), IT conference program, trips to customers, top talent fellowships with relocation
- If you work hard (50-60 h week), usually the management realizes and gives different perks
- Challenging projects, you might get good customer exposure or experience working with customers directly
cons:
- Underperformance is not addressed, every team has 1-2 slackers, sometimes very hard to achieve goals if several people simply come to work to collect the paycheck. In other companies these people would not survive but the manager would not address the issues because of fear to lose headcount.
- My team/manager doesn't allow working from home
- Scrum teams with many different roles but not so many developers ;-))
- Fat layer of product and solution management, shielding from customers
- A lot of talented, motivated developers have left the team since no progression in the career happened
- Technical level of expertise of employees is lower if you compare with other top IT companies like Amazon, Google, Microsoft, Apple (feedback from ex-SAP employees)
- Montreal is still a small location on the outskirts of SAP empire, everything happens in Walldorf, Germany which means if you reached T4 level (expert) your career is mainly finished, since there are no positions of T5 level in Montreal
- Constant fight over projects with other locations, Walldorf dictates most of decisions on architecture and product level
- Having sunlife as a provider of medical insurance results in wasted time fighting over medical expenses (a lot of claims are rejected)

review_title: A giant that needs to change.
pros:
- Great market position
- Great Work Life balance
- Have the right resources to compete with the big players in cloud
- Some great work done by few people.
cons:
- No learning after a while unless you change roles which is very complicated.

- Top management (especially in India) way too focused on getting employer awards from various magazines and not on complicated, outdated internal policies.

- Lot of irrelevant processes created by older people just to stay relevant. This in turn creates hurdles for quick developments/improvements.

- Average engineering talent compared to other product based companies. A tendency to hire people from service based companies and then ask them to make the company as good as the leading companies. Not going to happen.

- Incompetent HR department. Great employee friendly policies. But the resource distribution is simply ridiculous in terms. Absolutely no intention of putting the right people in right roles. No steps taken upon feedback. Only thing you listen is you have to come up yourself. Keep up this attitude and most of the talented will keep quitting, leaving the company with mediocre talent.

- Finally, older people helping each other out only to keep their jobs. It's appalling how poor most of the experienced people are technically even though their roles involve mostly technical work.

- No hiring in mid level or senior roles. People who have stayed in the company for long look out for each other and promote each other. Most of them do not care about the company. No senior expert people for cloud, only lots of fresher hiring. Freshers can only go as far as coding good requirements, but the design and architecture has to come from experts (ther are very few in the company). Most experts have outdated knowledge.

review_title: The cheapest company in the bay
job_title: Software Developer in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
- You can chill a lot and coast along. Variable comp parts are very minimal and firings are pretty uncommon, despite bad performance. TLDR: Perfect company for coasting and retirement.
- Perks are OK (but not great)
cons:
Working for SAP, especially if you are the Bay Area and you want to have a career with a meaningful purpose or comp is one of the worst life choices you can make.

There's a ton of problems at SAP, but I believe many of them are symptoms of an extremely below market compensation and incentive structure which nurtures and rewards a culture of mediocrity.

They key problem areas are:
Compensation (Note this is from the perspective of Engineering):
 - The compensation at SAP Palo Alto is severely below market. New Grads often get only around ~100k TC (total incl, bonus and stock!) and even as a seasoned engineer and high performer it is extremely difficult to get 200k total comp. Most folks I know earn between 100-150k (again incl. bonus and stocks) and have around 5YoE and are usually pretty high performing. While "100-150k" sounds like a lot somewhere else this is ridiculously bad for a company of SAP's size in the bay area when you are a high performer. Almost every startup, no matter how small will pay you more Base than what SAP offers as Total Comp and give you a generous stock option package on top.  Most bigger companies of SAP's size will pay you at least 1.5x, often times 2x than SAP (FANG would go even 2.5x-3x if you get lucky) . Furthermore the salary progression is very slow. If you progress as a high performer you get often times only between 2-4% salary increase per year. During a promotion you will normally get at max only get 10/11% more, often times less than that. Note typically you can get a promotion earliest every 2 years. On top of that almost everyone with your YoE gets paid the same, no matter how good or bad you're performing. I.e. If you perform 10x to the worst person in your team, you're probably still just earning about the same, max 10% more. Managers get a very small bonus and salary raise pool that they have to distribute between folks. Furthermore the pool size doesn't depend on the performance of the team. If you are in a team with only high performers the pool size is the like in teams with only low performers. Altogether the comp level is extremely low and the system does not reward performance, therefore everybody is just coasting and the whole atmosphere is very demoralizing.

Extremely political and bad decision making:
Most of the middle management is extremely political and just trying to keep their job / justify their existence and increase their teams headcount instead of actually making the right technology and product decisions in the interest of the company. I had one SVP even admitting this to me and saying that at "SAP SVPs are like dukes fighting to keep power over their own little kingdom". If you want to experience GoT real life, be SAP's guest. Often multiple organizations worldwide work on a very similar problem but instead of joining forces they're just making up arbitrary differences to avoid a conflict and keep their SVPs independent. Important technology decisions are made by SVPs and Architects in committees where 90% of the people haven't written a single line of code in decades. Every tech decision is affected by the "not-invented-here-syndrome" and instead of reusing existing proven OSS tech for non-differentiated components a bad SAP-copy of a technology is developed, because leaders believe they can easier sell proprietary SAP tech for top $$$ to their customers. This works in the beginning with some naive SAP fanboy customers but never leads to an industry leading product or technology and long term always leads to the same result: SAP's losing in favor of a much better and cheaper competitor. In general whoever makes the best PPT slides and talks the loudest gets to make decision and the promotion. SAP is a sales machine and not a tech company, unfortunately.

Immigration Policies:
The immigration policies at SAP are an absolute nightmare. First of all you have to beg your manager and HR to file H1Bs and GC. For GC you have to be 3 years with the company until they start the process, unless you get an exception approval. If you leave the company within 1 year after getting the GC, you have to pay back all the lawyer and filing expenses. The immigration team (HR and Lawyers) are extremely unresponsive and often times don't answer for weeks or months to your emails. You basically have to beg your manager to follow up with HR / immigration on your behalf and even your manager doesn't get answers for weeks at times. Furthermore they have some weird policies like that you have to be in particular T  level (career level at sap) to file a GC in a particular category. For example for GC EB-3 you have to be in T2. If you are already in T3 this means in some cases your manager has to temporarily demote you to T2 in order to start the GC process which is just another way of keeping your comp down. Many folks I know are visa-trapped inside SAP on an L1 or E1 visa and SAP uses the visa trap to keep folks inside the company on their subpar comp. Those folks would leave the company within a blink of an eye once they get the right visa.

Subpar technology and Engineering:
The engineering and technology at SAP is pretty bad overall. Because of the politics often times bad tech decisions are made and because of the bad comp SAP can't get the right talent to consistently create good tech. A lot of the core technologies that you have to use in your day-to-day work were developed and are pushed by the HQ in Walldorf where people live in their own bubble and rarely hear or acknowledge of tech industry trends before it's too late. Over-engineering is a serious problem as well.

For context I just want to add that I've worked at SAP multiple years, both in Walldorf HQ and in Palo Alto. The experiences described not only represent my personal ones but are consistent with the experiences of my network in multiple teams and locations, incl. US, Germany and India. The only location which I would mildly recommend is SAP Germany due to very good perks and OK-ish comp (that being said there are much better alternatives there too). It honestly appears like a miracle to me that SAP has a 4.4 Glassdoor rating and is rated as a Best Place to work, but can probably be explained with SAP being very good at Marketing bad stuff as Gold.

review_title: Awesome Company, However not for people who want to work on latest Technologies
pros: Amazing Environment. Facilities in terms of Food, Transportation, WFH option, Flexible working hours etc. Work is pretty relaxed in most teams although few teams have their tails on fire most of the time. Overall an amazing work environment.
cons: Because of the tightly bound integration of everything with native SAP technologies, not much flexibility to use all out open source technologies. Limited learning opportunities in that department.

review_title: Support Engineer
pros:
- We can begin between 8am and 10am and finish between 4pm and 6pm. 
- Free food but the quantity is limited. 
- Gym onsite with classes and a funny instructor. 
- Two days working from home every week. However, you cannot work from home neither Fridays nor Mondays. 
- When you work on a Saturday or Sunday, you get 1,5days in exchange (instead of 1 day as other companies do). You get 2 days in exchange when you work a bank holiday. 
- The pension plan is really good in comparison with other companies. If you put 4% of your salary and the company adds a 10%. Other companies only match what you put.
- You can create a development plan and get advice from HR. I have seen people moving to other departments but have also seen people trying hard and didn´t succeed. It all depends how helpful your manager is.
When a person in my team tried to move to another department, his current manager said to the future manager, “we need him here. We cannot afford losing him from our team”. This person eventually left the company.
- You can charge your electric car (if you have one) for free.
cons:
- Several People in the team have suffered burnouts. Since January this year SAP is not replacing people who left the team. This means than the ones staying have double of work and end up suffering burnouts.
- The salaries are completely unfair. People who began years ago were offered less salary than the ones beginning nowadays. Despite all the salaries reviews done every March, some salaries are still far away from being at the same level. There are cases with €3000 of difference between the new and old people. The best is that you cannot talk about these differences with your manager because it is written in the contact that you cannot say your salary to anybody. If you try to point out this difference, they will try to force you to say the name of the person and this employee will get in trouble. 
- The salary increases really little. Sometimes the salary increase is €450 gross a year!
- You always have to queue to go to the toilet in the main building. There are really few toilets for the number of people working there.
- The main building is an eco-friendly building. This mean that sometimes is warm and sometimes is cold. I still remember when everybody was sent home during the irish heat wave last year. There were only 30ºC outside but we all felt like chicken being roasted inside an oven in the main building.

SAP Business One is growing rapidly in Market Share with over 25,000 customers.

cons: SAP is a large firm.  If you are not used to working for a large organization it may not be for you.  You must work hard but if you do you can reap strong rewards.

review_title: Interesting job with continuous learning opportunities
pros:
I've never seen a business where information is shared so freely among co-workers and teams. It's a very entrepreneurial company, so you can really mold your experience here depending on what you are interested to do. The majority of managers are very supportive to enable you to get what you want from your job and experience with SAP, and with its German heritage, work-life balance is usually very good (e.g., vacation policy, sick days, flex schedules).

There are virtually never layoffs... the Board goes to great extremes to find ways to prevent this, and even acquisitions don't always result in mass layoffs.  I've been impressed at their handling of the company finances, especially during the recession.

I work with an amazing group of people who really care about our customers, their work, and the quality of our software. I'm very proud to be an employee, and I understand why so many people who start as customers end up working here.
cons:
As a German company with a works council, "down in the weeds" you can get people who are difficult to impossible to move out of their job into something more appropriate. These aren't always slackers - sometimes it's just a bad fit personally or skills-wise, but this is the flip-side of a company where almost no one ever gets fired.

SAP is a huge company, and making a change here is like turning a cruiseship - it doesn't happen fast, ever. So it can be frustrating to feel like we can't be as agile as other companies when we need to be.

review_title: Good place to start or end a career
pros:
Work-like balance isn't that bad as you are permitted time off when requested.Since SAP doesn't prime many projects there should be enough bench time to balance things out.
Really great Consultants that are true professionals that take pride in their work 
If you enjoy travel then you will like this job. It was one of my favorite aspects and I was able to have projects in some really great locations.  The job requires 100% travel so don't complain when you actually receive this. It is a condition of the job. If you hate traveling don't apply for this position. 
Good Benefits
cons:
Upward mobility is severely limited for females. Management in some divisions is 100% male and do not care about the careers of women they manage.
Utilization targets are really important yet the Consultant has very little control over this. If you are on a bad team or have a bad manager you will have a lot of bench time. Any attempts to move to other departments to increase your utilization will be denied, thus stagnating your career and salary. 
Compensation is no longer competitive the longer you stay with the company 
The longer you stay the less management cares about you....hiring new employees is top priority. However, new employees will not be trained properly so they quickly turnover.  
Very little diversity despite the propaganda campaigns stating otherwise. Diversity in SAP speak simply means hiring more men of various age ranges. 
Nepotism is the key to having a great career....not talent
Management is notoriously ineffective and turnover is high. If you are unfortunate to have a bad manager (and many are) just resign to the fact that this is a job and not a career for you. You must have an advocate to have a career here.

review_title: "No Jerks Policy"
job_title: Anonymous Employee in South San Francisco, CA
pros: SuccessFactors is a leader in the market with a rich parent supporting our efforts. When the machine is lubricated and in motion, it's next to impossible to stop the momentum. Very powerful! Listening to the CEO, Lars and Bill is inspirational and they have a great way of motivating you to believe you can do it (whatever "it" is).
cons:
I normally don't rant like this but I am sooooo disappointment in my Kool-aide high going down and what the real deal is that I had to tell you to beware of the hype. Just because they have a "No Jerks" policy and it's on the way means absolutely nothing. 

This is a Performance Management Company that doesn't even use their own tools and consequently, there is no true goal alignment, employees feel disengaged and under-valued, and the moral is low. Training at SF is a bootcamp where 65% of the material is irrelevant to your actual job and then they have you do a volunteer event to feel warm and fuzzy. You're then expected to get all the training you need from outdated recorded sessions and everyone is too busy to actually answer your questions. To top it off, selling a product where the implementation may/may not go well and the customer service leaves much to be desired causes the sales reps to questions the integrity of what they're selling to customers. 

Low work-life balance and sales team is stressed out because management bullies them with territory re-assignments and micromanagement. There is a WFH policy however it is only given to some sales reps while others are forced to be in the office (favortism). These under-performing same reps are also allowed to build up existing accounts while others are all net new. Solution Consultants that want to be sales reps fight against supporting the sales team the way they need it and management hasn't figured out how to make the relationship work. The successfactors' sales team cannot tell you that they honestly have a clue what direction the company is headed, it's the end of Q1 and no comp plan has been shared (wtf!), and the finance team can't get the commissions right.

job_title: Senior Developer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Good Work-Life balance. Lot of opportunities to grow. Can gain good functional domain experience. Great colleagues. Good culture. Flexible timings. You get the opportunity to work across functional domains and technologies. You may find colleagues who are with this company for more than 30 years.
cons: Not great at the compensation. Still follows old methodologies and slow in adopting changes. Some times politics may come in line. Not good at recognizing the hard work. Upper management asks for feedback, but considers rarely. Frequent re-orgs.

review_title: Did not love being part of such a large company
pros:
Pay and benefits were great, although my salary (from many years at an acquired company) may have been a reason I was part of a layoff.
Many opportunities to learn/work - as long as you are in the right location.
The company is focused on improving user experience across its core software line.
cons: It was hard to find information in all the noise of the corporate portal, or a person who could provide the right information. It seemed there were several groups working on the same thing, and groups did not necessarily talk to each other.

review_title: Typical Large Company
pros: The Company has great benefits and great pay.
cons: The company decision-making process is simply too "silo-ed".  The right hand doesn't know what the left hand is doing, and it leads to decisions that can be detrimental to the entire organization (because the decision was made with the good of a single organization in mind).

review_title: Been a good experience working with global teams in diverse practices, business units and cultures
pros: Work life balance, respect for employees, our opinion counts, compensation is quite decent, freedom of expression is decent, huge diversity in cultures and working styles, good learning for people who are new to IT
cons: Lack of growth or promotions, complete absence of training in non-technical teams, professional development is not great, rotation across teams is not easy. Everything depends on networking.

review_title: Plenty of opportunities to get training, get involved in projects,  choose your area of extpertise etc...
pros:
Opportunities: Training in SAP and partner technologies which is very valuable across all industries and organisations, control over the direction of your role within the company and your team, a lot of opportunity to travel worldwide for work..
Perks: Competitive starting salary with great benefits including health, dental, pension, tax saving schemes, free lunches and well subsidised breakfast & dinner, Flexi time etc...
Environment: Friendly with accessible managers and team leads, smart / casual dress code, hard work is recognised and for a big company - one to one mentoring is still used & is effective. The average age is very young at 30ish - with many interns rotating in & out every year which creates a good buzz
cons: No real negatives to mention.. One thing that is challenging is the onboarding process - everyone's experience is different as they often start at different times and many new hires in recent months / years means that start dates don't always coincide and some colleagues start on their own while others in a group. There is a good general onboarding structure but this varies across teams and lines of business - a lot of self motivation is required in order to get the most out of your first few months of ramping up. You need to famiarliase yourself with internal processes and read / study material related to your role without being asked and often during your spare time - you will need to have a keen interest in the job and work hard to develop core technical competencies yourself so that you can effectively learn SAP related material / technologies and do your job well. However - the Buddy / coach system is effective and supportive once you actively participate in your own development.

review_title: Talent Acquisition
pros: SAP is by far the best company I have worked for. the career opportunities are great, the salary is competitive, the environment is cool and the open-doors encorage you to seak up. benefits are also great, one of the best in my location. The multi-national exposure and development portfolio is amazing. At SAP I am able to partner with the smartest people in technology industry!
cons: As every big company for times it is hard to get stuff done at SAP.

review_title: Senior Director
pros: Very virtual organization with frequent telecommuting. Family friendly. Competitive salaries.
cons: Not innovative; very slow to make change and allot of internal resistance to change. Takes a strong internal network to accomplish goals across teams; spend more time on politics than working with customers. Building a career path as a middle manager is all about who you know. This approach means that its not a very diverse organization. The rhetoric is that diversity is key but the reality is just the opposite. Many employees are "lifers" who don't seek excellence, just a secure salary. Also in interviewing outside the company, SAP experience is not valued and you spend more time explaining why you stayed there vs what great work you have done.

review_title: A fundamentally good company, albeit with the issues that come with being a large global organization.
pros: Work allows you to have a global scope and impact.   Core cultural values and beliefs are very supportive and people focused.   Lots of opportunties to do different things.
cons: Some legacy parts of the company, particularly in the home country, tend to be somewhat bureaucratic and resistant to change.   Company lacks transparency around some topics and restructures far too often to appease egos and opinions rather than support strategies.

review_title: Large company that really focuses on the customer and values it's employees contributions to customer success.

review_title: Want to be on the front line of the technology world - then it is a place for you, but be aware of what to expect
pros:
Very dynamic and very innovative company with a lot of opportunities to grow and develop yourself. A lot of nice and well educated people of different art and personalities. 
Company supports people development as well as the people themselves.
Be ready to be dynamic person and flexible as company moves very fast and changes internally also fast. Be ready for continues learning and self development - company gives you a lot of opportunities to learn, and expects you to grow continuously.
Company gives a lot of flexibility in term of your time - flexible working time, flexible hours and even location. The main focus is on the tasks assigned to you being completed. This means - be sure you commit to what is possible to deliver, otherwise it might lead to overtime, which in most cases is not compensated.
Be aware: this is a big international company - networking is a key for the career development, and for the daily business. A lot of things are happening in the same time - hence you will be in the situation when something happens and you are not aware of it - keep networking to be simply up to date.
In some cases even relocation to other countries and regions is possible. if you young, talented and get to the high potential pool - you might get into the job rotation mode (very selected group of employees). 
Be ready to move and grow within the company, if you are about to make a management career - be active in this regards.
All in all - a nice place to work.
cons:
In some cases internal move is not easy due to multiple reasons, for instance:
Due to the support of gender equality: women might be promoted despite better man candidates; 
The same is related to the age: reaching certain age / seniority level potential opportunities are getting narrower, as many new positions are opened primarily expecting younger people to join and with lower salary groups.
The compensation system has been simplified in a way that over-performance is not really supported in form of money (exception is in the sales area).
The same is true in regards to the salary increase - be ready to have slow gradual yearly increases - keep it in mind when you negotiate your starting salary. 
Learn the salary (grades) system - it  determines your salary growth.

review_title: Great for self managing people.
job_title: Senior Support Engineer in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Lovely environment and everyone wants to succeed. Almost nobody on a technical level will turn you away if you ask a question. Free lunches are nice. Work is super flexible and management usually are happy to give you lots of accomidations like working non-normal hours, working in a meeting room ect. as long you deliver on your requirements.
cons:
You are a number to management. Almost all of my managers actions can be summed up by the phrase: "It will look better for his team's stats". Also managers are constantly fighting for work off other managers in the same org unit. 
Until about 2 weeks ago i was on a team with almost 100 people under 1 manager. 
I can tell you several managers favorite people who get the most benefits regardless of performance. 
Due to it being a large org i have had projects taken off me no matter how much prep i have done for very silly reasons. And this will impact my career. Things like "new employee needed to ramp up/ this employee had no work to do/ looks better if this employee works on this" and usually ends with "you can work on this other thing". Basically if I get a customer to agree to do some work and do a lot work to achieve that, there is no guarantee I will get the benefits for it.  
Heard my manager say to some new hires the phrase "we dont train you like we used to, we rely more on on the job training". And I know for a fact that he believed that this was a good thing. 
Cant guarantee that your skill set will be useful in a few years as teams are created and destroyed regularly. (Employees are usually just moved onto other teams.)

review_title: SAP - The Goldilocks Workplace
pros:
- Awesome people: I've worked for many different companies and in multiple industries - these are the best co-workers I've ever had. It's not just confined to my team either; I find myself making friends with people in completely different teams, and pretty much everyone I run into is easy to get along with and respectful. Oh, and did I mention - there are some REALLY smart people working here.

- Great work-life balance: I'm not constantly in crunch mode or working late/working weekends, nor is there any pressure to do so!

- Interesting work: I find the cloud-based analytics product we're working on to be very interesting - I can see the value it actually has to a business, and I feel challenged to innovate and pump out amazing features.

- Fun culture with cool perks: You'd think a German enterprise software company wouldn't be fun, but it's quite the opposite! The Vancouver Labs have all sorts of fun events that go on - food trucks, buffets + beer on the rooftop, annual summer & Christmas parties, therapy puppies, e-sports event tix (SAP sponsors Team Liquid), a lunch card, and the list goes on and on...

It really is the "Goldilocks Workplace", in that it hits a happy medium in all the right spots. Decent compensation, interesting work, with just the right amount of pressure and innovation to keep things challenging in a good way. It's stable, secure, and the company's prospects are blue skies and green pastures all the way. It's a company you can see yourself staying at for a very, very, very long time. I recommend it to all my friends and loved ones, knowing that I'd be doing them a solid by getting them a job here.
cons:
- The rumor mill is that while SAP pays somewhere in the top 5th percentile, some of our competitors (e.g. Salesforce, Amazon, Microsoft) pay even more. I guess you have to ask yourself, what's that extra 20%-ish pay bump worth trading off?

- The business can be very old-school corporate in some aspects, with word from Germany trumping the needs of local teams. It gets really annoying, for example, when the annual 3rd/4th quarter headcount freeze hits, because you know it always lifts at the start of next year, and all the hiring gets done then. I feel bad for really good candidates who are simply "unlucky" in the timing of their graduation. There's also the odd business policies occasionally, such as no more on-site stationery. Not a big deal, but it's a good example of the strange instructions that come down from HQ sometimes. It's a behemoth of a company, with lots of constantly shifting parts - but I'm sure it's the same at most companies of this magnitude.

- Not all roles are built equal. While I personally have had a great experience, I do know that in other teams and other roles (non-dev roles), there may not be as much opportunity for advancement or innovation. So, to whomever reads this, please keep in mind that my perspective is from that of a Software Developer role - take that however you wish.

review_title: Amazing 6+ yrs.  My experience has been that we truly drink our own champagne promoting from w/in based on performance.

review_title: Leadership is out of touch

cons:

The continual hiring of people outside the company rather than looking to promote people inside the company has led to a significant culture change that is negative.  Those who have been hired into leadership are out of touch with those who are doing the actual work.  We have a lot of managers but not a lot of real leaders. review_title: Toxic, bogged down in internal process and pressure unnecessarily

pros: Good package, lunch facilities etc. Different departments to try if first one doesnt work out. That's about it on positives
cons: Should never have joined. False promises/missold job. HR are faceless and not interested in getting involved. Promises that they're aware that things are wrong and need fixing but still beat you. Just a nasty toxic environment where you are just a number. Very short sighted as good talent just leaves.

review_title: Shared service center - good start for fresh graduates, not great for career development
pros: Great start for juniors - I've learned how to work with SAP database, the job taught me discipline, organizing my work efficiently (as there is quite large workload), using two languages at work was also a benefit, gained quite lot of technical skills. You get very good inside of how big corporate works - and SAP indeed is a large one. You experience very corporate and process-oriented culture (if you think of this as a beneficial aspect). Lot of training provided, if you try really hard you can learn many skills even above your job description
cons: The biggest one - salary. SAP states their salaries are competitive, I don't agree. Most big shared services in Prague will offer you better starting salaries. Company moved to great new offices, but the salary structures remain the same. From my own personal subjective experience, trying really hard at your job, working overtime or being successful with projects doesn't automatically bring you pay rise or promotion. This goes down to your manager, who, in case he/she is in another country, relies purely on judgment of HRBP in Prague (who doesn't even know you) in regards to salary review. In my case, I moved via internal transfer to a job with much higher responsibility and technical knowledge requirements and received payrise of 26 euros after spending year and a half in the company. I like SAP - but it works like in every big SSC. If you are hard working, either you are lucky and your manager makes sure you are happy, or you leave. This is even what SSCs want as their purpose is to save costs, but in this case maybe they should really consider a change
