review_title: Great culture and dynamic work environment
pros: I came to SAP through an acquisition more than 7 years ago. While it can be tricky (and confusing) at times to navigate the continuous changes that occur at tech companies, I really appreciate the positive and collaborative culture at SAP. Nearly all colleagues I've worked with at SAP are truly nice people who are focused on making a positive impact to the company and its customers.
cons: Like other tech companies, expect a continuous flow of change within the organization. It can be confusing at times. If you find that unsettling, this probably isn't the right industry for you.

review_title: Comfortable place to work, poor direction and rewards
pros:
laid back environment

Once fully ramped up and proficient, you can get by comfortably

Rarely too demanding for a long period of time. Often work goes through busy and quiet periods. 

A lot of autonomy given: as long as work gets done by end of the week everyone is happy

Work is manageable for the most part, can telework twice a week
cons:
Salary is poor compared to our competitors. Legacy issue at SAP, has always been the case, and nothing seems like this will change any time soon. 

Management seems like they're doing what they can with resources they have, however don't expect frequent events throughout the year, or much in the way of making employees feel valued. 

Seems to be running on a shoestring budget. Ireland is low-cost center compared to other countries, and it certainly feels that way. 

Compensation for increased workload / skill is minimal. Don't expect big year on year increases, regardless of the work you do. 

Long term strategy and goals are defined, but do not feel achievable for the most part. Targets set by board / upper management feel unrealistic, and overly ambitious. Decisions made by upper management often are confusing and contradictory. Told to work efficiently and push for the strategy, but all the hard work in the world won't help meet targets. 

The salesperson attitude of pushing services / upgrades on customers is prevalent, but disheartening. 

Some managers have been in the role for many years, very stuck in their ways and closed off to criticism and suggestions

Company wants to hire and promote innovative thinkers, but new ideas are often ignored due to costs or lack of medium / long term commitment

Training is poor to non-existent. Again management cites costs in refusing to provide proper training to employees.

Management wants skilled, motivated, innovative workforce, while not wanting to pay for it

review_title: Overall a good employer with some key issues

Pleasant office environment
Overall a good culture

You can ask for more work but there are no benefits to doing this as there is no promotion or salary increase. no point in doing extra work and earning same as person that does the very basiscs. 

Opportunities to learn are focuses on soft skills.

review_title: Seems like a good deal....but it isn't.
pros:
The salary is pretty good for the position.  

The benefits including the $4.00 per diem for lunch are great.  

Depending on the department you work for you may have the opportunity to work from home.
cons:
Many of the departments are very territorial.  You will frequently find that the most stressful part of your job will be dealing with other employees of SAP that do not understand that in the end you are all on the same team.  

Explanations on how to perform every day tasks in the system are poorly documented and the instructions that come from Germany are rarely helpful because they do everything differently over there.  

The sales team can be very arrogant and difficult to work with.

Many of the departments do NOT have flexible hours.  There is a school of thought that believes the $4.00 per diem for lunch at the cafeteria is designed to get employees to stay in the building all day and eat lunch at your desk so that they essentially get an extra hour of work out of you.  Expect to be there at least nine hours every day, there is no skipping lunch and leaving early.  

Currently SAP America is in a hiring freeze and has been since late last year.  There has been NO word on when the hiring freeze will be lifted.  

Quarter End's for Finance are a nightmare.  If you have a family and want to spend Christmas, New Years Eve, Or July 4th with them this is not the place for you.  I am not exaggerating when I say I left the building on New Years Eve at 9:30 PM and there were several people that were still there.

review_title: Rewarding, educational and always challenging
pros:
SAP is a very people-centric organization.  Everybody at all levels of the organization treat one another with respect.  SAP also encourages management to reward their people, and encourages peers to recognize each other.  SAP has a good name, too, and so clients treat us with respect.

Also, I think it is very cool that we have co-CEOs.  It is a big job, and I am glad we have a team at the top.
cons:
As a consultant, most of my interaction with SAP is remotely.  Even after 5 years working at SAP, I still have trouble finding information when I need it.  SAP tries very hard to communicate policies and provide good training, but it is hard to keep up with everything that is offered.  

Another downside of working for SAP is that our hourly rates are higher than other consultants, which causes certain things to happen: sometimes the client will be inclined to bring you on as the only SAP employee on a project, and bring all other consultants from a partner or independent.  The client does this so that SAP will have "skin in the game..." but still pay low rates for the majority of the team.  Sometimes you discover that the other consultants have no real implementation experience, which can put you in a difficult political situation.  Also, you are required to solve all of the toughest problems because you are considered to be the expert (a living-and-breathing-SAP-help-file).   Your higher rate also means that the client will wait as long as possible before bringing you on and can be very picky about how many hours you work.

review_title: Great place to work (**conditions applied**)
pros:
You get to work on one of the best software platforms in the world, you get to work with colleagues (esp. German counterparts) who are plain brilliant and awesome. Great place to learn. Stagnation sets in quickly and it is upto you to ensure this does not happen (change teams or initiate new projects). People tend to get lazy after spending a few years at SAP. 

If you play your cards right, you can grow very quickly. You have the chance to build networks and this will help accelerate your growth in the company. Some people I know have become directors/VP's in 10 years or so.  

Other Pros - 

Some managers are really accomplished and are good leaders
The current MD is a proven leader
scope for international mobility (if you build your networks)
Free food
free transport
Initiation of some employee friendly HR policies (though implementation is still left to managers)
cons:
WHERE IS THE INNOVATION????

SAP Labs has changed a lot in the past 8 years. Once a breeding ground for technologists and Geeks, it has now reduced to a body shop for cheap labour. These days, not much innovation happens in SAP, and developers mostly work on unimportant projects which the 'real' German and American developers dont want to do. Some team managers 're-invent' stuff or start 'projects' just to prove they are doing something important. 

SAP Labs in India is a managers company, which means employees have no say in what goes around. Promotions and growth depends on shouting out loud, networking and being close to managers and VP's, leaving real talent frustrated. Most Managers are not competent or skilled , and they constantly deny employees benefits (like tele-commute etc) which are provided by the company.

review_title: Delusional Management
pros: Nice colleagues, slightly above average pay, commuter benefits, free food, office location, being part of SAP gives company access to lot of resources.
cons: This company drinks its own Kool-Aid. Instead of digging out deficiencies & working on solving them, the management across the company spends more time building powerpoint slides to show why SuccessFactors is the best cloud company in the world. I think they come up with these metrics to secure their bonuses for the year. The reality is that Successfactors is nowhere close to being the best cloud player and it will take quite a bit to get there. In the long run this will be a more serious issue.

review_title: Good company for career development
pros: The company has many different lines of business and encourages cross-pollination, and I saw many colleagues take on several roles before finding their sweet spot. Standout talent tends to get recognized, good processes for developing high potential employees. Recent focus on innovation has loosened the bureaucratic shackles somewhat.
cons: Revolving door in middle management makes execution a bit of a challenge. Many key positions seem to change on a yearly basis or worse. Overly long process for developing and rolling out comp plans, in some cases you wouldn't see them until 4-5 months into the year.

review_title: Poor Work Life Balance, but Top Tier Pay. Office Politics abound and Opportunities for growth only exists in the US.
job_title: Director of Sales Operations in Toronto, ON
pros: Salary levels were higher than most but seem to be leveling off to match other competitors in the industry now. There are still some great people that work there both older experienced ones and newer Millennial's coming in. The SAP brand is both a blessing and a curse. This is a great stepping stone company if you want to work harder than you have ever worked in your life, to make money and get experience to move on to a more balanced life. Great for a single person to start out at.
cons: You are a number at SAP until you make yourself heard, the executive management is tyrannical and will not listen unless you are willing to play office politics. Office politics are the way at SAP, you need to be ruthless and uncaring about others only concerned with helping them win business at whatever the cost to you or the customer. They have a name for this at SAP, it’s called "Building your Personal Brand! " They offer a lot of training programs but most staff are too overburdened with work to be able to take the time for it, guidance and support from your Manager is virtually non-existent as they are also overburdened. I worked 80-100 hours a week, 7 days a week for many years until I needed to make a change to reconnect with my family. Growth opportunities are reserved for those that play Office Politics well, choose your side carefully as the pendulum often shifts in the other direction. If you are in an office outside of the US understand that you are in a Satellite Sales Office, don't be fooled into thinking that you will gain more experience or growth than that. Your job in a Satellite Sales Office (or Marketing Unit) is to bring in revenue at whatever the cost to your fellow employees or the customer. If you want to move up you may have to move to the US or Germany.

review_title: A very employee friendly company, great place to learn and grow!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
I have been with SAP for over 12 years. That it itself is a testament to how valued and comfortable the company makes you feel as an employee. 
With SAP, you get the feeling that you are working on high value products that make a material impact to how businesses are run. The brand is highly respected in the industry. Work culture is great, very open and employee friendly. Pay and benefits are okay, it is better than average market, but the upside is limited as there is no profit sharing or RSUs granted on a regular basis. 
The best part is, SAP provides great opportunities to move within the company to new jobs and teams, and invests in talent development.
cons:
Speed and agility - This is definitely an area SAP can improve on. 
I have often felt that SAP leadership lacks decisiveness. So, in several areas you see similar products competing with other SAP products, and it could be confusing. This often affects the speed of delivery. 
There is also more resistance to change, so you could get stuck with "dead" products or technologies for a while.
Proprietary technologies - SAP's flagship products - SAP Business Suite - is built using proprietary technologies. In the last few years, SAP has embraced more common technology stacks to build solutions, and I hope this will only increase and will improve the ease of development and speed of delivery. 
Not enough early talent - I feel that the average age of an SAP employee is higher than the industry average. This is a huge benefit due the experience and knowledge levels that reflect in high quality of software products the company produces. But, it is important to balance this with early talent to leverage new ideas, trends, skills and energy they can bring.

review_title: I love working at SAP

review_title: Perfect Balance

review_title: Market Development Represnetative
job_title: Market Development Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great culture. Some of the people I worked with in the last year are amazing! Nice office. Unlimited soda/coffee/LaCroix options. They cater in food all the time.
cons:
Although the job description states that the role is for a Market Development Representative position, you are really an overpaid Telemarketer. The truth is this role consist of cold calling prospects 8- hours a day with the sole purpose of  setting appointments for Concur's Regional Sales Executives to follow up with potential new business. The practices that Concur uses to reach out to prospects is the biggest reason I left. You will be forced to mail merge/email blast thousands of new prospects, then follow up with them via telephone. Emailing these prospects constantly, calling them constantly, leads to a ton of rejection. They implemented new software to cut down on the email blast earlier this year, but with limited to sending 250 emails a day, they switched back to the "spray and pray" mentality. Get used email merges, daily, sometimes reaching out to 10K people at a time. It seems like they don't care about saturating their territories with constant emails. 

You must perform well in the Market Development Representative positions for a minimum of 12 months prior to being looked at going into any other role; in those 12 months, you must be hitting 100% to goal each month or you WILL NOT be promoted. That simple. The goals keep getting higher and higher because they want to get to 1 Billion in revenue by 2020. This is constantly preached. 

 This position is best suited for someone straight out of college, very flexible with work hours (some reps work 6:45am - 5:30pm daily), no kids, and live close to the St. Louis Park location. A large number of the current MDR's do not like the position at all, but are working hard to possibly be looked at to be promoted down the road.

review_title: Lots of positives, some very real negatives
pros:
- Great company !
- Great products !
- Motivated & charismatic CEO that could sell cement shoes to passengers on a sinking ship.
- If you are in Germany, you probably have a job for life.
- Very good travel policies.
- Excellent benefits.
- Some years you get a very generous bonus.
- You will always be proud to work for SAP
cons:
- Too bureaucratic.
- Way too many layoffs, sometimes with horrible euphemisms such as simplification.  "Hey, life is simple, you don't have a job".  Literally folks were saying "I've been simplified".   I can't stress how bad this hurts morale, and productivity.  Folks stop helping each other because they don't want to make themselves irrelevant.  It was fascinating and terrifying to watch from the inside.
- If you are good at your job, it's difficult to move up as your manager will likely not let you go.  (This was ultimately the reason that I eventually left)
- For services, there are VERY high utilization numbers which means you'll have to do training  / self-improvement on your own time.  You'll also likely not take some of your PTO in an effort to make your numbers (and ultimately your bonus payment)  If you end up on short term assignments, it will be nearly impossible to make your numbers.  
- You don't always get a raise.  When you do, it's likely fairly small.  Over time inflation means you make less. 
- There are some new ideas that make no sense.  Example:  They changed the employee evaluation system to something called "SAP Talk".   You no longer get rated.  You simply have a conversation with your manager and set some goals.  But you aren't rated.  You have NO idea really how you are doing.  You have no idea how your performance will affect a raise (if any).  I feel like my career went into a big fog once the ratings went away.

Technology is moving quickly, but many aspects are controlled and guided by central architecture which doesn't leave a ton of room for flexibility.

review_title: Employees are really well treated

review_title: In general, a great place to work
job_title: Technical Support Consultant in São Leopoldo, Rio Grande do Sul

SAP allows you to do new thing and learn new areas if you want to improve different skills.  
Great place to work and great compensations & benefits. 
Home office culture is really good.
cons: Due there are a lot of thing do do, sometimes you can see yourself overloaded in your work and it can impact your personal life.

review_title: A great international company to work at
pros: Generally speaking SAP is quite an international company and diversity is embraced by most of our colleagues. Great events are hosted all the time and there's always great opportunities to expand your network and get inspired from the colleagues. cons: Some managers lack sufficient leadership skills and might result in lack of good planning for the employees. This can be big drawbacks for individual development. Not sure if the managers are properly selected or sufficiently trained.

review_title: Significant Insurance Premiums Increase!!!
pros: Don't get me wrong, there is a lot to love about this company - mostly the people you work alongside.
cons: 2020 Insurance Premiums just came out and there is a huge spike.  My colleague who has just herself on the plan saw a 100% increase in her monthly premium for 2019 vs. 2020.  Mine is increasing by a minimum of 17%.  Annual raises are minimal at best - during a time that the company is trying to boost revenue for shareholders... their workforce is most definitely feeling the impact!

review_title: Good learning atmosphere, nice colleagues, internationalism

innovation and entrepreneurship. smart, ambitious people . Feedback culture

review_title: Fantastic employer with excessive politics
pros: Extremely flexible schedule works really well for people with young families. Good compensation, excellent benefits. Best of both worlds--European approach to employment (job relatively secure), American approach to being an employee (less structure).
cons: Excessive politics and way too many turf wars. Probably inevitable for a large company, but still hampers productivity and can be demotivating. Strategic direction changes every 6 months.

review_title: Great Place to be in, if you are can fight for good work
pros:
Transparent and Visionary Leadership 
Good Pay Package
Recognition / Rewards for your hard work
Pro Employee Policies  
Amazing Internal Support Teams and speed of execution ( HR/Transport/Finance)
cons:
Middle-management is a concern for SAP, In certain cases middle-management is not capable enough to accept challenges

You would in  certain cases have to fight with your bosses to get better piece of work

Complete Management Control from Germany.

review_title: Since 2011 the management has be in a state of confusion
pros: My fellow colleagues are for the most part, hard working and conscientious
cons: Very disappointing compensation results. SAP in 2012 had double digit growth but underfunded the employee bonus pool by 16%. Employees will only receive 87% of their expected bonuses. This announcement was buried 5 minutes into a blog linked to by a inappropriately titled email that came out on Feb 26 2013.

review_title: Completely disorganized, cult mentality. If you don't like what we're doing, get out!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in South San Francisco, CA
pros:
Big company name (especially with SAP) and overly inflated titles look great on your resume
Great benefits
cons:
This is a culture of lies, fear and manipulation.  The mantras are plastered all over every wall with things like "No A-holes."  The company (and management) does not practice what they preach and, until the CEO quit, we were constantly berated at "town hall meetings" and by company-wide emails with the constant message - if you are unhappy here, leave.  You are simply disgruntled and we don't want you here.  There is no open mindedness towards change for the better or the "Kaizen" culture they claim to have.  In fact, punishment abounds in this world of fear.  Nearly every employee in the place has been the subject of some form of reprimand.

There is high turnover in upper management, which is very unsettling.  People at all levels don't seem to stay in any position for more than 6 months before either leaving for something else, or being moved to another functional area.  Entire teams are disbanded on a whim and there is no certainty about who does what.  This type of CONSTANT organizational change creates an environment of zero responsibility.  

Work-from-home is selectively applied, even within teams.  Work-life balance only exists if you count "carrying your work phone around with you and constantly being on call" a balance.  You can expect to work late nights and weekends.  "Unlimited paid vacation" simply means that you're not actually entitled to any vacation, except at the whim and will of your manager.

Despite growing revenues, everyone in the company suffers from "not enough resources" to do the job correctly.  There is a company-wide culture of "something is better than nothing," which, if you believe in having pride in your work, will be a challenge for you.

review_title: Product Expert
pros: Great work/life balance, open communication, good salary and very skilled people working in this company. great culture and many opportunities to travel (at customers , internal workshops, Teched etc...)
cons: You have to work on the hot technology of the moment to be recognized by your management (e.g. HANA, cloud etc...). Most people are aging (average late 40's) so maybe some lack of general energy around the workplace, but ok overall.

review_title: Excellent Growth Opportunity
pros:

+ Virtual working environment
cons:
+ Challenge to make sure you get the right territory to be successful

+ Not invented here mentality can inhibit creativity to help get deals done

review_title: Excellent company
job_title: Senior Solution Sales Executive in Almaty
pros: Real team work company, lots of attention and support from all levels of management, good and frequent trainings in order to increase your expertise. Even more trainings and courses are available for free. Overall internal culture is very good, positive and supportive, while letting you do your work independently. Quickly reacts to market. Proud to be part of the company.
cons: Not much to mention here. Product portfolio and product licensing are a bit complicated but company already simplifies it. All the rest - same or better than in any other company.

review_title: Great Company, but know you'll be stepping into multiple roles to get things done
job_title: Platinum Support Account Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great pay - lots of investment in new products, both internally (CRM system) and in developing the different modules (new reports, new views, etc.) Lots of good energy and flexibility to work remotely.
cons: Often times designated resources (engineers) aren't available for high priority items - as a Support Account Manager, you may be asked to look at code of forms, etc. to help move things along.

review_title: Large corporation striving to change culture to compete in rapidly changing arena.
pros:
Depending on where you are based there maybe a range of opportunities for advancement locally and if you're willing to move internationally.

Personal development resources are more of the online soft skills variety although there is a smaller range of more technical, job relevant classroom courses available depending on where you are based. Germany, France and India appear to provide the greatest number of the latter.
cons:
Appears to be going through a period of continuous reorganisation with reporting lines constantly changing. This appears to have little practical effect at lower levels although must detract from concentrating on future development and implementation of strategy whilst senior management are playing musical chairs.

There is the impression that competing groups are attempting to appear relevant by building similar features into their products. This duplication is driven by the political nature of progression based on the appearance of achievement and potential sales but leads to a variety of offerings that confuses sales people and customers alike.

Have really bet the farm on the the SAP HANA platform and becoming a cloud based company. As the analysts have noted the latter is affecting the on-premise sales but despite this the stated aim is still double digit growth year on year. Major threats are Oracle and the smaller competitors who threaten to make more focused inroads into multiple product areas.

There is a tremendous disconnect between the external and internal barrage of corporate messaging and the actual decisions made internally but this is probably the same corporations the world over.

Internal processes can appear to be very dogmatic and archaic and veer on the side of telling you when you're in contravention of the rules rather than giving you the information to adhere to them.

review_title: Business Development Manager
job_title: Business Development Manager in La Crosse, WI
pros: Great company, forward thinking, solid management team.
cons: Huge organization, 75K+ employees means sometimes not as agile in decision making process, I have had a couple of experiences where new compensation plans have not been rolled out until well into the 2nd quarter, which causes frustration on the part of the sales team.  Also there can be a bit of a "revolving door" in middle management as they work to get experience to climb the corporate ladder, causing some instability.

review_title: One of the best jobs in the Business

review_title: Great experience overall

review_title: Working at SAP was a good experience

review_title: Career Growth

review_title: HCM Software
job_title: Technical Services Engineer in Boston, MA
pros: The SuccessFactors product truly is amazing, customizable, and tightly integrated between modules. There are a host of talented and dedicated employees that are committed to the betterment of the customers and their goals.
cons: If you are employed in a customer facing position that provides support and configuration assistance, then you will consistently be required to do more with less, and will be viewed as a necessary evil. Managers regularly refuse to allow employees to advance out of their roles if they are seen of immediate value in their current role.

review_title: A lot of work to catch up for improvement
pros:
Truly a tech company based overseas.
New and still growing.
Part of a tech giant SAP which gives good background and experience.
Good health and life benefits.
Good middle class level salary.
cons:
High tolerance for mediocrity; if you want a steady paycheck then this is the company for you.  Incompetent and competent talents have little or no rewards, discipline or recognition system. Just be there and do your job type of thing.

Bad hiring > training > learning > retaining program & sets employees to fail; close to no system at all, there is no ongoing training opportunity that will make employees feel growth; same as for their leaders.

Stale leadership breeds stale culture; this cuts innovation since leaders stay 5 years to decades in the same role.

Oligarch culture; some departments have clique of people or clique of leadership. Some employees to leaders (vice versa) think suspiciously of their colleagues limiting pacing for any improvement and damaging relationships. They would even put you on surveillance so they can find and talk about anything interesting. Then, you'll be surprised that everyone in the company is already talking about it.

Rumor culture; is another norm to be tolerated in this company. Damaging any person's livelihood and reputation is accepted, some leaders even join the fun.

Social media ranting culture; is wide-spread, accepted and normal. If you want to with colleagues who spend their precious time and energy on ranting (daily/occasionally) about work then this is for you (if you are one of them).

Friendliness based performance; if you are people pleasure then you'll be successful here. Talent and commitment are not valued if pessimist and envious colleagues/leaders destroy your reputation. HR also find this culture normal, there is little to non in balance of ethics to weigh judgement on what is right or wrong.

"I hear your feedback" attitude for employees in authority; they like to hear feedback but nothing will be done on any matter, authority is confusing and seem like a mess on who can do or implement anything that can help. There is some push and pull due to many layers of leadership fighting for the spotlight or the next promotion.

Many customer complaints; the laidback mediocre culture creates intense customer dissatisfaction. Like previously, these customer feedback are overlooked in expense of choosing to make employees happy (vs customers).

High customer turnover; while growth is always the press-release there is still a lot of customers leaving due to it's old tech and really bad service. This company will be like Nokia soon, because it's the only strong choice for a solution. However, as new companies or competition build stronger solutions, better tech and seamless service this company will be like a rat in a quick-sand.

review_title: Good, bad and ugly
pros: Great people. Some of the best colleagues I have ever worked with. Compensation is quite good.... when they pay it. Numerous resources to help you win.  Lots of customers so great opportunity for young sales people to practice their craft. They have a very good graduate program to get in young pre-sales and sales professionals into the business. If you’re lucky enough to score a spot in this program take it. You will learn so much about Enterprise software and how a large tech vendor functions.
cons: Politics, politics, politics. The organisation is rife with political Mumbo jumbo. Some of your colleagues will spend most of their time cajoling senior managers to get favour and promotions. If you’re not a yes person be prepared to have a big target on your back. A large portion of managers in ANZ are not leaders and have been promoted after decades in the business as such all they understand is process and the SAP way. Any attempt to provide a different point of view is stifled. Commissions are rarely paid correctly and on time. I had numerous instances of waiting 6 months+ for commission and managers were not supportive in escalation. Overall be prepared for a highly political organisations, with unhappy customers and a very old school on premise technology thinking. Lastly, this is a pressure cooker of an org, almost no work life balance and very demanding managers. There were numerous Occassions when my managers would call me while on leave.

review_title: Customer Success Manager
job_title: Customer Success Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: I’m a remote employee and I love it, this was on of reasons I accepted my offer from SAP 5 1/2 years ago. Individual contributors have opportunity for annual bonuses based on performance as well as targets determined by several business factors. Each annual bonus I have received are amazing and never disappoint! SAP really cares about their customers success and drives this throughout the organization.
cons: Being a remote employee has its disadvantages, at times you don’t feel a part of a team or the many activities they hold at corporate offices. Invites are never made to local offices, even to holiday parties or outings. Work hours can be long when issues arise and it’s expected you work, even on weekends and especially on release weekends. Career advancement is very difficult to achieve unless you personally know someone, opportunities are not always given based on qualifications and the internal job posting process is not consistent. I personally applied for over 12 internal positions I was highly qualified for over the last 2 years and was not offered 1 position. No feedback from recruiters or hiring managers. Continued job education is hard to achieve due to time constraints during work hours but with so many products that are supported it is a must to keep up with products and changes.

review_title: Great Company to Work
job_title: Senior Analyst in Newtown Square, PA
pros:

3. Have great offices with excellent world class facilities
4.  Unlimited learning and growth opportunities (learning new technology is never   stopped in this company)
5. Opendoor policy, which allows people to speak openly about the issues and problems.
cons:
1.  Sometime, feel like too much process driven
2.  Should make all their teams work more closely.

review_title: Proud and Happy to work for SAP

cons: Because the company is so large, sometimes it is hard to understand the best move to make within the company to better your career, but HR are a great help when it comes to this.

review_title: The best company in south of Brazil
job_title: Product Support Engineer in São Leopoldo, Rio Grande do Sul

It also has a very good work/life balance policy, which prevents stress out of working hours - and nowadays we all should value this more than anything. Benefits and salary are also great, way above the average in my region.
cons: Despite having an Innovation hub and heading towards new technologies, the majority of the job positions deals with legacy technology, which can be disappointing for younger employees.

review_title: Best IT company in Europe, by far.
job_title: User Experience Design Expert in Berlin
pros:

review_title: SAP is a great place to work. Great offices, global company.
job_title: Senior Director in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Truly international, global organization where you can interact with people from all continents in a given day.
Ownership and flexibility  - most people work from home office
Company has lots of resources and small ideas can become big very rapidly if you manage to set the wheels in movement.
cons:
Hard to go up the ranks, political environment from VP-level and up.
Very complex organization that is perpetually changing due to periodic reorgs.  You need to be a very flexible person who adapts to change quickly.

review_title: SAP Labs - A wonder
pros:
I was an employee of SAP Labs India. This is my favourite. If you are very particular about work environment, this is the company for you. Some key points.

1. Very flexible work timing. You can follow your own work timing.
2. Acurate time recording. Very transperant.
3. No hierarchies. I joined with no relevant experience - fimilar to fresher. I did not get a feeling for a moment that I am junior. Every people is very approachable.
4. Team mates are very keen on sharing their knowledge. This would have been dificult if this time is included in your deliverable and you have to answer why did you consume more time for the deliverable. You always record accurate time here.
5. You plan your vacation and avail leave. In many organization it is only in paper you hardly get it.
6. You take the ownership of your own work item. You are valued much as developer. Developer gives estimate of time and effort of development. It is not like your manager/ lead agreed upon a timeline while you are unaware of it.
7. Many employee benefits/ perks. 
8. Very good recognition procedures.
9. Sick leave-not unlimited, but you can avail it. In many other organizations you can find noise around your place about an employee who is on sick leave. Manager/ Lead doubts if the employee is really sick. 
10. You can get very fast growth. I got two promotions in three years. I have seen very young leaders in Labs - and they really deserve such positions.
11. 360 degree appraisal. I even had a say on my new manager selection. Regular meetings with management/ manager where you can say your concern. Those gets addressed. You will easily find that your employer is very friendly.
12. Plan your career. Share your development plans and excute your plans to grow. Management will support you as much as they can.
cons: You own your career in Labs. You may not find you are forced to do some thing. You need to take the responsibilit of your work and deliver it. You may thrive well with less work, availing all benefits etc- at the end you are the loser.

review_title: Customer Support Manager
pros:
Work from home is great.
I had a lot of great colleagues, I am still in touch with several and some are even close friends now. It is a friendly work environment.
The software is interesting and fun to work with.
cons:
The organisation is so big that finding the information needed for the job is nearly impossible. Never met my manager face to face.
Too few people to do the job meaning a lot of overtime - unpaid.

review_title: Great Place
pros: Changing technologies, dedication to continuing education through company class offerings and external resources, stable established company with an eye towards the future.
cons: still a lot of legacy code that can be difficult to maintain. Sometimes the smaller offices do not abide by a few of the more generous policies the parent company has in place. sometimes the operations team in the datacenters is not very responsive, making it difficult to resolve live customer issues.

review_title: Great Company, once you know how to navigate
job_title: Vice President, Operations in Arlington, VA

Silos exist based on management objective bonus structure, which doesn't always lead to the "best" decision for the business.

review_title: Wish I would have joined years ago
job_title: Senior Solutions Engineer in Newtown Square, PA

They are re-inventing themselves so they can help companies run better for years to come.
Decent work / life balance.
Compensation is above average for my field
cons:
It is a large company, that works with other large organizations so there will be complexity.
Needs a little more marketing to let other companies know we are more than just ERP.

review_title: Stable but a slow company
job_title: Senior Software Developer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Stable enterprise business oriented. Long vacation package. Fair health and 401K benefit. With $6.5 lunch credit and free fruit daily.

review_title: Lots of room for growth and new challenges!

I'm  surrounded by smart, articulate, engaged colleagues who seem to really want to make an impact here.   Great place to work -  great work/life balance, as many roles can be done virtually.
cons: As any large company,  you have to navigate through multiple layers of processes to get things done.  But leadership seems genuinely committed to our "Run Simple" motto.   Things are improving every day.

review_title: A good company to work for

review_title: Great place to start your career at

review_title: SAP is a one-of-a-kind place to work!
job_title: Senior Presales Specialist in Bogotá, Bogota
pros: At SAP there are so many opportunities to learn and grow. The corporate culture of inclusion and openness gives the individuals the opportunity to develop not only professionally but also personally.  Corporate Social Responsibility is also very important at SAP, as part of the company's effort to improve people's live.
cons: SAP is transforming  and improving internal processes to streamline the operations for the benefit of the business with great impact on the day-to-day activities of the employees, which I see as a very positive action from SAP to improve employee engagement.

review_title: SAP is an employer of choice in the tech space
pros:
-Flexible work environment
-Compensation is competitive for area and position
-Good management and leadership
cons: -Processes could use improvement (acquisitions will understand this better than most)

review_title: SAP best place to work
pros: SAP is a good place to learn new technologies. Also, the policies of the company gives sense of satisfaction to the employees.
cons: people need to be more warm welcoming in terms of accepting others who are travelling from other cities.

review_title: A big organisation made up of small innovative companies
pros:
- You're looked after as an employee
 - Benefits are really very good
 - Great pay structure and continued pay increases
 - Good bonus structure
 - SAP is paranoid and is always working hard to buck the trend, always tries to be different and really do the best for its customers
 - SAP isn't what you think - yes, it is huge, but inside it's like micro companies and departments where innovation and being different is key
 - It's not stuffy - I have worked for many start-ups and I would say SAP innovates more than any of them. And has the huge benefit that you have with the backing of such a big organisation
 - I would say I am proud to work for SAP and enjoy handling objections from those that think SAP is still the "ERP vendor of old".
 - SAP is a job for life in a positive way. You can move anywhere in the organisation, travel the world, if you are willing to work for it.
 - Results-based: you can work from home, work from the beech, work anywhere. As long as you care, do your job and show passion you'll go a long way.
cons:
- HR is behind emails and tickets, I would love to have the chance to meet HR on a more personal level
 - Once you've gone through your inductions whilst there is a lot of online learnings thrown at you, you do feel a little alone.
 - You have to get lucky with your manager, I think the management layer makes or breaks your experience at SAP.
 - SAP can breed 'career junkies' - where you'll only succeed if you appease the right people, rather than being fantastic at your job or the right person to succeed. It still is who you know not what you know or who you really are. But perhaps that's life and not necessarily just SAP.
 - I regularly receive 1 billion emails each day!
 - Portal portal portal - I'd like human human human please.

review_title: Presales Expert
pros: SAP is committed to truly helping their customers achieve their business objectives.  They continue to innovate each and every day and are focused on building business solutions for the future.  They empower their workforce to think outside the box, they respect the ability to balance work and personal needs and trust their employees to get the job done.
cons: As with any very large organization, their are many resources and lots of information.  Information overload can get hard to manage and organize.  But better too much than not enough.

review_title: World class opportunities
pros:
I work in a customer facing position at SAP. I have had the opportunity to work with Fortune 10 companies, small companies, public sector entities and everything in between. The reputation of SAP gives me instant credibility with the customer as the vendor representative. I have the opportunity to develop a trusted advisor relationship with my customers and work with them on business critical projects; giving direction, providing leadership and support as they implement SAP's software products across their company.  
It's easy to maintain and build that credibility with the wealth of documentation and colleague support. I am able to find answers to product questions and develop solutions to implementation challenges knowing I can count on other colleagues across the company supporting me.
SAP gives me the opportunity to do what I love to do every day at customers around the world that I would never have the opportunity to touch otherwise. I have the freedom to assume as much responsibility as I wish and rise as high in the company as I am able. 
Expertise, hard work and results are generously rewarded based on my abilities.
cons:
Customer facing positions can be high stress since you're the face of SAP and you're dealing with decisions that cost millions of dollars and can make or break the customer's company financially. You have to continually study and add to your body of knowledge as new information becomes available on an almost daily basis. You have to continually increase your skill sets to remain relevant.
This is not a job, it's a lifestyle. If you don't approach it that way, you'll burn out quickly. The advantage of SAP is the (earned) perception that customers have about the quality of our employees. The disadvantage is that you have to live up to that perception every minute you're in front of the customer.
If you're looking for a 9 to 5 job with very specifically defined, repeatable tasks, SAP is probably not for you.

review_title: Purpose Drive Company
pros:
Most of the large companies have visions inspiring the employee for higher purpose. It is one of few companies taking the vision into day to day life and really live by it. The CEO is a great ambassador for the vision and has been always highlighting the vision statement "help the world run better and improve people's life" in all-hands and all-employee emails. 

Each year in October (Month of Services), the employees are encouraged to volunteer in the community during work hours. 

Compensations (including benefits) are very competitive on the market. Bonus payout has been consistent with great financial performance.

The perk of Lunch On Us is a great win. I am not aware of any other tech companies offering such perk to employees. There are variety of food we can choose to use the lunch card. 

The company has great leaders in defining, revising and driving the strategy in winning the market. Some decisions such as S/4HANA is a great success with strong leaders.
cons:
It is probably one of the common "Cons" for global company with many line-of-businesses and product lines. The company is aware of the siloes and working towards simplified organizational structures.

ABAP technology has been used in core product lines. There is a lock-in for technology if working for product lines such as ERP or S/4HANA. 

Business travel for revenue enabling roles is very limited to control the budget. The investment is mainly on knowledge transfer for my line-of-business. Others will mostly be replaced with video conferencing technologies. Personally I believe the team building benefit of business travel for achieving high performance and job satisfaction.

review_title: Entrepreneurial spirit, collaborative, tons of growth potential
pros:
CAREER FLEXIBILITY: I started my career in pre-sales, moved to product development, and  looking for a new challenge, I reinvented my career in marketing. I can't imagine another company where I'd have been able to reboot my career *with support from management* as I have here. 

COLLABORATIVE CULTURE: The level of collaboration here is really amazing. Talk to SAPers and the most common  "plus" you hear about the company is "the people"... Can't find information you're looking for? Send an email to someone you don't know who has that keyword in their profile, and no matter where in the world they are, they're going to help you or help you find someone with the information. I've never had someone say to me "that's not my job". It's amazing. And uncommon.

ENTREPRENEURIAL SPIRIT: SAP is big, but everyone I talk to agrees the thing we love is the way you can mold your role/job and career here - and if you decide you want to leave to try something different or you're taking a break from work to take care of family, and want to come back to SAP you'll find that additional experience viewed as a positive (and in the case of a break to care for children/family, you will find support for your re-entry).  That said, if you are someone who wants a job that's highly-directed (strong oversight, active management by your boss on a day to day basis with daily feedback/input) this is not going to be a place for you in most cases. This is a highly-independent work environment in the vast majority of cases.

CULTURE: I'm going to sound marketing-y for a minute, but imagine working for a company that is EDGE Certified (leading business certification for gender equality), has a global Tech Diversity & Inclusion team, has offices and customers in ~180 countries;  has a major Corporate Social Responsibility organization that coordinates volunteers for service activities, and during 2 mos of the year offers paid time off to participate in volunteer activities;  and donation-matching is offered. SAP has been in industry leader since 2014 delivering an Annual "Integrated Report" which considers the corporate impact on the environment and our sustainability, to use a holistic view of our total impact beyond finances as our measure of success each year.  We also have a range of employee interest groups including Business Women's Network, Black Employees Network, and are one of Workplace Pride's Top 10 companies in the world for LGBTQ-friendly  workplace environment and policies.  Inter-cultural training is provided to help teams in different countries understand how to work and communicate more effectively with each other. This is not about political correctness; it's about being respectful of others' cultures and different points of view, even if you have different beliefs. 

GLOBAL REACH/IMPACT:  If you eat it, drink it, drive it, wear it, or use it in your daily life, our customers probably make it. E.g., 78% of the world's food supply is delivered by SAP customers (including 82% of the world's chocolate supply, and 72% of the world's beer).  That is incredible - but it also is a key reason our Board and CEO have a mission to "Help the world run better and improve people's lives". If your company touches 70% of financial transactions that happen daily, globally, you have an opportunity and a responsibility to think about how that reach can benefit people - not just ourselves.  A lot of people struggle wanting to work somewhere that makes a difference - I've found working at SAP I have a long-term career where I do make a difference, in ways that I can't imagine other companies could. Very cool.

SUPPORT TO INNOVATE & TAKE RISKS:  the CEO says "tell it like it is" and take informed risks and as far as I've seen, this is supported (standard caveat of, "when it's done in a constructive, and respectful way".  This may partly be a function of German work culture, but I've found the openness here refreshing compared with friends' experiences.

PURPOSE-DRIVEN: SAP's mission FOR YEARS is "Help the world run better and improve people's lives". This was our mission before it was 'cool'. This was our mission before terms like 'green-washing' and 'virtue-signaling' came into mainstream conversations. We have had CSR programs for more than 20 years; we have had sustainability programs for at least a decade; we've had excellent benefits like paid parental leave for adoptions, paid bereavement leave (immediate family ), affordable healthcare, paid vacation starting at 3 wks (sick days are separate from vacation days), subsidized public transportation, and our larger offices there are employee cafeterias where you can get subsidized lunches (hot food, not just deli-style food), sourced locally when possible, and with vegetarian and vegan options. 

TRAINING & CAREER SUPPORT:  a robust program for growing within the company means once you join SAP, you can do a wide range of jobs and change careers - as I did - multiple times without leaving the company. I personally attribute this to the German business model, which brings in young talent and nurtures it, versus the typical American model where recruiters look for existing-employed individuals and attempt to hire them away.  This model means a lot of people stay at SAP for a long time compared to other tech companies - but the ability to move around within the company and try different jobs keeps your career fresh and interesting. There are formal and informal job training programs, formal Mentoring and Coaching programs, internal recruiters to help people move around, and - one of the best things - opportunities to work in other countries for short term or permanent assignments, with the most opportunities in Asia, Europe, and Latin America.
cons:
LARGE BUSINESS COMPLEXITY:  the entrepreneurial spirit is real, but SAP still is a large enterprise, with a broad portfolio of software and there's just a layer (or layers) of complexity that's unavoidable.  Approvals are layered and things don't move as fast as you want/should. No worse than other places, better than many. 

RE-ORGs: all companies in tech go through reorganizations more frequently than companies in traditional fields like manufacturing, but SAP is somewhat known for moving teams and organizations around faster than average.  Depending on your role in the company, you could have a new focus in your job every year without actually moving to a new team. 

If you hate change and having to constantly learn new things, this will be challenging for you.  But if you get bored easily, this could be a positive even if it can be frustrating.

review_title: Awesome Place to Work
pros:
- The company's long-term prospects are looking great. Vancouver location especially has lots of opportunity, because it's home to development on SAP's most successful "homemade" (non-acquisition) cloud product (SAP Analytics Cloud). The product is also a part of the core strategy now.

- Very respectful, healthy place to work at. The company has really good values, result being that everyone is professional, respectful and nice to each other.

- Lots of really smart people to work with and learn from.

- There's lots of really challenging, interesting work to go around. Lots of movement towards newer technologies as well. There will be no shortage of demand for development work, or opportunities to challenge yourself if that's what you want to do.

- Good work-life balance is promoted. Devs aren't on-call all the time. No expectation to be constantly crunching, unlike other places.

- High performers are recognized and rewarded. Lots of opportunity for advancement.

- People with ideas and opinions on how things can improve are encouraged to share, especially if you're willing to be part of the solution.
cons:
- SAP is in the "A-tier" of compensation, but not "S-tier". There are a few other companies in Vancouver that pay the top of the top (about 2.5x the average), whereas SAP is in the level below that (2x the average). The kind of talent at SAP is about the same, so you do take a pay cut in exchange for better work-life balance. This also causes issues with losing some really good talent to competitors.

- Culture changes as product in Vancouver Labs starts to mature. Less startup-like perks, less free-flow spending on miscellaneous things like free food, events, etc.

- Technology challenges such as old frameworks that can be difficult to work with (SAP UI5), technical debt, etc. Still lots of work left to overcome these challenges, all the while needing to balance the need for aggressive product growth.

review_title: Great People, Great Opportunities, Great Benefits
pros:
I've worked at SAP for many years and I'm continually impressed with how helpful employees are to each other. It drives me to make an extra effort so that anyone who comes to me leaves feeling that I removed a big unknown or roadblock for them. I believe these small behaviours add up to a great performance from the whole organization. 
After years at SAP, the one thing that has kept me is the ability to work on what I want. There are so many industries and technologies that SAP covers that you can start in a new technology area or run a large team or even have your new idea turned into a business.
Finally, the benefits are very good - salary, bonuses, lunch card but more importantly I find for some are nice extras are the health benefits and support services like counseling to career path support and even resume writing. Also, I would like to add that working from home has been hugely helpful as I start a family as I can manage my life and work schedule together.
cons: I believe it's hard to say there is a con with SAP, or if there is, they will likely solve it. It's more like, one is looking for red and SAP only has blue, or blue, green, orange, black. So a con might be that SAP doesn't fit what one is looking for right now. Do some research and learn what SAP can offer you. SAP is a large company with many offices. If you want to work in a small social networking startup and like the challenge of fighting it out to overcome all odds for a big win (or big loss) then maybe SAP isn't for you. With that said, if you want to experiment in a safer environment, with strong support services, access to customers and access to experienced people then  SAP could work for you.

review_title: Positive introduction the the complex world of Enterprise software
pros: The company really does take care of it's people.  Even if they have some massive shift in strategy, I have to admit they do a good job of trying to shift peoples roles instead of just letting them go.  They also offer a decent severence strategy to give you time to find another role inside the company if they do let you go.  The benefits are good.  The people are usually the best of the best and are very helpful.  There are some attitudes and egos but most people are great to work with.  There are tons of opportunities to advance here and it's encouraged.  SAP is also a great career experience and you become a valuable commodity after a couple of years in sales.
cons: In the sales side, the biggest negative to working here is that the company changes their strategy yearly, which isn't terribly odd execpt that it usually means you'll be in a different role in a different territory from year to year.  The exception is if you are high level field AE.  This means you have one year to make hey because you know you'll be doing something different come January.  Also, don't plan on taking vacation in sales during the last quarter, especially right at the end of the year.  That's when all the big deals close.  As an Inside sales person, there's also only so much affect you can have on a larger deal.  Due to the way the sale organization is structured, an SAP partner is involved as well as an SAP feild person, which can often reduce your role on large deals to admin and reporting guy.

review_title: Great culture, nice people and good opportunity to do many things
job_title: Senior Development Project Consultant in Walldorf, Baden-Wurttemberg
pros:
SAP is the only relevant software vendor outside the US and that is not without a reason. It has fostered a great global culture with executives, important locations and people from all over the world. 

I have worked at SAP for 8 years (including my student internship) and I have almost only met helpful and nice people both in Germany and the US. Even with senior executives the experience were mostly good. 

The company has given me the opportunity to work in the US straight out of university for which I will be always grateful. I have had great mentors and am very lucky to be where I am in my career.  

SAP is financially generous to its employees and allows for a fantastic work-life balance both on campus with health options (gym, running track), free food and access to the latest gadgets. Also off-campus, the company allows to work from home when needed to enable the employee to attend to personal matters as long as the job is getting done.
cons:
It is somewhat hard to explore new opportunities within the company if you're not working in a hub location like Walldorf, Palo Alto or Newtown Square. That is not a fault of SAP but just a systemic problem of satellite locations. 

One big problem however is that the top talent program which SAP offers to its employees who are chosen to be in that "special" pool of people is more of a joke as it neither offers opportunity provides access to things other employees don't get...it clearly is not a top talent program.
